1.  The name, rank, badge number and present assignment of the person being disciplined; 
2.  The date, time and location of the misconduct; 
3.  The section number of the violated rule and common name of the infraction; 
4.  A complete statement of the facts of the misconduct; 
5.  The punishment imposed or recommended; 
6.  The written signature, badge number and rank of the preparing officer and his or her position in relation to the member being disciplined. 
C.  Distribution of Report. Reports of disciplinary action shall be distributed as follows by the officer imposing or recommending the disciplinary action: 
1.  Original to the chief of police; 
2.  The member being disciplined; 
3.  The officer imposing or recommending the action. 
D.  Appeals. Appeals from the penalties imposed as a disciplinary measure may be taken as provided in the provisions of NJSA 40A:14-147 through 40A:14-151, as amended, inclusive, and the ordinances of the township. 
(Prior code § 2-9.32) 
2.48.330 - Processing of complaints by citizens. 
    Complaints by a citizen against a member of the police department shall be processed in accordance with the following rules: 
A.  During Normal Business Hours. During normal business hours such complaints shall be referred to the chief of police. 
B.  Other Than Normal Business Hours. At other times notify the lieutenant who will take one of the following actions: 
1.  Instruct the highest ranking officer then on duty to receive and document the complaint; 
2.  Receive and investigate the complaint himself or herself; 
3.  If, in the opinion of the lieutenant, the incident is of sufficient gravity, the lieutenant shall notify the chief of police regardless of the hour and, in addition, shall take any immediate action necessary to preserve the integrity of the department until the arrival of the commanding officer. 
C.  Investigation of Complaint. The member assigned the investigation of an alleged act of misconduct on the part of a member of the department shall conduct a thorough and accurate investigation. Such investigation shall include obtaining a signed statement from all parties concerned when necessary and pertinent, gathering and preserving any physical evidence pertaining to the complaint and obtaining all other information bearing on the matter. 
D.  Report of Investigation and Findings. An alleged act of misconduct must be investigated and the results of the investigation must be submitted in a written report entitled, "Report of Investigation and Findings". The investigating member shall summarize the pertinent facts, including: 
1.  A summary of the complaint or alleged act of misconduct; 
2.  Pertinent portions of the statements of all parties to the incident; 
3.  A description of the incident, physical evidence and other evidence important to the case; 
4.  The observations and conclusions of the investigating member or members. 
E.  Inclusion of One of the Findings to be Listed in Report. One of the findings of an alleged act of misconduct listed below will be included in the "Report of Investigation and Findings": 
1.  Investigation indicates that the act or acts complained of did not occur or did not involve department personnel; 
2.  The act did occur, but was justified, lawful and proper; 
3.  The investigation disclosed evidence insufficient to prove clearly the allegations made in the complaint; 
4.  The investigation disclosed evidence sufficient to prove clearly the allegations made in the complaint; 
5.  The investigation established that the subject of the investigation in the "Report of Investigation and Findings" was not involved in the alleged incident. 
(Prior code § 2-9.33) 
2.48.340 - Procedures upon charges being preferred. 
    No command officer or police officer shall be removed from office or suspended, reduced in rank or subject to other penalty, except for just cause, as hereinbefore provided, and then only after a hearing upon the charge or charges of the cause of the complaint referred against such member, which charge or charges shall be submitted, investigated, heard and disposed of in the following manner: 
A.  All charges preferred against a member of the police department shall be in writing and signed by the person who is making the same and a copy delivered to the chief of police and the individual charged. 
B.  The chief of police, upon receiving such charges, shall forthwith investigate the same and, if he or she shall find such charges to be true, may impose upon the offender punishment consisting of a warning, reprimand or suspension from duty without pay for a period not to exceed five days. The chief of police shall inform the township committee, in writing, of the imposition of any such penalty within twenty-four (24) hours thereof. 
C.  If the chief of police shall determine that any charges are true or that the severity of the offense warrants a greater punishment than that which he or she is empowered to impose, he or she shall transmit such charges to the township committee. Upon receipt of such charges, the township committee shall promptly cause written notice of the same to be served upon the accused and set a date of not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than thirty (30) days, to appear before the township committee for a hearing upon such charges. At the time and place fixed for such hearing, the township committee shall receive evidence in support of the charges and shall afford to the accused an opportunity to be heard, to cross-examine witnesses appearing in support of the charges, to present evidence on his or her own behalf, to be represented by counsel and, in general, to permit the accused every opportunity to make a defense. If, upon conclusion of the hearing, the township committee shall determine that the charges have been established, it shall, in its discretion, remove the offender from office, reduce the offender in rank or suspend the offender without pay for a period not to exceed six months. 
D.  Nothing contained herein shall deprive any member of the police department of any right of appeal accorded by the laws of the state of New Jersey. 
(Prior code § 2-9.34) 
2.48.350 - Reports of dereliction of duty. 
    The chief of police shall promptly report to the township committee each and every case of dereliction of duty of any member of the police department coming in any way to his or her knowledge and also any complaints made to him or her against any member of the police department. 
(Prior code § 2-9.35) 
2.48.360 - Disposing of complaint. 
    After conclusion of the hearing as set forth in the preceding subsections, the township committee shall adopt a written resolution setting forth findings of facts and conclusions based thereon disposing of the complaint against the member of the police department. In the event that the township committee finds that the member of the police department has committed the offense described in the complaint, it shall set forth in detail the penalty to be imposed upon such member of the police department. 
(Prior code § 2-9.36) 
2.48.370 - Opportunity for a fair trial. 
    It is intended by this section to give a fair trial to any person against whom a charge or charges may be preferred for any cause under the provisions of this chapter. It is the further intention to provide a reasonable opportunity for such a person to make a defense regarding such charge, if any, he or she has or chooses to make. 
(Prior code § 2-9.37) 
2.48.380 - Scheduling of trial. 
    If any officer or member of the police department shall be suspended pending trial before the township committee on any such charge, such trial shall be commenced within thirty days, unless such suspension was based upon a criminal offense as charged by the Grand Jury. In such later event, the trial before the township committee shall be suspended pending final disposition of the indictment returned by the Grand Jury. The trial before the township committee shall take place within thirty (30) days after final disposition on the indictment handed up by the Grand Jury. 
(Prior code § 2-9.38) 
2.48.390 - Powers of township committee-Enforcement of subpoena. 
    The township committee shall have the power to hear and determine the charge or charges made against an officer of the police department and shall have the power to subpoena witnesses and/or documentary evidence. The Superior Court shall have jurisdiction to enforce any such subpoena. 
(Prior code § 2-9.39) 
2.48.400 - Legal defense. 
    Whenever an officer of the police department is a defendant in any action or legal proceeding arising out of or incidental to the performance of his or her duty, the township committee shall provide such member or officer with reasonably necessary means for the defense of such action or proceeding, including reasonable attorney's fees, but not for defense costs in a disciplinary proceeding instituted by the township or in a criminal proceeding instituted as a result of a complaint on behalf of the township. If any such criminal proceeding instituted by or on behalf of the township or the state of New Jersey shall be dismissed or finally determined in favor of the member or officer, he or she shall be reimbursed for the reasonable expense of his or her defense. 
(Prior code § 2-9.40) 
2.48.410 - Right to appeal conviction. 
    Any member of the police department who has been convicted of any violation of any of the rules or regulations of such department by the township committee may appeal such conviction in the manner provided by law. 
(Prior code § 2-9.41) 
2.48.420 - Violation-Penalties. 
    All charges against members of the police department shall be thoroughly examined by the township committee and upon any member of the department being convicted by the township committee for the breaking of any rules, regulation or orders of the department, the township committee may, in lieu of dismissal from the department, impose such penalties as in its judgment are warranted by the character of the offense. 
(Prior code § 2-9.42) 
2.48.430 - Violations as part of personnel records. 
    All rules and regulations violations shall remain in a part of the police officer's service record for a period of two years, unless otherwise provided in the rules. If there has been no reoccurrence during the two-year period, such violation shall be expunged and deemed never to have occurred. 
(Prior code § 2-9.43) 
2.48.440 - Compensation during period of suspension prior to determination. 
    Consistent with the foregoing subsections, whenever any command officer or police officer is charged under the law of the state or the United States with an offense, such police officer may be suspended with pay until the case against such officer is disposed of at trial, until the complaint is dismissed or until the prosecution is terminated; provided, however, that if a Grand Jury returns an indictment against the officer, or the officer is charged with an offense which is a crime of any degree or which involves moral turpitude or dishonesty, the officer may be suspended without pay until the case is disposed of at trial, until the complaint is dismissed or until the prosecution is terminated. If a suspended police officer is found not guilty at trial, if the charges are dismissed or if the prosecution is terminated, the officer shall be reinstated in his or her position, and shall be entitled to recover all pay withheld during the period of suspension, subject to any disciplinary proceedings or administrative action. If any police officer is suspended with pay and is found guilty of or pleads guilty to any of the charges brought against him or her, or to a lesser charge or charges, such police officer shall reimburse the township for all pay received by him or her during the period of his or her suspension. 
(Prior code § 2-9.44) 
2.48.450 - Compensation during suspension for member found guilty. 
    When any member of the police department is suspended from office, tried, found guilty and afterwards reinstated, he or she shall not receive any pay for the period of such suspension unless otherwise ordered by the township committee. 
(Prior code § 2-9.45) 
2.48.460 - Discipline as part of personnel records. 
    In those cases where a complaint(s) against an officer is sustained, the charging form and disposition of charges shall remain a permanent part of the police officer's personnel file. All other documents or materials relative to discipline, inclusive of, but not limited to, the internal affairs investigation reports shall remain a part of the internal affairs file and shall be confidential. 
(Ord. 10-2000: prior code § 2-9.47) 
2.48.470 - Disposition of property coming into possession of police department. 
    When tangible personal property comes into the possession of the police department by finding or recovery, and if the owner, or his or her whereabouts is unknown and cannot be ascertained, or if such owner shall refuse to receive such property, then the property shall not be disposed of for six months, except in the case of motor vehicles, which shall be kept for three months. In any such case, the township committee, by resolution, may then provide for the sale, in whole or in part, of any such property at public auction after notice of a designated time and place therefor, not less than ten (10) days prior thereto is published in a newspaper circulating within the township. The proceeds of any such sale shall be paid into the general treasury of the township. All unclaimed money coming into the possession of the police department shall be turned over to the township treasurer within forty-eight (48) hours for retention in a trust account and after six months, if unclaimed by any person entitled thereto, be paid into the general treasury. 
(Prior code § 2-9.46) 
2.48.480 - Police related services during off-duty hours. 
A.  Full-time members of the East Greenwich police department be and are authorized and empowered to perform police-related services for private persons or entities during off-duty hours subject to the following terms and conditions: 
1.  Any person or entity requesting police-related services during off-duty hours shall make application therefore to the chief of police, in writing, with said writing to include the dates and hours of requested services, the nature and scope of the duties to be performed and such further information as the chief of police, in his or her sole determination, may require. Additionally, all applicants for such services shall provide documentary evidence for workers compensation insurance, that meets or exceeds New Jersey State Statute of required limits, for such employee-related services and shall provide a certificate of additional insurance naming the township of East Greenwich as a certificate holder and an "additional insured" on a general liability insurance policy having policy limits not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence. The said certificate should also show the limits of coverage for automobile as well as any excess limits of coverage above required minimums. 
2.  Rules and general or special orders governing the conduct and establishment of off-duty services shall be established by the chief of police, and all such rules and general or special orders governing the operation of the police department shall apply to members of the department while working off-duty assignments. 
3.  All payments for services rendered shall be placed in an off-duty police account to be known and established as the "Police Special Trust Account" and all funds collected for services rendered and disbursements made shall be by and through such account. 
4.  All members of the police department shall be paid for services performed on the scheduled pay dates and on the submission of a time voucher approved by the chief of police, or his designee, and presented to the township of East Greenwich for payment from the aforesaid account. 
5.  The chief of police or his designee shall bill for all such services rendered by members of the department and shall keep such further books and records as may be deemed appropriate by the township of East Greenwich or the township auditor. 
6.  All assignments for outside services shall be on a voluntary basis and in accordance with the rules and general or special orders to be established by the chief of police for off-duty assignments. 
B.  Payments to off-duty police officers for such work shall be in an amount per hour as set from time to time by ordinance of the township committee for the township of East Greenwich. 
C.  Rates charged to a person or entity requesting police-related services for such off-duty assignments shall be in an amount as set from time to time by ordinance of the township committee for the township of East Greenwich. The calculation of this rate shall be based upon the hourly payment to the offduty officer, the township's matching share of social security and medicare and unemployment, and any such other employer matching costs or expenses, worker's compensation insurance, administrative costs of maintaining time records, payroll processing, and additional liability insurance costs associated with the services provided. 
(Ord. 33-2003: Ord. 25-2003; Ord. 24-2003) 
Chapter 2.52 - INTERMUNICIPAL POLICE ASSISTANCE 

2.52.010 - Findings. 
    N.J.S.A 40A:14-156.1, et seq., provides that the governing bodies of two or more municipalities, by reciprocal ordinances, may enter into agreements with each other for mutual police aid in case of emergencies. The township deems it to be to the best interest of all the residents of this community as well as the residents of all the communities of the county of Gloucester that reciprocal agreements be created providing for intermunicipal police assistance during any and all emergencies. 
(Prior code § 2-15.1) 
2.52.020 - Reciprocal agreement established. 
    The township hereby established a reciprocal agreement with each and every municipality within the county of Gloucester for intermunicipal police assistance at times of any and all emergencies. This chapter shall become effective as to each and every other municipality within the county of Gloucester at such times that the municipality has in the past or may in the future adopt an ordinance providing for the same terms and conditions as set forth herein. 
(Prior code § 2-15.2) 
2.52.030 - Maintenance of municipal expenses. 
    The township agrees to maintain all expenses incurred by members of its municipal police department for emergency assistance rendered within or without the boundaries of this community. The township shall make no claim for reimbursement from any municipality for damages, injuries, wages and the like for aid rendered by the members of its police department through any other community adopting an ordinance with the same terms of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 2-15.3) 
2.52.040 - Intermunicipal police authority. 
    In accordance with N.J.S.A. 40:14A-156.1, et seq., the members of the police department of the township, and of any other municipality passing an ordinance with the same terms and conditions as this chapter, while on duty rendering assistance to any other municipality shall have the same powers, authority and immunities as have the members of the police force of the municipality in which such assistance is being rendered. 
(Prior code § 2-15.4) 
2.52.050 - Local chief of police-Senior ranking officer. 
    At such times that an emergency may occur and intermunicipal police aid is requested, the chief of police of the municipality wherein the emergency exists shall be the senior ranking officer of all members of any police department which may be rendering assistance within the confines of the municipality. 
(Prior code § 2-15.5) 
Chapter 2.56 - BOARD OF HEALTH 

2.56.010 - Membership-Term of office. 
    There shall be a board of health for the township which shall consist of the members of the township committee. 
(Prior code § 2-10.1) 
(Ord. No. 27-2011, 12-27-2011) 
2.56.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The board of health shall adopt rules and regulations for its government. The board shall appoint a local registrar of vital statistics, clerk and sanitary inspector, and may appoint such other officers or assistants as it may deem necessary. All appointees of the board shall be governed by the rules of the board and be subject to all laws, rules and regulations governing such officers, and may be removed for cause by the board. The term of office of the local registrar shall be three years and until his or her successor has been appointed and qualified; and any vacancy occurring in the office shall be filled for the unexpired term only. The sanitary inspector shall promptly report to the board of health every violation of the health ordinances of the township coming to his or her view or knowledge. The chief of police of the township, when on police duty, shall serve as special sanitary inspector. 
(Prior code § 2-10.2) 
Chapter 2.60 - REDEVELOPMENT AND HOUSING LAW 

2.60.010 - Inclusion of township. 
    Pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40A:12A, seq., the township consents to and requests to be included within the area of operation of the housing authority of Gloucester County. 
(Ord. 17-2001 § b; prior code § 2-17.1) 
2.60.020 - Powers, duties and obligations of township. 
    The powers, duties and obligations of the township in relation to the powers, duties and obligations of the housing authority of Gloucester County will be governed by the provisions of N.J.S.A. 40A:12A, et seq. 
(Ord. 17-2001 § c; prior code § 2-17.2) 
Chapter 2.64 - ENVIRONMENTAL COMMISSION 

2.64.010 - Establishment. 
    The township committee considers it to be a need in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare that an environmental commission be established for the protection, development and use of natural resources, including water resources, located within the territorial limits of the township and therefore there is hereby created an environmental commission which shall be known as the "Environmental Commission of the Town-ship". 
(Prior code § 2-18.1) 
2.64.020 - Purpose. 
    The creation of the environmental commission is for the following purposes: 
A.  To promote the conservation and development of the environmental quality of the township; 
B.  To plan, implement and inform the public about local conservation programs; 
C.  To compile and keep an index of all open areas publicly or privately owned, including open marshlands, swamps and other wetlands; 
D.  To conduct research into the possible use of the open areas and the preservation or protection of their resources such as air and water; 
E.  To recommend to the planning board plans and programs for inclusion in a municipal master plan and the development and use of such areas; 
F.  To inform the public of ways and means of promoting and encouraging the betterment of the quality of our environment; 
G.  To identify all scenic, historic, park and recreation sites and make recommendations for their protection and improvement; 
H.  To make recommendations as to legislation for control of excavation and soil erosion and other activities affecting the landscape; 
I.  To review all proposed road locations and subdivisions for the environmental impact when requested to do so by the township committee, planning board, or other township agencies; 
J.  To promote good architectural and landscape design for all developments with adequate provisions for park and green areas therein; 
K.  To manage donated or purchased lands for conservation purposes and operate conservation programs; 
L.  To act as the coordinating agency of the community on conservation matters and a liaison between local conservation needs and regional, state and federal agencies administering to those needs. 
(Prior code § 2-18.2) 
(Ord. 01-2008) 
2.64.030 - Functions. 
    The function of the environmental commission shall be limited to advising the planning board, the township committee and all subsidiary agencies thereof on the areas as hereinafter delineated, receiving and disseminating information of such issues and securing federal and state functions for such purposes. The commissions shall not have any power whatsoever to legislate or make final determinations on any pending subdivisions or other similar applications, but shall be permitted to review the same for the purposes of making recommendations to the appropriate township agencies when so requested. 
(Prior code § 2-18.3) 
2.64.040 - Membership-Terms-Compensation. 
A.  Membership. The environmental commission shall consist of seven members to be appointed by the township committee, with one member being a member of the planning board. All members must be residents of the township. 
B.  Terms. One member shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 1988; two members shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 1989; two members shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 1990; and two members shall be appointed for a term ending December 31, 1991. The planning board member of the commission shall be appointed for a term not to exceed the remainder of his or her term on the planning board. All subsequent appointments of members to the commission, except for the filling of vacancies for unexpired terms, shall be for terms of three years beginning the first day of January of the first year of the term. 
C.  Compensation. All members of the commission shall serve during their terms in office without any compensation. 
(Prior code § 2-18.4) 
2.64.050 - Designation of chairperson-Bylaws. 
    The township committee shall designate one of the members to serve as chairperson and presiding officer of the environmental commission. The commission is authorized to adopt bylaws governing the procedural operation of the commission. 
(Prior code § 2-18.5) 
2.64.060 - Removal of members. 
    The township committee may remove any member of the environmental commission for cause on written charges served upon the member and after a fair and impartial hearing thereon, at which the member shall be entitled to be heard in person or by counsel. A vote of two - thirds of the entire membership shall be needed to remove any member, and no member shall be removed for political reasons. 
(Prior code § 2-18.6) 
2.64.070 - Acquisitions of property. 
    The environmental commission, subject to the approval of the township committee in the form of a two-thirds vote in the affirmative of the entire members of the township committee, may acquire property, both real and personal, in the name of the township by gift, purchase, grant, bequest, devise or lease for any of its purposes and shall administer the same for such purposes subject to the terms of the conveyance or gift. Such acquisition may be to acquire the fee or any lesser interest, development, right, easement including conservation easements, covenant or other contractual right including a conveyance on conditions or with limitations or reversions, as may be necessary to acquire, maintain, improve, protect, limit the future use of or otherwise conserve and protect and properly utilize open spaces and other land and water areas in the township. 
(Prior code § 2-18.7) 
2.64.080 - Control of acquired land. 
    The environmental commission, subject to the approval of the township committee in the form of a two-thirds vote in the affirmative of the entire members of the township committee, may have control of lands acquired for the purposes herein stated, and may adopt suitable rules and regulations for the use thereof and the conduct of all persons while on or using the same. Absent approval by the township committee as specified above, control of any such acquired lands shall remain with the township committee. 
(Prior code § 2-18.8) 
2.64.090 - Records and reports. 
    The environmental commission shall keep records of its meetings and activities, and shall make a semi-annual report on or before the first day of January and on or before the first day of July and submit the same to the township committee. The report shall be comprehensive and detailed governing operation, receipts, disbursements and expenditures for the full year. 
(Prior code § 2-18.9) 
2.64.100 - Appropriation of funds. 
    The township committee may appropriate funds for the expenses incurred by the environmental commission. But under no circumstances shall any expenses exceed the limits of the funds appropriated to it. 
(Prior code § 2-18.10) 
Chapter 2.68 - ENTERPRISE COMMISSION 

2.68.010 - Created. 
    A local enterprise commission is created to be known as the "Enterprise Commission of the Township." 
(Ord. 2-1996 (part): prior code § 2-13.1) 
2.68.020 - Members-Terms-Compensation. 
    The Commission shall consist of nine members appointed by the township committee and shall be a body corporate having the powers conferred by the Laws of New Jersey. Each member shall be, for the last five years preceding his or her appointment, a citizen of the United States and a qualified voter of the State of New Jersey. Two members shall be appointed for a period of one year, two members shall be appointed for two years, two members shall be appointed for three years, two members shall be appointed for four years and one member shall be appointed for five years. At the expiration of each of the above terms, a new member shall be appointed for a term of five years. The members shall serve without compensation. The members of the commission shall choose annually from among its members a chairperson or president, and such other officers as it may deem necessary. The mayor shall be an ex officio member thereof. 
(Ord. 2-1996 (part): prior code § 2-13.2) 
2.68.030 - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies shall be promptly filled by appointment by the mayor for the unexpired term thereof. Members shall serve for their respective terms and until their successors are appointed and qualify. 
(Prior code § 2-13.3) 
2.68.040 - Qualifications. 
    Each member shall be chosen with a special view to his or her qualifications and fitness for service on the commission. The member shall have had at least ten (10) years of experience in industry or commerce, shall be conversant with the industrial needs and facilities of the township and shall be of known devotion to public service. 
(Prior code § 2-13.4) 
2.68.050 - Oath of office. 
    Each member and officer of the commission, before assuming office, shall take and subscribe an oath that he or she will faithfully, and impartially discharge the duties of the office. 
(Prior code § 2-13.5) 
2.68.060 - Conflict of interest-Bond required. 
    No member, officer or employee of the commission shall be interested, directly or indirectly, in any contracts for work or materials used by the commission, or in any sales, leases or agreements in connection with lands, buildings or other property owned or controlled by it, or in any fees or compensation of any kind paid to any broker, architect, engineer, merchant or other person doing business with the commission or in any other transaction of or with the commission or the benefits or profits thereof. The members and officers may be required to furnish bonds to the commission, to secure the faithful discharge of their duties, in form, amount and with such surety as may, from time to time, be required by resolution of the township committee. 
(Prior code § 2-13.6) 
2.68.070 - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum of the commission. 
(Prior code § 2-13.7) 
2.68.080 - Recruiting employees-Availability of services. 
    Insofar as may be practicable, the employees and assistants required by the commission shall be recruited from the public officers and employees of the township served by the commission. The township attorney shall be the counsel to the commission; the township engineer shall be the engineer of the commission; and the several departments of the township government shall be available to the commission for the purposes of the commission's business. Township employees serving the commission shall do so without compensation other than their regular compensation as employees of the township. The commission, from time to time, shall make known to the mayor its wants in the nature of services by employees of the township, and the mayor shall designate which of the township's employees, if any, shall render such services. To the extent that the commission shall deem it necessary to carry on its function, and to the extent that it shall consider the services of existing employees of the township insufficient for its purposes, it may employ such additional employees or services and at such compensation as may be approved by resolution of the township committee. The commission's requirements in this direction shall be submitted, from time to time, in writing, to the committee. 
(Prior code § 2-13.8) 
2.68.090 - Office. 
    The commission shall have and maintain a suitable office, where its maps, plans, documents, records and accounts shall be kept, subject to public inspection at such times and under such reasonable regulations as the commission shall determine. If practicable, existing office facilities of the township shall be used without charge by the township, and the office and similar equipment of the township shall, wherever possible, be used by and be made available for the use of the commission, without charge. 
(Prior code § 2-13.9) 
Chapter 2.72 - COMMISSION ON SENIOR SERVICES 

2.72.010 - Establishment and name. 
    The name of the existing township commission on aging shall be changed to the commission on senior services, as set forth herein, effective January 1, 2007. 
(Ord. 14-2006 (part): prior code § 2-19.1) 
2.72.020 - Composition-Terms-Vacancies-Compensation. 
A.  Composition. The commission on senior services shall consist of eleven (11) members appointed by the township committee. All members shall be residents of the township. 
B.  Terms. Appointments shall be for one-year terms. One of the eleven (11) members of the commission shall be a member of the township committee. 
C.  Vacancies. Appointments to vacancies shall be for the unexpired term. 
D.  Compensation. Members shall receive no compensation for their services as members. 
(Ord. 14-2006 (part): prior code § 2-19.2) 
(Ord. 3-2008) 
2.72.030 - Organization-Meetings-Bylaws. 
A.  Organization. The members of the commission on senior services shall reorganize annually and select a chairperson, vice-chairperson, and secretary. The chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary shall serve as such until the first day of January next following their respective appointments and until their successors shall be appointed. Vacancies in these offices shall be filled for the unexpired term only. 
B.  Meetings. The commission shall meet at least once a month and at such other times as the commission may direct. 
C.  Bylaws. The commission shall establish bylaws which shall govern the conduct of the commission at its meetings. Bylaws shall be adopted within three months of the organization of the first commission. 
(Ord. 14-2006 (part): prior code § 2-19.3) 
(Ord. 3-2008) 
2.72.040 - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
A.  To advise in the coordination and integration of programs and services affecting the welfare of older adults, fifty-five (55) and older, who are residents of the township; 
B.  To conduct research through public hearings and other means, operate demonstration programs and conduct evaluation studies in the problems of the aged; 
C.  To advise the township committee on the establishment of policies that will assist in the resolution of the problems of the aged; 
D.  To confer with appropriate municipal, county, state, referral and private agencies concerned with programs for the aged, for the purpose of improving the scope and efficiency of the services rendered to the aged; 
E.  To contact any individual or public or private agency for the purpose of securing such funds as may be deemed necessary or convenient for the carrying out of its purposes; 
F.  To make, amend and rescind rules, regulations and bylaws for its own government; 
G.  To serve as a coordinating body to insure that older adults are aware of programs and services made available to them by civic and religious organizations and by municipal, county, state and federal governments and private agencies; 
H.  To prepare and submit annually, by November 15th, for the consideration of the township committee, a proposed budget for its activities; 
I.  To report upon its activities and recommendation to the township committee annually and at such times as the respective governing bodies shall request or as the commission shall deem advisable. 
(Ord. 14-2006 (part): prior code § 2-19.4) 
2.72.050 - Cooperation from other agencies. 
    All township agencies shall cooperate with the commission in furnishing such reports and information as the commission shall deem necessary to carry out its functions and purposes. 
(Ord. 14-2006 (part): prior code § 2-19.5) 
2.72.060 - Fiscal regulations. 
    The township committee shall have the power to approve the annual budget submitted by the commission on senior services in whole or in part or to modify same, and the budget as finally approved by the township committee shall constitute the budget for the commission for the budget year and the amount shown therein as revenue from township sources shall constitute the limitation of the township committee's contribution to the commission for such year. 
(Ord. 14-2006 (part): prior code § 2-19.6) 
Chapter 2.76 - PERSONNEL SYSTEM 

2.76.010 - Adoption of personnel policies and job descriptions. 
    The township committee may from time to time adopt personnel policies and job descriptions for the employment of persons by the Township of East Greenwich. 
(Ord. 16-2003 § 1) 
Chapter 2.80 - MUNICIPAL HOUSING LIAISON 

2.80.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to create the administrative mechanisms needed for the execution of East Greenwich Township's responsibility to assist in the provision of affordable housing pursuant to the Fair Housing Act of 1985. 
(Ord. 7-2007 § 1) 
2.80.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Administrative agent" means the entity responsible for administering the affordability controls of some or all units in the affordable housing program for East Greenwich Township to ensure that the restricted units under administration are affirmatively marketed and sold or rented, as applicable, only to low- and moderate-income households. 
    "Municipal housing liaison" means the employee charged by the governing body with the responsibility for oversight and administration of the affordable housing program for East Greenwich Township. 
(Ord. 7-2007 § 2) 
2.80.030 - Establishment of municipal housing liaison position and compensation-Powers and duties. 
A.  Establishment of Position of Municipal Housing Liaison. There is established the position of municipal housing liaison for East Greenwich Township. 
B.  Subject to the approval of the council on affordable housing (COAH), the municipal housing liaison shall be appointed by the governing body and may be a full- or part-time municipal employee. 
C.  The municipal housing liaison shall be responsible for oversight and administration of the affordable housing program for East Greenwich Township, including the following responsibilities which may not be contracted out, exclusive of subsection (C)(6) which may be contracted out: 
1.  Serving as East Greenwich Township's primary point of contact for all inquiries from the state, affordable housing providers, administrative agents, and interested households; 
2.  Monitoring the status of all restricted units in East Greenwich Township's fair share plan; 
3.  Compiling, verifying, and submitting annual reports as required by COAH; 
4.  Coordinating meetings with affordable housing providers and administrative agents, as applicable; 
5.  Attending continuing education opportunities on affordability controls, compliance monitoring, and affirmative marketing as offered or approved by COAH; 
6.  If applicable, serving as the administrative agent for some or all of the restricted units in East Greenwich Township. 
D.  Subject to approval by COAH, East Greenwich Township may contract with or authorize a consultant, authority, government or any agency charged by the governing body, which entity shall have the responsibility of administering the affordable housing program of East Greenwich Township, except for those responsibilities which may not be contracted out pursuant to subsection C above. If East Greenwich Township contracts with another entity to administer all or any part of the affordable housing program, including the affordability controls and affirmative marketing plan, the municipal housing liaison shall supervise the contracting administrative agent. 
E.  Compensation. Compensation shall be fixed by the governing body at the time of the appointment of the municipal housing liaison. 
F.  Administrative Powers and Duties Assigned to the Municipal Housing Liaison. Only the five required responsibilities outlined in subsection C above will be handled by East Greenwich Township's municipal housing liaison. All other duties will be delegated to an approved administrative agent. 
(Ord. 7-2007 § 3) 
Chapter 2.86 - PROFESSIONAL SERVICE AGREEMENTS 

2.86.010 - State law. 
    The provisions of an Act concerning certain campaign contributions by certain business entities, supplementing P.L. 1973, c. 83 (c. 19:44A-1 et seq.), and amending P.L. 1973, c. 83, was enacted as a law by the State of New Jersey, and particularly New Jersey Statute NJSA 19:44A-20.5, et seq., which bind the Township of East Greenwich and pre-empt any provision of this chapter not consistent with the provisions of said state statute. 
(Ord. 21-2005, § A.) 
2.86.020 - Fair and open process. 
    Any contract required to be awarded under a fair and open process, pursuant to New Jersey Statute NJSA 19:44A-20.5, shall be subject to the following fair and open process: 
1.  Pursuant to the terms of New Jersey Statute NJSA 19:44A-20.7, said contract shall be publicly advertised in newspapers or on the internet website maintained by the township in sufficient time to give notice in advance of the award of the contract; and shall be awarded under a process that provides for public solicitation of proposals or qualifications and awarded and disclosed under criteria established in writing by the public entity prior to the solicitation of proposals or qualifications; and publicly opened and announced when awarded. The notice and posting shall set forth the name of the position or contract which is to become open, where the solicitation notice setting forth the criteria to be considered and materials required to be submitted by the applicant can be obtained, a date, time and place when the proposals or qualifications shall be publicly opened and a statement that the proposals or qualifications are being solicited through a fair and open process pursuant to NJSA 19:44A-20.5 et seq. The decision of the Township of the Committee (sic) of the Township of East Greenwich as to what constitutes a fair and open process shall be final, pursuant to New Jersey Statute NJSA 19:44A-20.7. 
(Ord. 21-2005, § B.) 
2.86.030 - Applications. 
    All applicants shall submit a resume or proposal which shall include the following information: 
1.  Full name, business affiliation and business address; 
2.  A listing of all post high school education; 
3.  Dates of licensure in the State of New Jersey or any other state; 
4.  A listing of any professional affiliations or memberships in any professional societies or organizations; 
5.  A listing of all special accreditations held by the individual licensed professional or business entity; A listing of all previous experience relating to or work involving, public entities. 
(Ord. 21-2005, § C.) 
2.86.040 - Criteria for award. 
    Proposals or qualifications of each applicant will be evaluated by the township considering the following: general experience, experience specific to the assignment, reputation in the field, knowledge of the subject matter to be addressed under the contract, accessibility, availability to accommodate any required meeting of the township, sufficiency of resources to perform the task and other factors demonstrated to be in the best interests and the most advantageous to the township considering all factors. 
(Ord. 21-2005, § D.) 
2.86.050 - Publication. 
    The award of any contract pursuant to public bidding or competitive contract process as set forth in the Local Public Contracts Law shall meet the requirements of a fair and open process. The award of the contract shall be publicized in the official newspaper of the township for publication of notices in accordance with NJSA 40A:11-5. 
(Ord. 21-2005, § E.) 
2.86.060 - Determination of fair and open. 
    Consistent with the provisions of NJSA 19:44A-20.7, the township's determination of what constitutes a fair and open process shall be final. Fair and open may necessarily be implemented differently for different categories of procurement depending on the subject matter of the procurement and the nature and nuances of the industry providing the services or product, but in every instance, the principals of fair and open shall be maintained. 
(Ord. 21-2005, § F.) 
Chapter 2.90 - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE 

2.90.010 - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established in the township of East Greenwich a parks and recreation committee, which shall have the duties and powers hereinafter more particularly set forth, and the members of which shall be appointed by the township committee in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.020 - Membership; terms; liaison; filling of vacancies. 
A.  The parks and recreation committee shall be composed of seven members and two alternate members, who shall be citizens and residents of the township of East Greenwich. Such members and alternate members shall be appointed by the township committee to serve three-year terms; provided, however, that the initial appointments shall be made in the following manner: two members for initial one-year terms; two members for initial two-year terms; three members for initial three-year terms; one alternate for an initial one-year term; and one alternate for an initial two-year term. After the conclusion of the initial terms as herein provided, all terms shall be for three years. The township committee shall designate the alternate members as "alternate no. 1", and alternate no. 2". At meetings of the parks and recreation committee, alternate members shall be permitted to participate in discussion of the proceedings, but shall not be permitted to vote except in the absence or disqualification of one or more regular members, in which event, alternate members shall be permitted to vote in lieu of such absent or disqualified regular members in the order of numerical designation of such members. 
B.  In addition to the aforementioned members, the township committee shall appoint a member of the township committee to serve as a liaison to the recreation committee each year, who shall be permitted to participate in discussions of the proceedings of the committee, but who shall not be permitted to vote. Such members of the township committee shall serve a one-year term. 
C.  All appointments shall expire on December 31. Initial appointments as above provided, shall be made for the balance of the one-, two- or three-year term designated, ending on December 31 of the applicable year. 
D.  Vacancies shall be filled by the township committee for the unexpired term only. The members shall serve until their respective successors are appointed, found qualified, and take office. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.030 - Relation to the township committee. 
A.  The township committee shall cooperate with the recreation committee to coordinate and provide equipment for recreational activities, as well as to coordinate the development, operation and maintenance of parks, public places, playgrounds, and recreational areas, in the township of East Greenwich, in order to provide for the maximum benefit and planned development for the residents of the township of East Greenwich. 
B.  The township committee may, from time to time, by resolution, place activities, parks, public places, playgrounds and recreational areas under the jurisdiction of the parks and recreation committee for development, operation or maintenance thereof, or for such purposes as may be specified in any such resolution. The township shall continue to be responsible for the care, custody and policing of any such parks, public places, playgrounds and recreational areas, which, from time to time, may be placed under the jurisdiction of the parks and recreation committee, unless such responsibilities or any others shall be specifically assigned in any such resolution. 
C.  The parks and recreation committee herein established shall not be deemed to be a park or recreation commission pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:12-1 et seq., but such parks and recreation committee shall have only those powers and duties as may be set forth herein or as may be more particularly provided by resolution of the township committee. 
D.  There shall be no appropriation of public funds to the parks and recreation committee, except as may be provided by the township committee for designated purposes consistent with the intent of this chapter. The parks and recreation committee shall recommend to the township committee proposals, from time to time, as may be consistent herewith. 
E.  The township committee shall obtain liability insurance coverage covering the approved activities under the jurisdiction of the parks and recreation committee, the participants in those activities, the township of East Greenwich and individual members of the parks and recreation committee. 
F.  Neither the parks and recreation committee nor any member or members thereof shall have any power or right, express or implied, to bind or obligate the township of East Greenwich or the township committee, directly or indirectly. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.040 - Duties. 
    The primary purpose of the parks and recreation committee shall be to: 
A.  Assist in providing equipment as needed to programs concerned with the recreation of the residents of the township of East Greenwich. 
B.  Provide recommendations for the orderly development of parks or other public lands in the township of East Greenwich. 
C.  Cooperate with the Gloucester County Department of Parks and Recreation in coordinating and advising on activities to be held on county-owned recreational land should such aid be requested by the Gloucester County Department of Parks and Recreation. 
D.  Suggest improvements needed for orderly development and to undertake such improvements as it is authorized to carry out pursuant to this chapter or hereafter by resolution of the township committee. 
E.  Operate and maintain such parks or other public lands over which it is given jurisdiction in any resolution of the township committee and shall do so pursuant to any standards set forth in any such resolution. 
F.  Handle other specific programs which may be assigned or authorized by the township committee, by resolution from time to time, in accordance with the general purposes of the parks and recreation committee and the provisions of this chapter and subject to the limitations contained herein. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.050 - Limitations. 
    The parks and recreation committee shall not act in any manner which would cause a forfeiture of any lands of the township of East Greenwich. The township committee reserves the right to limit the jurisdiction, purposes or programs of the parks and recreation committee at any time by resolution of the township committee. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.060 - Organization. 
    The parks and recreation committee may organize as it sees fit, choosing a chairperson and such other officers from among its members as it may deem advisable, adopt rules and bylaws for the proper administration of its functions and formulate committees for the administration and handling of its programs. 
    Members shall attend one-half of all public meetings in each calendar year and shall not be absent from three consecutive regularly scheduled meetings. The committee shall petition the township committee for removal and replacement of any member with attendance below this standard. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.070 - Park director. 
    The park director appointed by the township committee shall serve as a voting member of the parks and recreation committee. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
2.90.080 - Grievance procedure; appeals. 
A.  Any recognized recreational group who feels or believes it is aggrieved by any of the actions of the park director shall have the right to appeal any of the park director's actions and/or recommendations in the first instance to the parks and recreation committee. Said appeal shall be filed not later than ten (10) days from the date of any action or recommendation taken by the park director and shall be in writing to the parks and recreation committee chairperson. 
B.  The parks and recreation committee chairperson shall thereafter set the matter down for a hearing and consider the testimony of witnesses and other evidence to be presented and at the conclusion of which the parks and recreation committee shall render a decision as soon as is practicable. 
C.  Any party may appeal the action of the parks and recreation committee to the township administrator within five days of the parks and recreation committee's decision, in writing to the township administrator. 
D.  Any party may appeal in the final instance the decision of the township administrator to the township committee, within five days of the township administrator's decision in writing to the township clerk. 
(Ord. No. 21-2009, 9-8-2009) 
Chapter 2.94 - AGRICULTURAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

2.94.010 - Findings and determinations. 
A.  The use of land for agricultural purposes is conducive to the preservation of open space for appropriate residential, commercial and recreational use, as well as agricultural use, and assures a supply of potable water, clean air and a pleasant and healthful environment as well as the aesthetic preservation of the countryside and production of food and agricultural products for this and future generations within East Greenwich township. 
B.  Agricultural enterprise has long been the primary economic base of the township. 
C.  It is self-evident that the comfort, safety, health and general welfare of the residents of the township and general public will be best served by the protection of land now and hereafter used for agricultural purposes from incompatible encroaching land development and interference by persons not engaged in the occupation of farming. 
D.  It is determined that any discomfort or inconvenience to persons not engaged in the occupation of farming resulting from dust, noise, odors, smoke and/or fumes created by farming activities is superseded by the benefits resulting from retaining farm lands and the production of agricultural products in the township. 
E.  It is further determined that it is wise and proper to encourage and protect the use of land for agricultural purposes by ordaining the right to farm all land everywhere in the township by creation of a right to farm zone encompassing the entire township. 
(Ord. No. 32-2009, § 1, 11-10-2009) 
2.94.020 - Purposes. 
    The agricultural advisory committee shall have as its purposes: 
A.  To attract new agriculture-related business, commerce and industry to locate or relocate in the township. 
B.  To encourage, growth, expansion and retention of existing agricultural businesses and farms in the township. 
C.  Serve as a conduit for the farming community and local government relating to agriculture and farming practices, development projects and issues. 
(Ord. No. 32-2009, § 2, 11-10-2009) 
2.94.030 - Powers and duties. 
    The agricultural advisory committee shall have the following powers and shall perform the following duties. 
A.  Prepare an Agricultural Development Plan. The committee shall prepare an agricultural development plan for the township of East Greenwich area which shall consist, at a minimum, of the following: 
1.  An evaluation of existing agricultural businesses and farms and their retention and expansion needs. 
2.  An assessment of the types of agricultural businesses and farms suitable to the area. 
3.  Contacts to be pursued in order to encourage relocation of new agricultural businesses and farms and/or retention and expansion of current agricultural businesses and farms. 
B.  Participate in State, County, and Local Agricultural Development Planning. Members of the committee shall attend and participate in meetings and activities involving agricultural planning and development at the state, and county level, as well as, at the local level, with agricultural business and farm groups. The committee shall be charged with the responsibility of bringing to the attention of the township committee the agricultural development plans and concerns of such groups and, upon motion and at the direction of township committee, shall coordinate joint resolution efforts with such groups. The committee may recommend to township committee that funds designated for the agricultural development of the township of East Greenwich be expended in support of such agricultural development efforts. 
C.  Advertise for or otherwise solicit agricultural businesses and farms in order to attract interest in relocation to or expansion to the Township. 
D.  Assist agricultural businesses in determining required infrastructure and/or other needs. 
E.  Report to the township committee at least once per quarter on agricultural development activities and issues. 
F.  Submit an Annual Report to the Township Committee in November of Each Year. By November 30 of each year, the committee shall submit a detailed written report to township committee, evaluating agricultural development and concerns in the township during the prior eleven (11) months. The report may include recommendations to township committee for agricultural development efforts in the upcoming year. 
G.  Limited Authority. 
1.  It is not intended that nor shall the committee be a sub-agency of the township committee. The committee shall possess no aspect of policy or rule making authority for the township. Advice or information from the committee shall not be binding upon the township committee, nor shall any action of the township committee be dependent first upon any recommendation or review by the committee. 
2.  The committee may not incur any debt nor contract for any goods in the name of the township of East Greenwich or the township committee. 
(Ord. No. 32-2009, § 3, 11-10-2009) 
2.94.040 - Committee members. 
A.  Membership. The agricultural advisory committee shall consist of five members and two alternate members, appointed by a majority of township committee. The members shall be residents of the township of East Greenwich and/or East Greenwich township land owners who engage in the farming and agriculture business. All members shall be residents of the township, and shall serve without compensation. 
B.  Term of Office. Members of the committee shall serve three-year terms, except that, upon the creation of this committee, in order to create staggered terms, one member shall serve for a one-year term from 2009 through 2010, two members shall serve a two-year term each from 2009 through 2011, and two members shall serve a full three-year term each from 2009 through 2012. Alternate members shall serve two-year terms, except that, upon the creation of this committee, in order to create staggered terms, one alternate member shall serve for a one-year term from 2009 through 2010, and the other alternate member shall serve a two-year term from 2009 through 2011. 
C.  Resignation. Any member desiring to resign from the committee shall submit a resignation in writing to the township clerk, who shall present it to the township committee for action. 
D.  Removal from Office. Upon three consecutive, unexcused absences of a member or upon an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the committee following consideration and discussion of the issue taken in executive session, the township committee may, upon recommendation of the committee, remove such member and appoint a replacement member. 
(Ord. No. 32-2009, § 4, 11-10-2009) 
2.94.050 - Officers. 
    The officers of the committee shall be as follows: chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary. The officers shall be elected by ballot of committee members to serve for one year or until their successors are elected and qualified, and their term of office shall begin at the close of the regular January meeting, except the initial officers upon the creation of this committee. 
(Ord. No. 32-2009, § 5, 11-10-2009) 
2.94.060 - Meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the committee shall be held monthly. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson or upon the written request of two or more members of the committee. Each committee member shall be notified of a meeting at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the meeting and written notice of each meeting shall be posted at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance. 
(Ord. No. 32-2009, § 6, 11-10-2009) 
Chapter 2.98 - JOINT MUNICIPAL COURT 

2.98.010 - Prior matters. 
    All summonses and other appropriate matters issuing or arising from the city of Woodbury and the township of East Greenwich shall be processed in the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court on and after February 9, 2015, including those matters arising prior to February 9, 2015 which remain pending. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 2, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.020 - Repeal and abolishment. 
    Notice of repeal and abolishment of the municipal courts of the city of Woodbury and the township of East Greenwich, and establishment of the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court shall be provided, in writing, to the administrative offices of the courts and the assignment judge of Vicinage 15, and posted in the municipal buildings of the participating municipalities in a location where public notices are normally posted. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 3, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.030 - Shared services agreement. 
    The responsibility for the operation of the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court shall be set forth in a shared services agreement, the "Agreement for the Operation of a Joint Municipal Court" approved by resolutions of Woodbury and East Greenwich. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 4, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.040 - Established. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 2B:12-1 et seq., the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 5, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.050 - Official seal. 
    The East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court shall have an official seal which shall bear the impression of the name of the court. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 6, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.060 - Territorial jurisdiction. 
    The territorial jurisdiction of the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court shall be coextensive with the territory of the city of Woodbury and the township of East Greenwich, Gloucester County, New Jersey. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 7, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.070 - Municipal judge, appointment and jurisdiction. 
    In accordance with N.J.S.A. 2B:12-4, as amended, the judge of the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate and shall have the qualifications required by law and shall serve for a term of three years from the date of his/her appointment and until his/her successor has been appointed and has qualified. The compensation of the judge shall be an annual salary as is now or hereinafter may be provided by ordinance and in accordance with the terms of the agreement for the operation of a joint municipal court between the city of Woodbury and the township of East Greenwich. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 8, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.080 - Joint municipal court administrator. 
    There shall be a joint municipal court administrator and at least one deputy court administrator who shall be appointed as provided by this chapter and in accordance with the terms of the agreement for the operation of a joint municipal court between the city of Woodbury and township of East Greenwich. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 9, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.090 - Support staff. 
    The East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court support staff shall be appointed in accordance with the terms of the agreement for the operation of a joint municipal court between the city of Woodbury and township of East Greenwich. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 10, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.100 - Joint municipal court prosecutor. 
    The joint municipal court prosecutor shall be appointed in accordance with the terms of the agreement for the operation of a joint municipal court between the city of Woodbury and township of East Greenwich. The joint municipal court prosecutor shall have the jurisdiction, powers and duties prescribed by N.J.S.A. 2B:25-1, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 11, 11-12-2014) 
2.98.110 - Joint municipal court public defender. 
A.  Appointment. The joint municipal court public defender shall be appointed in accordance with the terms of the agreement for the operation of a joint municipal court between the city of Woodbury and township of East Greenwich. The joint municipal court public defender shall have the jurisdiction, powers and duties prescribed by N.J.S.A. 2B:24.1, et seq. 
B.  Representation. Any person applying to the East Greenwich Joint Municipal Court for representation by a municipal public defender shall, in accordance with the provisions of N.J.S.A. 2B:24-17, pay an application fee, but only in an amount determined by the joint municipal court judge, necessary to pay the costs of municipal public defender services. The joint municipal court judge may waive said application fee in whole or in part if the court determines, in its discretion, that the application fee represents an unreasonable burden on the person seeking representation. Said determination shall be made in accordance with the applicable provisions under law. 
C.  Alternate Method of Collection. If the payment of the fee is deferred by the joint municipal court judge or the fee is otherwise unpaid, then the participating municipalities may endeavor to collect the fee in the manner provided in N.J.S.A. 40:6A-1 and N.J.S.A. 2A:158A-19. Collection of such fees by a third-party shall be authorized by both Woodbury and East Greenwich. 
(Ord. No. 15-2014, § 12, 11-12-2014) 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.04 - CLAIMS AGAINST THE CITY 
Sections: 

3.04.010 - Payment of claims. 
    Any person claiming payment from the township shall first submit a detailed statement of the items or demand necessitating such claim to the township clerk, specifying particularly how the bill or demand is made up, and a certification of the party claiming payment that it is correct. No bill, claim or demand shall be considered for payment unless the voucher includes or has attached to it a certification of a department head or other municipal official responsible for certain functions or of his or her duly designated representative, having personal knowledge of the facts that the goods have been received by, or the services rendered to the township, and that those services rendered are consistent with any existing contract or purchase order. The chief financial officer of the township shall have the duty to audit, warrant and make recommendations on all claims and bills. The bill or claim duly certified shall be presented to the township clerk for inclusion in the agenda of the next immediate meeting of the township committee to consider the payment of bills, and it shall be the duty of the clerk to examine all bills or claims submitted for payment in order to ascertain if proper administrative procedures have been followed. This review responsibility may be assigned to the chief financial officer of the township. All claims or bills to be considered by the township committee shall be made available to every member of the committee at least on or before the Monday preceding the regular meeting night of the township committee for formal action at the regular meeting. Claims shall be considered by the committee which shall approve them, except that the committee may reject any claim presented to it stating the reason for such rejection. Any disapproved claim shall be referred back to the clerk with such instructions as the township committee may give at the time of disapproval. It shall be the duty of the municipal clerk to record all claims in the official minutes or through an appropriate claims register, indicating that the committee has by formal action approved them with appropriate record as to any claims disapproved or rejected. All records pertaining to approved and disapproved bills or claims shall be available for public inspection. After the clerk has certified that the claims have been approved, he shall turn them over to the treasurer, or other chief financial officer, who shall forthwith prepare the necessary checks for the payment thereof. Checks shall be signed by the mayor, by the township treasurer, and by the township clerk. After preparing checks for the payment of claims, the treasurer shall record them in proper books of account and thereafter mail the checks to the claimants. 
(Prior code § 2-6) 
Chapter 3.08 - HOTEL AND MOTEL ROOM OCCUPANCY TAX 

3.08.010 - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this chapter to implement the provisions of P.L. 2003, c. 114, which authorizes the governing body of a municipality to adopt an ordinance imposing a tax at a uniform percentage rate not to exceed three percent on charges of rent for every occupancy of a room or rooms in a hotel subject to taxation pursuant to subsection (d) of section 3 of P.L. 1966, c. 40 (NJSA 54:32B-3) which shall be in addition to any other tax or fee imposed pursuant to statute or local ordinance or resolution by any governmental entity upon the occupancy of a hotel room. 
()Ord. 2-2008, § 1.1) 
3.08.020 - Established. 
    There is hereby established a hotel and motel room occupancy tax in the township which shall be fixed at a uniform percentage rate of three percent on charges of rent for every occupancy of a hotel or motel room in the township subject to taxation pursuant to subsection (d) of section 3 of P.L. 1966, c. 40, NJSA 54:32B-3 (sales tax). 
(Ord. 2-2008, § 1.2) 
3.08.030 - Tax an addition. 
    The hotel and motel room occupancy tax shall be in addition to any other tax or fee imposed pursuant to statute or local ordinance or resolution by any governmental entity upon the occupancy of a hotel room. 
(Ord. 2-2008, § 1.3) 
3.08.040 - Exemptions. 
    The hotel and motel room occupancy tax authorized herein shall not be imposed on the rent for an occupancy if the purchaser, user or consumer is an entity exempt from the tax imposed on an occupancy under the "Sales and use Tax Act" pursuant to subsection (a) of section 9 of P.L. 1966, c. 30 (C. 54:32B-9). 
(Ord. 2-2008, § 1.4) 
3.08.050 - Payment. 
    In accordance with the requirements of P.L. 2003, c. 114: 
A.  All taxes imposed by this chapter shall be paid by the purchaser. 
B.  A vendor shall not assume or absorb any tax imposed by this ordinance. 
C.  A vendor shall not in any manner advertise or hold out to any person or to the public in general, in any manner, directly or indirectly, that the tax will be assumed or absorbed by the vendor, that the tax will not be separately charged and stated to the customer, or that the tax will be refunded to the customer. 
D.  Each assumption or absorption by a vendor of the tax shall be deeded [deemed] a separate offense and each representation or advertisement by a vendor for each day that the representation or advertisement continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
E.  The penalty for violation of the foregoing provisions shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. 2-2008, § 1.5) 
3.08.060 - Collection. 
    The tax imposed by this chapter shall be collected on behalf of the township by the person collecting the rent from the hotel or motel customer. Each person required to collect the tax herein imposed shall be personally liable for the tax imposed, collected or required to be collected hereunder. Any such person shall have the same right in respect to collecting the tax from a customer as if the tax were a part of the rent and payable at the same time; provided that the chief financial officer of the township shall be joined as a party in any action or proceeding brought to collect the tax. 
(Ord. 2-2008, § 1.6) 
Chapter 3.12 - TAX ABATEMENTS, EXEMPTIONS AND PAYMENTS IN LIEU OF TAX AGREEMENTS 
Sections: 

3.12.010 - Conditions. 
    The township has the authority to enter into agreements ("financial agreements") with redevelopers, developers and/or other appropriate entities, for the granting of up to five years of tax treatment, pursuant to NJSA 40A:21-1 et seq., and for a longer term, pursuant to NJSA 40A:20-1 et seq., concerning certain projects within the township, subject to the following conditions: 
(Ord. 28-2008) 
3.12.020 - Application. 
A.  Applicants for five years or less tax treatment pursuant to NJSA 40A:21-1 et seq. or for long-term tax treatment pursuant to NJSA 40A:20-1, et seq. shall provide the township committee with an application setting forth the following: 
1.  A general description of the project for which an abatement, exemption, or payment in lieu of tax agreement is sought. 
2.  A legal description of all real estate comprising: 
(a)  The project site; and 
(b)  The proposed tax treatment area at such project site. 
3.  Plans, drawings and other documents as may be required by the governing body to demonstrate the structure and design of the project. 
4.  A description of the number, classes and types of employees to be employed at the project site within two years of completion of the project. 
5.  A statement of the reasons for seeking tax abatement and/or exemption or other tax treatment as part of applicant's project and a description of the benefits likely to be realized by applicant if a financial agreement is granted. 
6.  Estimate of the cost of completing such project. 
7.  Estimate of the time to complete such project. 
8.  A statement showing: 
(a)  The real property taxes as currently assessed for the project site; and 
(b)  Estimated, proposed tax payments that would be made by applicant for the tax treatment portion of the project site during the period of the financial agreement, pursuant to law. 
9.  Names of current owners of property within: 
(a)  The entire proposed project site; and 
(b)  The proposed tax treatment area. 
10.  A description of any agreements of sale and lease agreements between applicant and any other entity, including the proposed users of the project site, and a history and description of such users' business. 
11.  Such other pertinent information as the governing body may require. 
B.  Applicants shall be encouraged to apply for tax treatment prior to commencement of construction (allowing, however, for minimal preparatory site work to be undertaken prior to commencement of construction if applicant is under a redevelopment or development agreement with the township). 
C.  Upon receipt of a completed, lawful, and timely application as set forth above, the township governing body shall review the application to determine whether to grant tax treatment. Once the township's governing body approves an application, the township's redevelopment counsel shall assist the township in negotiating a financial agreement, and the township shall adopt an authorizing ordinance for the project. Any agreement so authorized shall provide for applicant to pay the municipality according to the financial agreement and controlling statute. 
D.  Every application shall initially be made on a form prescribed by the township, to be finalized, at the discretion of the township, on any updated form the township is required to use or desires to use, and shall be filed with the tax assessor, with a copy to the mayor. Every application which is complete pursuant to law and timely filed with the township, shall be reviewed by the assessor and the mayor, to be considered by the governing body for tax treatment. 
E.  Financial agreements hereunder shall be applied for, and granted on an individual project basis, at the township's discretion. 
F.  No abatement, exemption, payment in lieu of taxes, or other tax treatment shall be granted except upon written application filed with and approved by the tax assessor, the mayor, and the township committee. 
G.  No abatement, exemption, payment in lieu of taxes, or other tax treatment shall be granted and no financial agreement shall be entered into for any property for which property taxes are delinquent or unpaid, nor for which penalties for nonpayment of taxes are due. 
(Ord. 28-2008) 
3.12.030 - Record. 
    The granting of a property tax abatement, an exemption, a payment in lieu of taxes agreement or other project-specific tax treatment shall be made a permanent, official township tax record, which record shall contain a notice of the termination date thereof. 
(Ord. 28-2008) 
3.12.040 - Applicability. 
    Payments in lieu of taxes, tax abatement payments and tax exemption payments shall be made in accordance with NJSA 40A:20-1 et seq. or NJSA 40A:21-1 et seq., as applicable, and shall be applied to the township, schools and Gloucester County, as set forth in such statutes, otherwise pursuant to law, and under the applicable financial agreement. 
(Ord. 28-2008) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - LICENSING GENERALLY 

5.04.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide a uniform set of procedures for administering the issuance, renewal and revocation of all licenses issued by the township, except alcoholic beverage licenses and dog licenses and except as may be specified otherwise or provided elsewhere in this title. 
(Prior code § 4-1.1) 
5.04.020 - Applications. 
    All applications for licenses shall be accompanied by the required fee and shall be made to or through the township clerk upon forms provided by him or her. Applications shall contain the information specified by resolution of the township committee and may include the following along with any other information deemed necessary or specifically called:
