A.  Name and permanent and local address of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of its registered agent; 
B.  If the licensed activity is to be carried on at a fixed location, the address and description of the premises; 
C.  If a vehicle is to be used, its description including the license number; 
D.  If the applicant is employed by another, the name and address of the employer together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
E.  The days of the week and the hours of the day during which the licensed activity will be conducted; 
F.  A description of the nature of the business and the goods, property or services to be sold or supplied; 
G.  A statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of any crime or the violation of any municipal ordinance other than traffic offenses and, if so, the date and place of conviction, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty imposed; 
H.  Appropriate evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant so that an investigator may properly evaluate his or her character and responsibility; 
I.  Applications by partnerships shall be signed by all partners with the information required by this section supplied in detail as to each partner, and applications of corporations shall have attached individual statements containing all of the information required by this section relating to each employee or agent who shall engage in the licensed activity, and shall be signed by each employee or agent. 
(Prior code § 4-1.2) 
5.04.030 - Investigation of applicants. 
    No license shall be granted unless the application has been approved by the township police department. Each application shall first be referred to the chief of police, or a police officer designated by him or her, who shall immediately institute whatever investigation of the applicant's business responsibility, moral character and ability to properly conduct the licensed activity he or she considers necessary for the protection of the public. The applicant shall be photographed and fingerprinted at the time of the initial application for a license. Upon conclusion of the investigation, the chief of police, or a police officer designated by him or her, shall communicate his or her findings in writing to the township clerk within a reasonable time after the application has been filed. If the investigator decides that the applicant's character, ability or business responsibility is unsatisfactory, or the products, services or activities are not free from fraud, he or she shall disapprove the application and the clerk shall not be authorized to issue the license and shall notify the applicant. Otherwise, the township clerk shall issue the license upon receipt of the written report, provided the required license fees have been paid, except in cases where approval of the township committee is required. In the case of an application for a solicitor's, peddler's or canvasser's license, each and every solicitor, peddler or canvasser shall submit an individual application subject to the terms and conditions set forth within this section above. In the event of the refusal of the issuance of a license, the applicant may appeal to the township committee for a hearing. The appeal shall be filed, in writing, with the township clerk within fourteen (14) days after written notification of the refusal. The township committee shall hold its hearing within ten (10) days thereafter, and its decision shall be final. 
(Prior code § 4-1.3) 
5.04.040 - Contents of license. 
    License shall be in a form which the township committee shall prescribe by resolution and shall contain the following information: 
A.  The name and address of the licensee; 
B.  The number and type of the license and the nature of the licensed activity; 
C.  The address at which the licensed activity is conducted, if the activity is carried on at a fixed location; 
D.  If the licensed activity is conducted from a vehicle, the make, model and license number of the vehicle; 
E.  The expiration date of the license; 
F.  Any other appropriate information which the chief of police may request and the township committee may require by resolution. 
(Prior code § 4-1.4) 
5.04.050 - License record. 
    The township clerk shall keep a record of all licenses issued under this title. The record shall be in a form prescribed by resolution of the township committee and shall contain the same information as is required by Section 5.04.040. It shall also indicate the amount of the fee paid for the license, the date upon which payment was received, the date of the issuance of the license, whether the license is new or a renewal and any other information which the township committee may require by resolution. 
(Prior code § 4-1.5) 
5.04.060 - Display of license. 
    When the licensed activity is conducted at a fixed location or from a vehicle, the license shall be prominently displayed at the location or on the vehicle. In all other cases the licensee shall have the license in his possession at all times and shall display it upon the request of any police officer or any person with whom he is doing business. 
(Prior code § 4-1.6) 
5.04.070 - Transferability. 
    Except as otherwise provided, a license shall apply only to the person to whom it was issued and shall not be transferable to another person. In cases where the licensed activity is conducted at a fixed location, licenses may be transferred from place to place, but only with the approval of the township committee by resolution. The fee for the transfer of a license from place to place shall be five dollars. 
(Prior code § 4-1.7) 
5.04.080 - Expiration date-Renewal-Proration of fees. 
A.  Except where expressly provided otherwise, all licenses shall expire on December 31st of the year of issue at midnight. Applications for the renewal of licenses shall be made not later than December 1st of the year of issue. 
B.  When an application for a license is made during the course of any calendar year, the fee shall be prorated to the nearest month. Any period of time greater than one-half a month shall be considered as a full month for this purpose. 
(Prior code § 4-1.8) 
5.04.090 - Revocation of license-Causes. 
    Any license or permit issued by the township may be revoked by the township committee after notice and a hearing for any of the following causes: 
A.  Fraud or misrepresentation in any application for a permit or license; 
B.  Fraud, misrepresentation or other dishonesty in the conduct of licensed activity; 
C.  A violation of any provision of this code; 
D.  Conviction of the licensee for any felony or high misdemeanor or a misdemeanor or disorderly person's offense involving moral turpitude; 
E.  Conduct of the licensed activity whether by the licensee himself or herself or his or her agents or employees in an unlawful manner or in a manner that constitutes a breach of the peace or a menace to the public health, safety or general welfare. 
F.  Whenever a license has been issued immediately upon an application pending the results of the investigation provided for by this title, such license may be summarily revoked if the result of the investigation is such as would have resulted in denial of the application. 
(Prior code § 4-1.9) 
5.04.100 - Notice of hearing. 
    Notice of a hearing for the revocation of a license or permit shall be given in writing by the township clerk. The notice shall specifically set forth the grounds upon which the proposed revocation is based and the time and place of the hearing. It shall be served by mailing a copy to the licensee at his or her last known address by certified mail, return receipt requested, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Prior code § 4-1.10) 
5.04.110 - Hearing-Determination. 
    At the hearing the licensee shall have the right to appear and be heard, to be represented by an attorney, to present a witness in his or her own behalf, to cross-examine opposing witnesses and to have a permanent record made of the proceedings at his or her own expense. The township committee shall revoke or suspend the license if it is satisfied by a preponderance of the evidence that the licensee is guilty of the acts charged 
(Prior code § 4-1.11) 
5.04.120 - Reinstatement of revoked licenses. 
    The township committee may issue another license to a person whose license has been revoked or denied as provided in this chapter if after a hearing it is satisfied by clear and convincing evidence that the acts which led to the revocation or denial will not occur again; otherwise, no person whose license has been revoked or denied, nor any person acting for him or her, directly or indirectly, shall be issued another license to carry on the same activity. 
(Prior code § 4-1.12) 
5.04.130 - Power to make rules and regulations. 
    The township committee may by resolution make rules and regulations which interpret or amplify any provision of this title or for the purpose of administering the provisions of this title or making them more effective. No regulation shall be inconsistent with or alter or amend any provision of this title and no regulation shall impose any requirement which is in addition to or greater than the requirements that are expressly or by implication imposed by any provision of this title. 
(Prior code § 4-1.13) 
5.04.140 - Violations-Penalties. 
    For a violation of any section of this title there shall be a fine of up to fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first offense; for a second offense a fine up to one-hundred dollars ($100.00); and for a third or greater offense a fine up to one-thousand dollars ($1,000.00), up to thirty (30) days in jail and up to thirty (30) days of community service. To be subject to the enhanced penalties set forth herein the subsequent offense(s) need not be of the same specific section as long as the prior conviction was for a violation of this title. 
(Prior code § 4-1.14) 
Chapter 5.08 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE LICENSES 

5.08.010 - Purpose. 
    This chapter is enacted to regulate the sale and transportation of alcoholic beverages in the township in accordance with the provisions of an act of the legislature of the state of New Jersey entitled An Act Concerning Alcoholic Beverages, comprising Chapter 436 of the Laws of 1933, its supplements and amendments, and also comprising R.S. 33:1-1 et seq. and in accordance with the rules and regulations of the State Director of Alcoholic Beverage Control. 
(Prior code § 5-1) 
5.08.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, words and phrases shall have the same meanings they have in R.S. 33:1-1 et seq. and the rules and regulations of the Director of the Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control. 
(Prior code § 5-2) 
5.08.030 - Licenses. 
A.  Laws Applicable. All applications for licenses, all licenses issued, and all proceedings under this chapter shall be in accordance with the act, rules and regulations referred to in the previous section and all other applicable laws of the state of New Jersey or of the United States. 
B.  Issuing Authority. All licenses required by this chapter shall be issued by the township committee, which shall also administer the provisions of this chapter. 
C.  License Required. No person shall sell or distribute alcoholic beverages within the township without having obtained a license in accordance with the act referred to in Section 5.08.010 and the provisions of this chapter. 
D.  Plenary Retail Consumption License. The holder of this license shall be entitled, subject to all rules and regulations governing the same, to sell for consumption in licensed premises any alcoholic beverages by the glass or other receptacle and also to sell all alcoholic beverages in original containers for consumption off the licensed premises. The fees shall be as follows: 
1.  For the license year of 2009 the fee shall be eight hundred sixty-four dollars ($864.00). 
2.  For the license year of 2010 the fee shall be one thousand thirty-six dollars ($1,036.00). 
3.  For the license year of 2011 the fee shall be one thousand two hundred forty-three dollars ($1,243.00). 
4.  For the license year of 2012 the fee shall be one thousand four hundred ninety-one dollars ($1,491.00). 
5.  For the license year of 2013 the fee shall be one thousand seven hundred eighty-nine dollars ($1,789.00). 
6.  For the license year of 2014 the fee shall be two thousand one hundred forty-six dollars ($2,146.00). 
7.  For the license year of 2015 and thereafter the annual fee shall be two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
E.  Plenary Retail Distribution License. The holder of this license shall be entitled, subject to all rules and regulations governing the same, to sell for consumption any alcoholic beverages for consumption off the licensed premises, but only in original containers. The fees shall be as follows: 
1.  For the license year of 2009 the fee shall be eight hundred sixty-four dollars ($864.00). 
2.  For the license year of 2010 the fee shall be one thousand thirty-six dollars ($1,036.00). 
3.  For the license year of 2011 the fee shall be one thousand two hundred forty-three dollars ($1,243.00). 
4.  For the license year of 2012 the fee shall be one thousand four hundred ninety-one dollars ($1,491.00). 
5.  For the license year of 2013 the fee shall be one thousand seven hundred eighty-nine dollars ($1,789.00). 
6.  For the license year of 2014 the fee shall be two thousand one hundred forty-six dollars ($2,146.00). 
7.  For the license year of 2015 and thereafter the annual fee shall be two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Prior code § 5-3) 
(Ord. 3-2009) 
5.08.040 - Regulation of licenses. 
A.  Plenary retail consumption licensee (32) with broad package privilege shall be permitted to sell, serve, deliver or allow, permit or suffer the sale, service or delivery of any alcoholic beverage, or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverage on the licensed premises between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday of each week and between the hours of 12:00 p.m. to 12:00 a.m. on Sunday. 
B.  Plenary retail consumption licensee (33) shall be permitted to sell, serve, deliver or allow, permit or suffer the sale, service or delivery of any alcoholic beverage, or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverage on the licensed premises between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. on Monday through Saturday of each week and between the hours of 12:00 p.m. to 12:00 a.m. on Sunday. 
C.  Plenary retail distribution licensee (44) shall be permitted to sell, serve, deliver or allow, permit or suffer the sale, service or delivery of any alcoholic beverage, or allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverage on the licensed premises between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. on Monday through Saturday of each week and between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
(Prior code § 5-4) 
(Ord. No. 23-2011, 12-27-2011) 
5.08.050 - Revocation of licenses. 
    Any license issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, any provisions of any applicable statute, or any of the rules and regulations of the State Director of Alcoholic Beverage Control. Proceedings for suspension or revocation shall be in accordance with the provisions of R.S. 33:1-31 by service of a five-day notice of charges preferred against the licensee and affording a reasonable opportunity for hearing. Suspension or revocation of a license shall be in addition to any other penalty which may be imposed for a violation of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 5-5) 
Chapter 5.12 - CANVASSERS AND SOLICITORS 

5.12.010 - Canvasser or solicitor defined. 
    The term "canvasser or solicitor" means any individual, whether resident of the township or not, who travels by foot or by means of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or by street to street for the purpose of selling or taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of food, foodstuffs, goods, wares and merchandise for present or future delivery, or for services to be performed now and in the future, whether or not a sample is carried or displayed, and whether or not advance payments are collected. The terms shall not be deemed to include bake, laundryman and milkman; nor shall it apply to a person canvassing or soliciting a business establishment for the purpose of selling goods, wares and merchandise to be resold at retail in the business establishment. 
(Prior code § 4-3.1) 
5.12.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any canvasser or solicitor as defined in this chapter to engage in canvassing and soliciting within the township without first obtaining a permit and license. 
(Prior code § 4-3.2) 
5.12.030 - Application. 
    In addition to the information required by Section 5.12.020, the application for a solicitor's license shall indicate the place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time of application and the proposed method of delivery. The applicant shall furnish two references as to his or her good character and business responsibility, and shall also provide personal identification data, including height, weight, identifying marks and two photographs taken within sixty (60) days. There shall also be imprinted upon the application form a fingerprint of the thumb and index finger of the applicant. 
(Prior code § 4-3.3) 
5.12.040 - Fees. 
    There shall be a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) payable in connection with the license application. If issued, the license will be effective for a period of ninety (90) days from the date of issuance. The application fee is non-refundable. In the event a license holder applies for a renewal of a license issued by the township, a new fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be due and owing for a ninety (90) day extension. Upon issuance of the license, the licensee shall be issued a badge or badges including a serial number. The licensee and any individuals covered under the license shall wear the badge in a conspicuous place on his or her outer clothing while engaged in business under the license. 
(Prior code § 4-3.4) 
(Ord. No. 10-2015, §§ I, II, 9-22-2015) 
5.12.050 - Expiration-Renewal. 
    A license shall expire six months after the date of issuance. If a licensee desires to renew a license which is near expiration or which has expired, the licensee shall file with the township clerk a statement to the effect that all the statements and other information made in his or her previous application are still true and complete. If, through changed circumstances, the previous application does not contain true up-to-date information, then, the licensee shall state what changes, if any, should be made. Upon the filing of the renewal statement, the township clerk shall issue a renewal license for a six-month period. A copy of the renewal application statement shall also be given to the chief of police, who shall cause an investigation to be made to verify the truth of the statements contained therein. 
(Prior code § 4-3.5) 
5.12.060 - Revocation. 
    In addition to the provisions of Section 5.04.090, a license may be revoked if the licensee shall allow another person to use the badge or button issued or shall fail to immediately notify the township clerk of the loss of the badge or button. 
(Prior code § 4-3.6) 
5.12.070 - Hours. 
    No licensee shall canvass or solicit in the township, except between the hours of nine a.m. and six p.m. The licensee shall exhibit his or her button or badge to any police officer or any resident of the municipality upon request. 
(Prior code § 4-3.7) 
Chapter 5.16 - MASSAGE PARLORS 

5.16.010 - Premises defined. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Premises" means any location where massages are performed. 
(Prior code § 4-8.1) 
5.16.020 - License for establishment required. 
    No person shall operate any establishment or utilize any premises in the township as or for a massage business, unless and until a license has first been obtained from the board of health of the township in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 4-8.2) 
5.16.030 - License for employees required. 
    No person shall render or perform services as a masseur or masseuse, or engage in the business of or be employed as a masseur or masseuse unless and until he or she has obtained a masseur's or masseuse's license from the board of health of the township in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter. Each and every applicant for a license either for an establishment or premises to be used for a massage business or for a masseur's or masseuse's license shall set forth the following information, in writing, on forms provided by the township clerk: 
A.  The name and address of the applicant and all former addresses for a period of three years prior to making the application; 
B.  The address of the establishment or premises to be used in the massage business and a physical description of the property and facilities if the applicant desires a license for such establishment or premises; 
C.  If the applicant desires a masseur's or masseuse's license, a statement of all employment fora period of three years prior to making the application; 
D.  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a crime in this or any other state; 
E.  A report from a duly licensed physician authorized to practice medicine in the state of New Jersey that the applicant seeking the license has been tested for AIDS, venereal disease and tuberculosis and has been found to be free from same within thirty (30) days of the date of the application. 
(Prior code § 4-8.3) 
5.16.040 - License fees. 
A.  Fee for Establishment or Premises. The applicant for a license for an establishment or premises shall pay an annual license fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which license fee shall become due on the first day of February in each year. 
B.  Fee for Masseur's or Masseuse's License. The applicant for a masseur's or masseuse's license shall pay an annual license fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which license fee shall become due and payable on the first day of February in each year. 
C.  Prorated Fee. In the event that a license is granted after February 1st in any year, the annual license fee shall be prorated for that portion of the year remaining. 
(Prior code § 4-8.4) 
5.16.050 - Approval by township committee required. 
    Each application for a license or the renewal thereof, either to operate a massage establishment or premise or to engage in the business of or to be employed as a masseur or masseuse, which is submitted to the township clerk shall be approved by the township committee before any license is issued. The township committee shall not approve such application if, on the basis of the past criminal record of the applicant or of the principals thereof or on the basis of other evidence of bad character or morals, it shall determine that the granting or renewal of such license would tend to encourage or permit criminal or immoral activities within the township. 
(Prior code § 4-8.5) 
5.16.060 - Treatment of opposite sex prohibited. 
    No person engaged or employed in the business of a masseur or masseuse shall treat or massage a person of the opposite sex. 
(Prior code § 4-8.6) 
5.16.070 - Records to be kept. 
    Any person who shall be granted a license under this chapter shall be required to keep accurate records which shall indicate the name, address and telephone number of the person receiving the massage. Such record shall also indicate how the name, address and telephone number of the person receiving the massage was verified. The means of identification shall be a driver's license, but in the event that a driver's license is not available the record shall indicate what identification was available for verification. No massage shall be administered to a person who does not have available some means of identification sufficient to verify his or her name and address. Such records shall be available for inspection by township officials during the normal business hours of such licensee or on reasonable notice by the township official. 
(Prior code § 4-8.7) 
5.16.080 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to massage or physical therapy treatments given: 
A.  In the office of a license physician, osteopath, chiropractor or physical therapist; 
B.  In a regularly established medical center, hospital or sanitarium having a staff which includes licensed physicians, osteopaths, chiropractors and/or physical therapists; 
C.  By any license physician, osteopath, chiropractor or physical therapist in the residence of his or her patient. 
(Prior code § 4-8.8) 
5.16.090 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be punished either by imprisonment in the county jail for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days or by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or both, in the discretion of the court. Each act performed in violations of this chapter shall be considered a separate violation thereof. 
(Prior code § 4-8.9) 
Chapter 5.20 - PEDDLERS 

5.20.010 - Peddler defined. 
    As used in this chapter, "peddler" means any person, whether a resident of the township or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, food, ice cream, fruit ices, soda water, garden farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchases. "Hawkers", "hucksters" and "vendors" are included. 
(Prior code § 4-2.1) 
5.20.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a peddler within the corporate limits of the township without first obtaining a license. 
(Prior code § 4-2.2) 
5.20.030 - Fees. 
    The license fee for a peddler shall be one hundred fifty dollars per year ($150.00/year). No portion of the fee shall be prorated for any part of the year. A badge or I.D. card shall be furnished to the licensee by the township. 
(Prior code § 4-2.3) 
(Ord. No. 10-2015, §§ I, II, 9-22-2015) 
5.20.040 - Use of streets. 
    No peddler shall have an exclusive right to any location, nor shall he or she be permitted to operate in any congested area where his or her operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this section, the judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Prior code § 4-2.4) 
5.20.050 - Time restrictions. 
    No person shall sell, offer for sale, hawk or peddle in the township any of the items listed in Section 5.20.010 before eight a.m. or after five p.m., nor at any time on Sundays or holidays. 
(Prior code § 4-2.5) 
5.20.060 - Duty of police to enforce. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the township to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his or her peddler's license and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating them. 
(Prior code § 4-2.6) 
5.20.070 - Exceptions. 
    This chapter shall not be construed to include: 
A.  The delivery of milk, eggs, bread, newspapers or such other necessary and perishable articles of food or merchandise of the type commonly delivered on a house to house basis at intervals of less than one week; 
B.  Federal census takers and polls or surveys taken pursuant to federal, state or local laws; 
C.  Any veteran or volunteer firefighter who holds a special license issued pursuant to N.J.S.A 45:24-9 shall be exempt from application for a license, but shall be required to comply with all other applicable subsections of this title; 
D.  Any nonprofit, charitable, educational, civic or veterans organization, society, volunteer first aid or fire company or the like, desiring to solicit or have solicited in its name, money, donation of money or property or financial assistance of any kind, or desiring to sell or distribute any item of literature or merchandise for which a fee is charged or solicited from persons other than members of such organization at any place or places within the township for a charitable, patriotic or philanthropic purpose shall be exempt from the provisions of Section 5.20.030, but shall in all other respects comply with this chapter. 
(Prior code § 4-2.7) 
5.20.080 - Inspection of equipment. 
    The equipment used or employed by peddlers of ice cream, food, beverages, confections and other related commodities shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary manner and be subject to the inspection of the board of health or its authorized agents. Any violation found and not immediately corrected shall be grounds for revocation of the license. 
(Prior code § 4-2.8) 
Chapter 5.28 - GARAGE AND YARD SALES 

5.28.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Garage sale" includes all sales entitled "garage sale", "lawn sale", "yard sale", "attic sale", "rummage sale", or "flea market sale", or any similar casual sale of personal property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large is, or can be, made aware of said sale. 
    "Goods" includes any goods, warehouse merchandise or any other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated under this chapter. 
    "Person" includes individuals, partnerships, voluntary associations, and corporations. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 1) 
5.28.020 - Permit required. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale in the township without first filing with the clerk of the township the information herein after specified and obtaining from the clerk a permit to conduct such sale, to be known as a "garage sale permit". 
B.  The persons making application for the garage sale permit shall file a completed application with the township clerk seven days before the first day of the garage sale in order to provide adequate time for the processing of the permit. Clerk shall transmit each permit application to the chief of police or his designee, who shall review the information contained on the permit. The chief of police or his designee shall have the right to impose conditions on the permit relating to matters of public safety. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 2) 
5.28.030 - Permit restrictions; display. 
A.  The permit shall be issued only to the premises on which a residential dwelling is located; it being the intention to prohibit garage sales on vacant lots, and further to limit the issuance of said permits to specified premises rather than to any individual. The permit may be issued to any premises only twice within any twelve-month period, and the permit shall be issued for no more than three consecutive calendar days. In the event the yard sale does not occur due to inclement weather or other reason, the canceled event shall not count as one of the two times allowed per year. Furthermore, no person, firm, group, corporation or association shall, directly or indirectly, conduct a garage sale at any premises within the township of East Greenwich more than twice in any twelve-month period. Charitable, religious, and civic organizations may be allowed more than two permits with the approval of the township committee for the township of East Greenwich. 
B.  Each permit issued under this chapter must be prominently displayed on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the garage sale. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 3; Ord. No. 33-2009, 11-10-2009) 
5.28.040 - Application information. 
    The information to be filed with the clerk for the township shall be as follows: 
A.  The name of the person, firm, group, corporation, association or organization conducting such sale. 
B.  The name of the owner of the property on which said sale is to be conducted and consent of the owner if the applicant is other than the owner. 
C.  The location at which sale is to be conducted. 
D.  The number of days of the sale. 
E.  The date and nature of any past sale. 
F.  The relationship or connection the applicant may have had with any other person, firm, group, organization, association or corporation conducting such sale, and the date or dates of such sale. 
G.  Whether or not the applicant has been issued any other vendor's license by any other municipal county, state or federal agency. 
H.  A sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing that the information given is full, true and complete to the best of the applicant's knowledge. 
I.  Any other information deemed necessary by the Clerk. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 4) 
5.28.050 - Hours and limitations. 
    All garage sales shall be conducted between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. only. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 5; Ord. No. 33-2009, 11-10-2009) 
5.28.060 - Signs. 
A.  Signs posted or handled advertising a garage sale, as herein defined, shall be of the size not large than twenty-four (24) inches by twenty-four (24) inches and must contain in addition to the definition of the type of sale being advertised, the address of the person conducting the sale, the number of the permit issued by the township of East Greenwich, and the dates for which such permits were issued. 
B.  All such signs shall be removed no later than forty-eight (48) hours after the completion of the sale. 
C.  Newspaper advertisements of such sale shall contain the same information as required in the case of signs. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 6; Ord. No. 30-2009, 11-10-2009) 
5.28.070 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
A.  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
B.  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
C.  Any person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement, and which separate items do not exceed five in number. 
D.  Any sale conducted by any merchant or business establishment in a place of business wherein such sale would be permitted by the zoning regulations of the township, or under the protection of a nonconforming use section thereof, or any sale conducted by a manufacturer, dealer, or vendor which sale would be conducted from properly zoned premises and would not otherwise be prohibited in the township ordinances. 
E.  Any religious, charitable, educational, cultural, or other organization or association not for profit may be exempted from the limitation established in section 5.28.030 above, upon demonstration to the Township Committee for the Township of East Greenwich its right to such exemption. The production of a certified copy of a certificate of incorporation, pursuant to title 15 of the New Jersey Statute[s], shall be presumptive evidence of the right of such organization through this exemption. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 7) 
5.28.080 - Enforcement. 
A.  This chapter shall be enforced by the police department for the township. 
B.  The person to whom such license is issued and the owner or tenant of the premises on which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severely [severally] responsible for the maintenance of good order on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity. No such person shall permit loud or disorderly conduct on said premises nor permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets, or interfere with the orderly passage of pedestrian traffic on sidewalks in the area of such premises. 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 8) 
5.28.090 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm, association or corporation convicted of violating any provision of this chapter or any amendment or supplement thereto shall be subject to a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. 18-2009, § 9) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapter 6.04 - ANIMALS GENERALLY 

6.04.010 - Running at large. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or one in possession and control of any domestic or farm animal to allow any such animal to enter upon the property, public or private, of another. 
(Prior code § 3-12.1) 
6.04.020 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Anyone who is found guilty of violating this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisonment for a term of up to thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 3-12.2) 
Chapter 6.08 - DOGS 

6.08.010 - Definitions. 
    The words hereinafter defined shall have the meaning indicated for the purposes of this chapter as follows: 
    "Dog" means any dog, bitch or spayed bitch. 
    "Dog of licensing age" means any dog which has attained the age of seven months or which possesses a set of permanent teeth. 
    "Kennel" means any establishment wherein or whereon the business of boarding or selling dogs or breeding dogs for sale is carried on, except a pet shop. 
    "Owner," when applied to the proprietorship of a dog, means and includes every person having a right of property in such dog and every person who has such a dog in his or her keeping. 
    "Pet shop" means any room or group of rooms, cage or exhibition pen, not part of a kennel, wherein dogs for sale are kept or displayed. 
    "Pound" means an establishment for the confinement of dogs seized either under the provisions of this chapter or otherwise. 
    "Shelter" means any establishment where dogs are received, housed and distributed without charge. 
(Prior code § 6-1) 
6.08.020 - Licensing provisions. 
A.  License-When Required. Licenses shall be required for the following dogs of licensing age: 
1.  Any dog owned or kept within the township by a resident of the township on January 1st of any calendar year; 
2.  Any dog acquired by any person during the course of any calendar year and kept within the township for more than ten (10) days after acquisition; 
3.  Any dog attaining licensing age during the course of the calendar year; 
4.  Any unlicensed dog brought into the township by any person and kept within the township for more than ten (10) days; 
5.  Any dog licensed by another state brought into the township by any person and kept within the township for more than ninety (90) days. Any person who harbors or possesses any dog for a period of fifteen (15) days or more, for the purpose of this chapter, shall be the owner of the dog or dogs so harbored or possessed. 
B.  Application. The application shall state the breed, sex, age, color and markings of the dog for which license and registration are sought, and whether it is a long or short haired variety; also the name, street and post office address of the owner and the person who shall keep or harbor the dog. Applications for licenses for dogs which are required to be licensed by the provisions of subsection A of this section shall be made before the last day of January in each calendar year. In all other cases, the application for a license shall be made within ten (10) days of the day upon which the dog in question first becomes subject to the provisions of this section. Registration numbers for each application for registration of such dog or dogs shall be in the order in which the applications are made. 
C.  License Record. The person designated by the township committee shall provide a book for the purpose of registering the name of the person owning, keeping, possessing or harboring any dog or dogs and the name and number of each dog registered. The information on the application and the registration number issued for the dog shall be preserved for a period of three years by the township. In addition, similar information shall be forwarded to the State Department of Health each month, on forms furnished by the department by the person designated by the township committee. 
D.  License Fee-Late Fee-Tags. 
1.  License Fee. Every person who owns, possesses, keeps or harbors any dog or dogs within the limits of the township shall obtain a license for each dog and each dog shall be registered and numbered with the person and/or persons designated by the township committee for such purpose. Such person shall pay the sum of eight dollars ($8.00) as a license fee for each and every dog, for a one-year license period, provided each dog and every dog is spayed or neutered and vaccinated for rabies. If the dog is not spayed or neutered, such person shall pay the sum of eleven dollars ($11.00) as a license fee for each and every dog for a one-year license period. Such license fees specified herein are exclusive of additional charges for New Jersey Registration Fee, New Jersey Pilot Clinic Fund, New Jersey Pet Population Control and any other charges imposed by or on behalf of the State of New Jersey or any other agency or subdivision thereof. 
2.  Late Fee. A late fee of ten dollars ($10.00) will be imposed as an addition to any other license fee for any and all licensing registrations made after March 1, of each license year. 
3.  Tags. Upon receipt of the license fee, additional registration fees and late fee, if applicable, the person making the collection shall issue to each person paying such fees, a license and a numbered metal tag for each dog licensed, designated as a registration tag. The tag shall be securely attached to a strap or collar worn around the neck of each dog so licensed and each tag shall have marked thereon the words "Licensed Dog, Township of East Greenwich, N. J.", with the year for which it is issued The person in charge of issuing such tags may issue substitute tags upon proof, in writing, from the owner or member of the owner's household above the age of fourteen (14) years, sufficient to satisfy the person of the loss of the original tag. Any owner so obtaining such substitute tag or tags shall pay an additional registration fee of one dollar for each substitute tag. 
E.  License-Expiration. Each license shall contain the name and address of the owner of the dog or dogs and a short description of the dog, indicating name, breed, sex, age, color and markings and also the number of the license, and shall bear the signature of the person authorized by the township committee. All one-year licenses shall expire on the last day of January in each year. 
F.  Exception. Dogs used as guides for blind persons and commonly known as "seeing eye" dogs shall be licensed and registered as other dogs, except that the owner or keeper of the dog shall not be required to pay any fee therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1-2014, 2-11-2014; Ord. No. 11-2013, 8-14-2013; Prior code § 6-2) 
Note- Reservation-Any three-year dog license issued prior to the effective date of Ord. No. 1-2014 shall be honored for the balance of the license period. Any renewals shall be for a one-year license only. 
6.08.030 - Pet shops, kennels, shelters and pounds. 
A.  License Required. Any person who keeps or operates or proposes to establish a kennel, a pet shop, a shelter or pound shall apply to the person designated by the township committee for such purposes, for a license entitling him or her to keep or operate such establishment. Any person holding such license shall not be required to secure individual licenses for dogs owned by the licensee and kept at such establishments; such licenses shall not be transferable to another owner or different premises. 
B.  Application Information. The application shall contain the following information: 
1.  A description of the premises where the establishment is located or is proposed to be located; 
2.  The purpose or purposes for which it is to be maintained. 
C.  Approval of Board of Health-Compliance with State Regulations. Each application shall be accompanied by the written approval of the board of health, showing compliance with the local and state rules and regulations governing location of and sanitation of such establishments. Licenses shall be subject to revocation by the township committee on recommendations of the State Board of Health or the local board of health for failure to comply with the rules and regulations of either the State Department or local board governing the same after the owner has been afforded a hearing by either the State Department or local board. 
D.  License Contents and Term. All licenses issued for a kennel, pet shop, shelter or pound shall state the purpose for which the establishment is maintained. All such licenses shall expire on the last day of January of each year. 
E.  Fees. The annual license fee for kennels and pet shops shall be as follows: 
1.  Kennel accommodating ten (10) or less dogs, ten dollars ($10.00); 
2.  Kennel accommodating more than ten (10) dogs, twenty-five dollars ($25.00); 
3.  Pet shop, ten dollars ($10.00); 
4.  Shelter or pound, no fee. 
F.  Control of Dog Off Premises. No dog kept in a kennel, pet shop, shelter or pound shall be permitted off premises except on a leash or in a crate or other safe control. 
(Ord. 18-2001; prior code § 6-3) 
6.08.040 - Disposition of fees. 
    License fees and other moneys collected or received under the provisions of this chapter, except registration tag fees, shall be forwarded to the township treasurer within thirty (30) days after collection or receipt, and shall be placed in a special account separate from any of the other accounts of the township. These funds shall be used for the following purposes only: 
A.  For collecting, keeping and disposing of dogs liable to seizure under this chapter; 
B.  For local prevention and control of rabies; 
C.  For providing anti-rabies treatment under the direction of the local board of health for any person known or suspected to have been exposed to rabies; 
D.  For payment of damage to or losses of poultry or domestic animals, except dogs and cats, caused by a dog or dogs. 
    Any unexpended balance remaining in the special account shall be retained therein until the end of the third fiscal year following and may be used for any of the purposes set forth in this section. At the end of the third fiscal year following, and at the end of each fiscal year thereafter, there shall be transferred from the special account to the general funds of the township any amount then in the account which is in excess of the total amount paid into the special account during the last two fiscal years next preceding. The registration tag fee due to the State Department of Health shall be forwarded by the person designated by the township committee within thirty (30) days after collection. 
(Prior code § 6-4) 
6.08.050 - Dog canvass. 
    The township committee shall cause a canvass to be made of all dogs owned, kept or harbored within the limits of the township and shall report to the person designated by the township committee and to the secretary of the township board of health, and to the State Department of Health, the result, setting forth in separate columns, the names and addresses of persons owning, keeping or harboring dogs, the number of licensed dogs owned, kept or harbored by each of these persons, together with the registration numbers of each of the dogs, and the number of unlicensed dogs owned, kept or harbored by each person, together with a complete description of each of the unlicensed dogs. 
(Prior code § 6-5) 
6.08.060 - Dog warden. 
A.  Appointment. The township committee shall appoint some suitable and fit person or corporation who shall be known as the dog warden. 
B.  Duties. It shall be the duty of the dog warden to carry out the provisions of this chapter. In addition, the dog warden shall feed and properly care for all dogs confined in the dog pound, and he or she shall keep the dog pound in a clean and sanitary condition. 
    Any person desiring to have the township dog warden dispose of his or her dog shall pay the warden such fee as the warden shall charge under the circumstances. Any and all moneys received by the dog warden under the provisions of this chapter shall be retained by the dog warden. 
(Prior code § 6-6) 
6.08.070 - Disposal of pet solid waste. 
A.  Purpose. The township of East Greenwich finds that the establishment of requirements for the proper disposal of pet solid waste is an important public concern to protect public health, safety and welfare of its residents. 
B.  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings stated herein unless their use in the text of this chapter clearly demonstrates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not directory. 
1.  "Immediate" means that the pet solid waste is removed at once, without delay. 
2.  "Owner/keeper" means any person who shall possess, maintain, house or harbor any pet or otherwise have the custody of any pet, whether or not the owner of such pet. 
3.  "Person" means any individual, corporation, company, partnership, firm, association or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
4.  "Pet" means a domesticated animal (other than a disability assistance animal) kept for amusement or companionship. 
5.  "Pet solid waste" means waste matter expelled from the bowels of the pet; excrement. 
6.  "Proper disposal" means placement in a designated waste receptacle, or other suitable container, and discarded in a refuse container which is regularly emptied by the municipality or some other refuse collector; or disposal into a system designed to convey domestic sewage for proper treatment and disposal. 
C.  Removal of Pet Solid Waste. Any person owning or in charge of any pet shall immediately and properly dispose of the pet's solid waste deposited on any property, public or private, not owned or possessed by that person. 
D.  Exemptions. Any owner or keeper who requires the use of a disability assistance animal shall be exempt from any provisions of this section while such animal is being used for that purpose. 
E.  Enforcement. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the police department of the township of East Greenwich. 
F.  Violations and Penalties. Any person who violates the provisions of this section or the rules and regulations of the State Department of Health shall be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or a period of community service or imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten (10) days. 
(Ord. 11-05) 
6.08.080 - Impounding and destruction of certain dogs. 
A.  Causes for Impounding. The dog warden shall take into custody and impound or cause to be taken into custody or impounded, and thereafter destroyed or disposed of, as provided in this subsection: 
1.  Any dog off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring the dog, which the dog warden may have reason to believe is a stray dog; 
2.  Any dog off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring the dog without a current registration tag on his or her collar; 
3.  Any female dog in season off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring the dog. 
B.  Access to Premises. Any officer or agent authorized or empowered to perform any duty under this chapter is authorized to go upon any premises to seize for impounding any dog or dogs which he or she may lawfully seize or impound when the officer is in immediate pursuit of such dog or dogs, except upon the premises of the owner of the dog if the owner is present and forbids the same. 
C.  Notice of Seizure. If any dog so seized wears a collar or harness having inscribed thereon or attached thereto the name and address of any person or a registration tag, or the owner of the person keeping or harboring the dog is known, the dog warden shall forthwith serve on the person whose address is given on the collar, or on the owner or the person keeping or harboring the dog, if known, a notice in writing stating that the dog has been seized and will be liable to be disposed of or destroyed if not claimed within seven days after the service of the notice. A notice under this subsection may be served either by delivering it to the person on whom it is to be served, or by leaving it at the person's usual, or last known place of abode, or at the address given on the collar, or by forwarding it by post in a prepaid letter addressed to that person at his or her usual or last known place of abode, or to the address given on the collar. 
D.  Disposition of Unclaimed Dogs. The dog warden is authorized and empowered to cause the destruction of any unclaimed dog, in as humane a manner as possible, under any of the following contingencies: 
1.  When any dog so seized has been detained after seven days after notice, when notice can be given or has been detained for seven days after seizure when no notice has been given as set forth in subsection C of this section; 
2.  If the owner or person keeping or harboring the dog has not claimed the dog and paid all expenses incurred by reason of its detention, including maintenance; 
3.  If the dog be unlicensed at the time of the seizure and the owner or person keeping or harboring the dog has not produced a license and registration tag for the dog. 
(Prior code § 6-8) 
6.08.090 - Regulations. 
    No person shall own, keep, or harbor a dog in the township except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and the following regulations. 
A.  Wearing of Registration. All dogs which are required by the provisions of this chapter to be licensed shall wear a collar or harness with the registration tag for such dog securely fastened thereto. 
B.  Use of Registration Tag. No person, except an officer in the performance of his or her duties shall remove a registration tag from the collar of any dog without the consent of the owner, nor shall any person attach a registration tag to a dog for which it was not issued. 
C.  Interference with Official Duties. No person shall in any way hinder or interfere with the dog warden, police officers, or officials, constables, canvassers or any other peace officers in the performance of their duty under the provisions of this chapter, nor shall he or she refuse to give information to any person making the canvass herein provided for, or take a dog from the dog pound excepting upon redeeming such dog in the manner provided by this chapter or break or damage the dog pound. 
D.  No person owning or having charge, care, custody or control of any dog shall cause, permit or allow the same to be or to run at large upon any street, alley or other place or upon any private property or premises other than that of the person owning or having charge, care, custody or control of such dog within the township unless such dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is in the control of a competent person. 
E.  Disturbing the Peace. No person who owns, keeps, harbors, possesses, or who is in charge or control of, any dog or dogs shall suffer or permit such dog or dogs to annoy neighbors and other persons living in vicinity by continued barking and howling. A complaint may be filed in the municipal court by a township police officer who witnesses such barking and howling which violates the provisions of this section. 
F.  Running at Large. No person owning, keeping or harboring any dog or cat shall suffer or permit it to run at large upon the public streets, in any public park, upon private property other than that of the owner or on any other public place within the township. 
G.  Leashing of Dogs. No person owning, keeping or harboring any dog shall suffer or permit it to be upon the public streets or in any of the public places of the township unless such dog is accompanied by a person over the age of twelve (12) years and is securely controlled by such person. 
H.  Property Damage. No person owning, keeping or harboring a dog shall permit or suffer it to do any injury or to do any damage to any lawn, shrubbery, flowers, grounds or property. 
I.  Nuisances by Dogs. No person owning, harboring, keeping, walking or in charge of any dog shall cause, suffer, permit or allow such dog to soil, defile, defecate on or commit any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, street, sidewalk, passageway, road, bypass, play area, park, any place where people congregate or walk, upon any public property whatsoever or upon any private property without the permission of the owner of the private property in the last instance. If any such person permits the dog to soil, defile, defecate on or commit any nuisance in the areas aforesaid, he/she shall immediately remove and dispose of all feces and droppings deposited by the dog. Removal shall be in a sanitary manner by shovel, container, disposal bag or such other sanitary means. In a multiple dwelling complex, the tenant dog owner shall take his/her dog to only the designated areas for walking of dogs or other animals which shall be provided and maintained in a sanitary manner by the management of the complex, if any. On the dog owner's property, such dog owner shall maintain the property in a sanitary manner in order to prevent any noxious odors, attraction of vermin breeding or any other public health nuisance to neighbors. 
J.  Penned Dogs and Other Animals. Dogs and other animals which are penned outside of the home shall be adequately housed in shelters of appropriate size for the size of the animals. Adequate food and water shall be provided for the animals. 
(Ord. 8-2004: prior code § 6-9) 
(Ord. No. 10-2012, 7-10-2012) 
6.08.100 - Issuance of process-Hearing. 
    The judge of the municipal court is empowered, upon the filing of a complaint in writing by any person authorized by the board of health when the plaintiff is the board of health or by the chairperson of the police committee of the township committee, or the duly designated dog warden, when the plaintiff is the township, alleging that a violation of this chapter has occurred, which complaint may be made upon information and belief, to issue process at the suit of the board of health, or of the township, as the case may be, as plaintiff. The process shall be either in the nature of a summons or warrant. The warrant may issue without any order of the court first being obtained against the person so charged. The process when in the nature of a warrant, shall he returnable forthwith, and when in the nature of a summons shall be returnable in not less than five days nor more than fifteen (15) entire days. The process shall state what provision of this chapter or of any statute pertaining to the subject matter hereof has been violated by the defendant. The court may, at all times amend all defects and errors in the complaint and process issued hereunder. Any officer authorized by law to serve and execute process in the court in which the proceeding is brought hereunder, may serve and execute all process in proceedings for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of the laws and statutes relating thereto. On the return of process issued pursuant to this section or at any time to which the trial shall be adjourned, the court, without the filing of any pleadings, may proceed to hear the testimony in a summary manner without a jury and give judgment for plaintiff for the penalty and costs, or for the defendant, if the facts warrant an acquittal. 
(Ord. 19-2001; prior code § 6-10) 
6.08.110 - Violations-Penalty. 
    Any person who violates or who fails or refuses to comply with section 6.08.020 of this chapter shall be liable to a penalty of not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense, except that for the first offense, the penalty shall be not less than one dollar ($1.00) not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). For any other violation of this chapter, the general penalty clause shall apply. 
(Prior code § 6-11) 
Chapter 6.12 - PIGS 

6.12.010 - Noncommercial pigs restricted. 
A.  From and after December 5, 1949 it is unlawful for any person to acquire, keep and maintain more than forty (40) pigs, hogs or swine on any farm lands and premises in the township, which he or she may be occupying as owner, tenant, lessee or otherwise. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any person who has conducted a commercial piggery within the township without interruption or cessation of business for a period of ten (10) years. 
    Pigs that are ten (10) weeks of age, or younger, shall not be counted in determining whether the number of pigs kept or maintained exceeds the number of forty (40). 
    No pigs, hogs or swine of any age or description shall be kept and maintained on any lands and premises in the township unless they be kept and maintained in a proper and suitable enclosure. The enclosure shall be kept clean and free from all objectionable, foul, putrid and decaying animal and vegetable matter. 
B.  From and after December 5, 1949 it is unlawful for any person to keep and maintain pigs, hogs or swine in excess of three in number on any lands and premises located within the built-up town acres of Mt. Royal, Clarksboro and Mickleton. 
    Any person keeping or maintaining three pigs, hogs or swine shall keep them outside of the built-up areas of Mt. Royal Clarksboro and Mickleton. 
    Any person keeping or maintaining three pigs, hogs or swine shall keep them outside of the built-up areas of Mt. Royal, Clarksboro and Mickleton, upon lands or farms located in the section of the township agricultural in nature. 
(Prior code § 4-5.1) 
6.12.020 - Commercial piggeries. 
A.  Definition. Any person keeping and maintaining pigs or hogs in excess of forty (40) in number, raising and selling the animals as a business and using garbage as feed shall be construed to be maintaining a commercial piggery within the terms and provisions of this section. 
B.  Number of Piggeries Limited. Commercial piggeries in existence on December 5, 1949 may continue in business upon compliance with the terms of this section. No new commercial piggery shall be permitted. 
C.  Permit Regulations. The township clerk is authorized to issue permits to the commercial piggeries doing business on December 5, 1949. Permits shall be issued annually and shall expire on December 31st of each year. Permits shall apply only to the person to whom granted. All permits shall be nontransferable. If any commercial piggery shall discontinue operation and go out of business the permit for the commercial piggery shall not be issued to any other person, or subsequent owner of the premises involved. 
    Any person granted a permit is required to exhibit it to any member of the township committee or any other designated township official or any police or health officer whenever called upon to do so. 
D.  Premises Subject to Inspection. All premises where pigs, hogs or swine shall be kept shall be subject to inspection at all times. 
(Prior code § 4-5.2) 
6.12.030 - Garbage not to be used as feed. 
    With the exception of commercial piggeries as hereinafter defined, no garbage shall be used as feed. (Prior section § 4-5.3) 
6.12.040 - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or effect any person engaged in the slaughterhouse business where pigs and hogs are killed for the purpose of procuring pork products, but is intended to license regulate and control the acquiring keeping and maintaining of pigs, hogs or swine, and the commercial piggery. 
(Prior code § 4-5.4) 
Chapter 6.16 - FEEDING OF WILDLIFE 

6.16.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to prohibit the feeding of unconfined wildlife in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the township of East Greenwich so as to protect public health, safety and welfare, and to prescribe penalties for failure to comply. 
(Ord. 9-05 § A) 
6.16.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings stated herein unless their use in the text of this chapter clearly demonstrates a different meaning. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    "Feed" means to give, place, expose, deposit, distribute or scatter any edible material with the intention of feeding, attracting or enticing wildlife. Feeding does not include baiting in legal taking of fish and/or game. 
    "Person" means any individual, corporation, company, partnership, firm, association or political subdivision of this state subject to municipal jurisdiction. 
    "Wildlife" means all animals that are neither human nor domesticated. 
(Ord. 9-05 § B) 
6.16.030 - Prohibited conduct. 
    No person shall feed, in any public park or on any other property owned or operated by the township of East Greenwich, any wildlife, excluding confined wildlife (for example, wildlife confined in zoos, parks, or rehabilitation centers, or unconfined wildlife at environmental education centers). 
(Ord. 9-05 § C) 
6.16.040 - Enforcement. 
A.  This chapter shall be enforced by the police department of the township of East Greenwich. 
B.  Any person found to be in violation of this chapter shall be ordered to cease the feeding immediately. 
(Ord. 9-05 § D) 
6.16.050 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person(s) who is found to be in violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by one or more of the following: by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), at the discretion of the judge. 
(Ord. 9-05 § E) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapter 8.04 - PUBLIC HEALTH NUISANCE CODE ADOPTED 

8.04.010 - Establishment. 
    A code defining and prohibiting certain matters, things, conditions or acts as a nuisance, prohibiting certain noises or sounds, requiring the proper heating of apartments, prohibiting lease or rental of certain buildings, prohibiting spitting in or upon public buildings, conveyances or sidewalks, authorizing the inspection of premises by an enforcing official, providing for the removal or abatement of certain nuisances and recovery of expenses incurred by the board of health in removing or abating such nuisances and prescribing penalties for violations is hereby established pursuant to Chapter 188, Laws of 1950. A copy of this code is annexed to the ordinance codified in this chapter and made a part hereof without the inclusion of the text in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 18-1) 
8.04.020 - Short title. 
    The code established and adopted by this chapter described and commonly known as the "Public Health Nuisance Code of New Jersey (1953)". 
(Prior code § 18-2) 
8.04.030 - Copies on file. 
    Three copies of the code adopted by this chapter have been placed on file in the office of the township clerk and with the secretary of the East Greenwich Township board of health and will remain on file there for the use and examination of the public. 
(Prior code § 18-3) 
8.04.040 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any person who violates or neglects to comply with any provision of this chapter or code or notice issued pursuant thereto, upon conviction thereof, shall be liable to a penalty of not less than five dollars nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
(Prior code § 18-4) 
Chapter 8.08 - ABANDONED VEHICLES, MACHINERY AND EQUIPMENT 

8.08.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    "Motor vehicle" includes every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported, including unused, abandoned, or junk automobile or automobiles, which are defined to mean any automobile or motor vehicle which is no longer in actual use as a motor vehicle, or which is unfit for use without rebuilding or reconditioning. 
    "Chattel" includes any parts of vehicles, machinery, equipment, ice boxes, refrigerators, sinks, stoves, tanks, plumbing fixtures or appliances, and objects of like nature. 
    "Person" includes a natural person or an incorporated or unincorporated entity of whatsoever nature with the exception of a municipal or other public entity. 
    "Tenant" includes any person in actual possession of lands or premises who by virtue of such possession can control the disposition of motor vehicles or chattels found thereon in violation of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 3-4) 
8.08.020 - Prohibition. 
    No person shall place, leave, keep or store, or permit the placing, leaving, keeping or storage of any motor vehicle not currently in use and which does not have a current motor vehicle registration license and current inspection certificate where required for current use, or any unused chattel as herein defined, out of doors, upon any public or private land or premises in the township, or between the right-of-way side lines of any public street or thoroughfare for a continuous period of time exceeding ten (10) calendar days. Any motor vehicle or chattel remaining on such land or premises for a period in excess of such period of time shall be deemed abandoned for the purposes of this chapter. Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the placing, leaving, keeping or storing of any such vehicle or chattel in an enclosed building and further nothing herein contained shall prohibit the placing, leaving, keeping or storing of any such vehicle or chattel in open places on such lands and premises if the same are on such lands and premises in connection with and used in a bona fide farming operation. 
(Prior code § 3-4.2) 
8.08.030 - Abatement of public nuisances. 
    The location of abandoned vehicles or chattels as herein defined on such lands and premises is found and declared to be detrimental to the public health, safety and general welfare of the residents of this community and to constitute a public nuisance. The police department and board of health, or either of them, are empowered to take the remedial actions in this chapter provided to abate the same. 
(Prior code § 3-4.3) 
8.08.040 - Duty of owners and tenants. 
    The owner or tenant of private lands and premises within the township on which such abandoned motor vehicle or chattel is located is required to remove or cause to be removed from such lands and premises such vehicle or chattel and on failing to do so, after being given the notice hereinafter provided, shall be chargeable with violation, of this chapter and subject to the penalties herein provided. 
(Prior code § 3-4.4) 
8.08.050 - Notice. 
    Whenever it shall appear to any member of the police department or board of health that this chapter is being violated and that the land on which the violation exists is privately owned, he or she shall, in writing, notify the owner and tenant, if there be one, in possession of the land on which the violation exists to abate the violation by removing the article or articles constituting the violation from the land or into an enclosed building on the land within seven days of the service of the notice. Notice shall be served upon the owner and tenant, if he or she resides in the township, personally or by leaving it at his or her usual place of abode with some member of his or her household over the age of fourteen (14) years. If any such owner and tenant shall reside outside the township, or if personal service on a resident of the township as above provided is found to be impossible, the notice shall be served upon him or her by registered or certified mail, addressed to him or her at his or her usual residence if ascertainable, otherwise, by notice published in the newspaper in which the legal notices of the township may be published. The owner and tenant shall abate the violation within the time fixed by the notice which shall not be less than seven days. 
(Prior code § 3-4.5) 
8.08.060 - Reinspection. 
    At the expiration of the time to abate the violation as provided in Section 8.08.050, the police department or board of health shall cause the land where the violation exists to be reinspected and shall report in writing to the township clerk whether or not the violation has been abated. In the event it is reported that the violation has not been abated, then at the direction of the township committee, the police department or board of health shall cause the vehicle or chattel constituting the violation to be removed to a designated area for storage. 
(Prior code § 3-4.6) 
8.08.070 - Notice of removal. 
    If the vehicle or chattel is removed as provided in Section 8.08.060, the police department or board of health removing the article shall serve notice on the owner and tenant in the manner provided in Section 8.08.050 of such fact, which notice shall give the location to where the article has been removed and state the owner's right to reclaim it by paying the cost of removal and interim storage charges. 
(Prior code § 3-4.7) 
8.08.080 - Lien of cost of removal. 
    The township official causing such removal shall promptly certify the cost thereof to the township committee which shall then examine such certificate and if found to be correct and, provided further that the cost of removal has not been satisfied as provided in Section 8.08.070, shall cause the cost so determined to be charged against the land on which the violation existed. The amount so charged shall thereupon become a lien upon such land and shall be added to and become and form part of the taxes next to be assessed and levied upon such land, the same to bear interest at the same rate as taxes, and shall be collected and enforced by the same officers and in the same manner as taxes. 
(Prior code § 3-4.8) 
8.08.090 - Removal of traffic hazards. 
    Whenever it shall appear to any member of the police department that this chapter is being violated and that the violation exists on public lanes or between the right-of-way side lines of any public street or thoroughfare, he or she shall determine whether such article is or may constitute a traffic hazard. If he or she so determines, and if the owner of the article cannot be promptly ascertained and located, or refuses to remove the article himself or herself, then the police department, on direction of the township committee, shall forthwith cause such article to be removed to a designated area. If not previously determined, after such removal, the police department shall attempt to ascertain the name of owner of such article and shall give to the owner the notice provided in Section 8.08.070. 
(Prior code § 3-4.9) 
8.08.100 - Removal of other vehicles or chattels on public land. 
    If the article constituting a violation of this chapter is not determined to be a traffic hazard as provided in Section 8.08.090, then whenever it shall appear to any member of the police department or board of health that this chapter is being violated and that the land on which the violation exists is publicly owned, he or she shall forthwith attempt to ascertain the owner of the article constituting such violation. On ascertaining such notice, he or she shall proceed to serve on such owner the notice specified in Section 8.08.050, except that it shall be stated in the notice that the time for the owner of the article to abate the violation shall be two days. At the expiration of the two days, the procedures set forth in Sections 8.08.060 and 8.08.070 shall be followed. If it is impossible with reasonable diligence to ascertain the name of the owner of such article, then after two days following discovery of the violation, the article constituting the violation shall be removed to a designated area by direction of the township committee and, thereafter, the police department or board of health shall attempt to ascertain the name of the owner of such article and shall give the owner the notice provided in Section 8.08.070. 
(Prior code § 3-4.10) 
8.08.110 - Sale or disposal of goods. 
    If any article or articles impounded as provided in this chapter shall remain unclaimed, as provided herein, the impounded article or articles shall be deemed to have been abandoned and forfeited by the owner and the township committee shall sell and dispose of them as provided by law. 
(Prior code § 3-4.11) 
8.08.120 - Liability of violators. 
    In addition to being subject to the powers and authority of township officials as provided in this chapter, the owner and tenant of private lands where a violation exists and the owner of articles constituting a violation on public lands or between the right of way side line of any public street or thoroughfare shall be also subject to the penalties imposed under this chapter for violation hereof. 
(Prior code § 3-4.12) 
Chapter 8.12 - ALARM SYSTEMS 

8.12.010 - False alarm defined. 
    "False alarm" means any alarm activated by negligence, unintentional acts by someone other than an intruder, animals, inanimate objects, weather, as well as inadvertence or malfunction of the alarm device or related equipment except for such activation caused by a power failure or an act of God. 
(Prior code § 3-17.1) 
8.12.020 - Applicability. 
A.  This chapter shall apply to any individual who is the owner or tenant of a residence, to any individual, partnership or corporation that owns, operates or releases any business, office, warehouse or any other commercial of professional entity wherein a security alarm device for police or fire protection designed to summon the police or fire department to any location in response to any type of alarm signal. 
B.  Said individual, partnership, corporation or other commercial or professional entity shall register with the police department the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of an emergency contact person or persons; 
2.  The name, address and telephone number of the security alarm server and/or control center; and 
3.  A description of the security alarm systems. 
(Ord. 3-1999 § 1; Ord 4-1997 § 1 (part): prior code § 3-17.2) 
8.12.030 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Anyone described under Section 8.12.020 who is aware that an alarm signal is false must notify the East Greenwich Township police department or the fire department immediately. In the event the security alarm system is monitored with the signal first going to a message sending bank that intercepts the signal before the police or fire are notified must be advised that the alarm is false.
