"Retailer", as defined by New Jersey Statute N.J.S.A. 2C:34-3.1, as used in this act, means any person who operates a store, newsstand, booth, concession or similar business with unimpeded access for persons under eighteen (18) years old, who is in the business of making sales of periodicals or other publications at retail containing pictures, drawings or photographs. 
(Ord. 21-04 § 1 (part)) 
9.34.040 - Violations-Sentencing. 
A.  Fines and Sentencing: A person convicted of violating this ordinance shall be punished by a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or be imprisoned in the Gloucester County Jail for a term of up to thirty (30) days, or any combination thereof. 
B.  Additional Fines; Subsequent Conviction. In addition to any of the fines and imprisonment set forth above, and pursuant to New Jersey Statute N.J.S.A. 40:49-5, a person who is convicted of violating this ordinance within one year of the date of a previous violation of the same ordinance and who was fined for the previous violation, shall be sentenced by a court to an additional fine as a repeat offender. The additional fine imposed by the court upon a person for a repeated offense shall not exceed the maximum fine fixed for a violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter, but shall be calculated separately from the fine imposed for the violation of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 21-04 § 1 (part)) 
Chapter 9.38 - COMMUNICATIONS AMPLIFICATION SYSTEMS 
Sections: 

9.38.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms shall, for the purposes of this Section and as used elsewhere in this code, have the meanings shown herein. 
    "APCO" means Association of Public Safety Communications Officers International. 
    "NABER" means National Association of Business and Education Radio. 
    "GCER" means Gloucester County Emergency Response. 
    "GCEMS" means Gloucester County Emergency Medical Services. 
    "PCIA" means Personal Communications Industry Association. 
    "FCC" means Federal Communications Commission. 
    "CAS" means communication amplification system. 
    "NPSPAC" means National Public Safety Planning Advisory Committee (frequencies designed for national radio interoperability). 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.020 - Gelneral Provisions. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no person shall erect, construct, alter, refit, change the use of, or provide an addition of more than twenty (20) percent of the existing floor area to, any building or structure of any part thereof, or cause the same to be done, which fails to support adequate radio coverage for GCER, GCEMS and the East Greenwich Police, Fire and Ambulance Departments. For the purposes of this chapter, adequate radio coverage shall include all of the following: 
1.  A minimum signal strength of one hundred (100) dBm available in ninety (90) percent of the area of each floor of the building when transmitted from the closest GCER radio communications system site; 
2.  A minimum signal strength of one hundred (100) dBm received at the closest GCER radio communications site when transmitted from ninety (90) percent of the area of each floor of the building; 
3.  As the CAS is part of the public safety radio system, the owner must adapt according to any growth changes or modifications as instructed by local authorities; 
4.  The frequency range which must be supported shall be compatible to the current public safety radio system in use by the township; 
5.  A ninety (90) percent reliability factor; 
6.  Signal strength measurements, for the purpose of measuring the performance of a bi-directional amplifier, shall be based on one input signal adequate to obtain a maximum continuous operating output level. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall become applicable upon notification to the property owner that unacceptable performance levels exist. The property owner shall have ninety (90) days from date of notification to enhance radio coverage and bring it within the acceptable limits of these provisions. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.030 - Amplification systems allowed. 
    Buildings and structures which cannot support the required level of radio coverage shall be equipped with either a radiating cable system or an internal multiple antenna system with or without FCC type accepted bi-directional amplifiers as needed. If any part of the installed system or systems contains an electrically powered component, the system shall be capable of operating on an independent battery and/or generator system for a period of at least twelve (12) hours without external power input. The battery system shall charge in the presence of an external power input. If used, bi-directional amplifiers shall include filters to reduce adjacent frequency interference at thirty-six (36) dB below the NPSPAC band. Settings used should not attenuate the NPSPAC frequencies and further provided that they are not more than one (1) MHz from the NPSPAC frequencies. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.040 - Testing procedures. 
    When an in-building radio system is required, and upon completion of installation, it will be the building owner's responsibility to have the radio system tested to ensure that two-way coverage on each floor of the building is a minimum of ninety (90) percent. Each floor of the building shall be divided into a grid of approximately twenty (20) equal areas. A maximum of two nonadjacent areas will be allowed to fail the test. In the event that three of the areas fail the test, in order to be more statistically accurate, the floor may be divided in forty (40) equal areas. In such event, a maximum of four nonadjacent areas will be allowed to fail the test. After the forty-area test, if the system continues to fail, the building owners shall have the system altered to meet the ninety (90) percent coverage requirement. The test shall be conducted using the most current Motorola portable radio or its equivalent talking through the GCER as specified by the authority having jurisdiction. A spot located approximately in the center of a grid area will be selected for the test, then the radio will be keyed to verify two-way communications to and from the outside of the building through the GCER. Once the spot has been selected, prospecting for a better spot within the grid area will not be permitted. 
    The gain values of all amplifiers shall be measured and the test measurement results shall be kept on file with the building owner so that the measurements can be verified each year during the annual tests. In the event that the measurement results become lost, the building owner will be required to rerun the acceptance test to reestablish the gain values. 
    Tests shall be made using the following guidelines: 
1.  With a service monitor or signal meter using a unity gain antenna on a small ground plane; 
2.  Measurements shall be made with the antenna held in a vertical position at three to four feet above the floor; 
3.  A calibrated service monitor or signal meter (with a factory calibration dated within twenty-four (24) months) may be used to do the test; 
4.  The GCER representative may also make simultaneous measurements to verify that the equipment is making accurate measurements. A variance of three db between the instruments will be allowed; and 
5.  If measurements in one location are varying, then average measurements shall be used. 
    Tests shall be made using the designated frequencies used by emergency response personnel. All tests shall be made in concert with GCER. If interference problems are noted, it is the owner's responsibility to ensure action is taken to reduce them. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.050 - Annual tests. 
    When an in-building radio system is required, the building owner shall test all active components of the system, including but not limited to amplifiers, power supplies and backup batteries, a minimum of once every twelve (12) months. Amplifiers shall be tested to ensure that the gain is the same as it was upon initial installation and acceptance. Backup batteries and power supplies shall be tested under load for a period of one hour to verify that they will properly operate during an actual power outage. If within the one-hour test period, in the opinion of the testing technician, the battery exhibits symptoms of failure, the test shall be extended for additional one-hour periods until the testing technician confirms the integrity of the battery. All other active components shall be checked to determine that they are operating with the manufacturer's specifications for the intended purpose. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.060 - Five-year tests. 
    In addition to the annual test, the building owner shall perform a radio coverage test a minimum of once every five years to insure that the radio system continues to meet the requirements of the original acceptance test. The procedure set forth above shall apply to such tests. A copy of accepted tests shall be provided to the GCER. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.070 - Qualifications of testing personnel. 
    All tests shall be conducted, documented and signed by a person in possession of a current FCC technician license, or a current technician certification issued by APCO, NABER, or the PCIA. All test records shall be retained on the inspected premises by the building owner and a copy submitted to municipal officials. 
    All tests will be performed in conjunction with GCER. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.080 - Field testing. 
    Police and fire personnel, after providing reasonable notice to the owner or his representative, shall have the right to enter onto the property to conduct field testing to be certain that the required level of radio coverage is present. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.090 - Exemptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to: structures in use groups R-3 and R-4; any building constructed of wood frame; and building thirty-five (35) feet high or less; as long as none of the aforementioned buildings make use of any metal construction or any underground storage or parking areas. For purposes of this chapter, parking structures and stairwells are included in the definition of "building" and stair shafts are included in the definition of "all parts of a building" but elevators may be excluded. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
9.38.100 - Existing buildings and structures. 
    Any non-exempt building or structure under construction or for which a building permit application is pending or has been approved as of the effective date of this section [July 22, 2008] shall comply with the requirements of this chapter if GECER, East Greenwich Fire Department and/or Police Department determines that adequate radio coverage as defined does not exist in the building or structure. The owner of the building or structure shall be notified in writing of the inadequacy of the coverage and shall have a period of ninety (90) consecutive calendar days from the date of the notice to comply with this section; including, but not limited to enhancing radio coverage and bringing it within the acceptable limits of this section. 
(Ord. 14-2008, § 2) 
Chapter 9.42 - NUISANCE 

9.42.010. - Unnecessary or unusual noise prohibited. 
A.  No person shall make, continue or cause to be made or continued, any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which does or is likely to annoy, disturb, injure or endanger the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others, within the limits of the township. 
(Ord. No. 11-2011, § 2, 7-12-2011) 
9.42.020. - Definition of noise. 
A.  The following acts are hereby declared to be examples of loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise in violation of this section: 
    "Animals, birds. The keeping of animals or birds, which by causing frequent or long-continued noise disturbs the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
    "Blowers." The operation of any blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
    "Construction or repair." The carrying out of excavation, demolition, construction, repair or alteration work, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. weekdays and Saturdays, the carrying out of construction, repair or alteration work by a homeowner on his/her own dwelling or property, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
    In the case of urgent necessity or in the interest of public health or safety, the township engineer may grant a permit for excavation, demolition, construction, repair, alteration work for a period not to exceed three days, which may be renewed for additional periods of three days, while the emergency continues by the terms of which permit such work may be carried on during the hours specified in the permit. 
    "Courts, schools, churches." The creation of excessive noise on a street adjacent to a school, institution of learning, church or court while in use which unreasonably interferes with the working of the institution or which disturbs or unduly annoys the students, teachers and administrators, congregation. 
    "Defect in vehicle or load." The use of an automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner that it creates loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noises. 
    "Drums." The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale. 
    "Exhaust." The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of a steam engine, internal combustion engine or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises. 
    "Hawkers, peddlers." The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
    "Horns and signaling devices." The sounding of a horn or signaling device on an automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle, on any street or public place except when required by law, or when necessary to give timely warning of the approach of the vehicle, or as warning of impending danger to person driving other vehicles or to persons on the street. No person shall sound a horn or signaling device on an automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle which emits an unreasonably loud or harsh sound, or for an unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. No person shall use any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity. The use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhausts is prohibited. The use of any signaling device when traffic for any reason is held up is prohibited. 
    "Loading, unloading, opening boxes." The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers. 
    "Loudspeaker; amplifiers for advertising." The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is case upon the public streets for purpose of commercial advertising or for any other purpose, with the following exceptions: such sound as may attract attention but which will not disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the inhabitants, provided such sound is produced and caused to be produced only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Such sound shall not be audible in any location for a period of longer than five minutes in any hour, except by special permit from the township committee. 
    "Outside alarms." The use of any alarm system emitting an audible or visible response shall, at the time such system is installed, cause to be installed an automatic timing device which shall deactivate such alarm so that it will be activated for no more than fifteen (15) minutes. All outside alarms shall be registered with the police department with an emergency phone number, as well as an alternate phone number, where someone with responsibility in relation to the alarmed premises may be contacted at any time by the police department. 
    "Pile drivers, hammers." The operation, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on weekdays, of any pile driver, steam shovel, bulldozer or other earth moving machinery, pneumatic hammer, derrick steam or electric hoist or any other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise. 
    "Public sales, taxicabs." Public outcries shall be prohibited at or for any public sale or auction, or to advertise any goods, wares or merchandise for sale, or to attract any attention, or to gain passengers for any cab, taxicab, hack or omnibus. 
    "Radios, televisions, phonographs." The playing, use or operation of a radio receiving set, television, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound, in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of neighboring inhabitants or with louder volume necessary for convenient hearing for persons who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which the machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device so that it is clearly audible at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet from the building structure of vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
    "Whistles." The blowing of any whistles, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper township authorities, or as may be required by general law or ordinance. 
    "Yelling, shouting." Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time or place, which annoys or disturbs the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, dwelling, hotel, motel or other type of residence of any person in the vicinity. 
    The above enumeration is intended to give typical illustrations of prohibited noise and shall not be construed as exclusive. 
(Ord. No. 11-2011, § 3, 7-12-2011) 
9.42.030. - Violations and penalties. 
A.  Any person, entity or corporation who or which violates any provision of this chapter, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by one or more of the following: imprisonment in the county jail or any place provided by the municipality for the detention of prisoners for a term up to but not exceeding ninety (90) days or by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by a period of community service up to but not exceeding ninety (90) days, or any combination of the above. 
B.  Each day that a violation exists, occurs, or continues shall constitute a separate offense for the purpose of imposing the penalties referred to above. 
(Ord. No. 11-2011, § 4, 7-12-2011) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapter 10.04 - TRAFFIC CONTROL REGULATIONS GENERALLY 

10.04.010 - Words and phrases. 
    Whenever any words and phrases are used in this chapter and Chapters 10.08 through 10.16, the meanings respectively ascribed to them in Subtitle 1 of Title 39 of the Revised Statutes of New Jersey shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used herein. 
(Prior code § 7-1) 
10.04.020 - Official time standard. 
    Whenever certain hours are named in this chapter, they shall mean either Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Savings Time, as may be in current use in the township. 
(Prior code § 7-2) 
10.04.030 - Limiting the use of streets to a certain class of vehicles. 
A.  Trucks Over Five Tons. Trucks weighing over five tons gross weight are excluded from streets or parts of streets described in Schedule IV, set out in Chapter 10.40, except for the pick up and delivery of materials. The tonnages specified shall in no event be less than five tons. 
B.  Trucks Over Ten Tons. Vehicles weighing over ten (10) tons gross weight are excluded from the streets or parts of streets described in Schedule IVA, set out in Chapter 10.40, except for the pick up and delivery of materials. 
(Prior code § 7-5) 
10.04.040 - Stop intersections. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of N.J.S.A. 39:4-140, the intersections described in Schedule V, set out in Chapter 10.40, are designated as stop intersections. Stop signs shall be installed as provided herein. 
(Prior code § 7-6)

D.  No passing shall be permitted along the length of Friendship Road from its intersection with Harmony Road (County Route No. 680) and Cohawkin Road (County Route No. 667). 
(Ord. 14-1998; Ord. 25-1996; prior code § 7-9; Ord. No. 10-2018, 11-13-2018) 
Chapter 10.16 - PARKING 

10.16.010 - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this chapter imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person of the duty to observe other, more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles as set forth in N.J.S.A. 39:4-138, any other New Jersey statute or as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 2-05 (part); prior code § 7-3.1) 
10.16.020 - Parking prohibited during state of emergency. 
A.  Upon the declaration of an emergency, there shall be no parking upon streets or sections of streets where temporary "EMERGENCY NO PARKING" signs are displayed. The director of public safety or the posting of "EMERGENCY NO PARKING" signs when weather conditions, accidents, fires, public celebrations, etc. dictate or require the avoidance of hazards or other conditions which interfere with the free flow of traffic. Notification that "EMERGENCY NO PARKING" signs are being or will be posted shall be given to the operator or owner of any vehicle which has been parked prior to the posting of the signs. 
B.  Any unoccupied motor vehicle or trailer parked in violation of this chapter shall be deemed to constitute an interference with the free flow of traffic, and the township may provide for the removal of such vehicle. The owner or operator of the motor vehicle or trailer shall pay the reasonable costs of removal and storage which may result from such removal before regaining possession of the vehicle. 
C.  Any person violating the ordinance codified in this section shall, upon conviction in the Municipal Court, be fined in an amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), or more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). Each such motor vehicle and trailer parked in violation of the ordinance codified in this section shall constitute a separate violation of this ordinance, for each day of such violation. 
(Ord. 2-05 (part); prior code § 7-3.2) 
10.16.021 - Temporary parking prohibition for snow removal plowing and removal. 
A.  Whenever snow has fallen and the accumulation is such that it covers the streets and highways, an emergency shall exist and no vehicle shall be parked on the streets or highways or portions thereof within the township. 
B.  The above parking prohibitions shall remain in effect after the snow has ceased until the streets have been plowed sufficiently and to the extent that parking will not interfere with the snowplowing operations and with then normal flow of traffic. 
C.  Any person violating the ordinance codified in this section shall, upon conviction in the Municipal Court, be fined in an amount not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), or more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). Each such motor vehicle and trailer parked in violation of the ordinance codified in this section shall constitute a separate violation of the ordinance codified in this section. 
(Ord. 2-05 (part)) 
10.16.030 - Parking prohibited at all times on certain streets. 
    No person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets or parts of streets described in Schedule I, set out in Chapter 10.40. 
(Prior code § 7-3.3) 
10.16.040 - Parking prohibited on Sundays during certain hours on certain streets. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on Sundays between the hours specified upon any of the streets or parts of streets described in Schedule II, set out in Chapter 10.40. 
(Prior code § 7-3.4) 
10.16.050 - Overnight parking of trucks. 
    No trucks, tractors or tractors and trailers weighing over five ton gross weight shall be permitted to park on any municipal street or road, within the township, between the hours of ten (10:00) p.m. and seven (7:00) a.m. The no parking prohibition shall include not only those vehicles left unattended with all power off, but also those vehicles standing unattended with any motors running. 
(Ord. 4-1998 § 1: prior code § 7-3.5) 
10.16.060 - No stopping or standing. 
    No person shall stop or stand a vehicle upon any of the streets or parts of streets described in Schedule VIII, set out in Chapter 10.40. 
(Prior code § 7-8) 
10.16.070 - Parking prohibited in designated fire zones. 
A.  The fire official under the direction of the Uniform Fire Code shall designate fire lanes within the Township of East Greenwich as the fire official determines necessary to protect the public health and safety by the posting of no parking signs in the designated fire zones. 
B.  It shall be the responsibility of the property owners to post the proper signs and markings for any designated fire lanes. Such designation shall be made within twenty (20) days after receipt of written notices from the chief to do so. 
C.  No person shall park any vehicle in or otherwise obstruct any designated fire lanes. 
D.  The bureau of fire prevention of the Township of East Greenwich and the Township of East Greenwich police department shall have concurrent jurisdiction to enforce subsection (C) by the issuance of a summons with a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. In addition, any vehicle parked in violation of subsection (C) will be towed and stored at the owner's expense. 
E.  It shall be the right of any person receiving such a summons to plead guilty or not guilty to the charge of violating this section. Those persons pleading not guilty to the charge of violating this section shall be given the opportunity to present their defense before the municipal court where a determination of guilt or innocence will be made. 
F.  Persons pleading guilty to or convicted of violating this section shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation, plus court costs. All fines and court costs shall be payable to the clerk of the municipal court. Court costs shall be retained by the municipal court and turned over to the municipal treasurer as prescribed by law. If authorized by law, the fines may be payable to the bureau of fire protection, retained by the Township of East Greenwich or allocated in an amount to be determined by the township committee. 
(Ord. 1-2001 § 1, 2002) 
10.16.080 - Prohibiting parking at the municipal annex. 
A.  All parking is hereby prohibited anywhere upon the site known as the Municipal Annex located at 21 East Cohawkin Road, Mickleton, unless by an employee of the Township of East Greenwich, by any person transacting lawful business with the Township of Each Greenwich, by members of the East Greenwich Ambulance Association, Inc., or by persons transacting business with that association. 
B.  Persons pleading guilty to or convicted of violating this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per violation plus court costs. All fines and court costs shall be payable to the clerk of the municipal court, court costs shall be retained by the municipal court and turned over to the municipal treasurer as prescribed by law. 
(Ord. 15-2003) 
Chapter 10.20 - INTERSECTION OBSTRUCTIONS 

10.20.010 - Sight triangles. 
    Sight triangles shall be maintained at intersections in which no grading, planting or structure shall be erected or maintained more than twelve (12) inches above the street centerline, except for street signs, fire hydrants and light standards. The sight triangle is defined as that area outside of the street right-of-way which is bounded by the intersecting points, one each located on the two intersecting street centerlines: arterial streets at three hundred (300) feet; collector streets at two hundred (200) feet; and local streets at ninety (90) feet. Where the intersecting streets are both arterials, both collectors or one arterial and one collector, two overlapping sight triangles will be required, formed by connecting the sign point noted above with a sight point ninety (90) feet on the intersecting street. 
(Prior code § 3-15.1) 
10.20.020 - Exceptions. 
    This chapter is independent of any sight triangle requirements imposed as part of the subdivision and site plan review process. 
(Prior code § 3-15.2) 
10.20.030 - Enforcement. 
    This chapter shall be enforced by the police department in consultation with the township engineer where necessary. 
(Prior code 3-15.3) 
10.20.040 - Violation-Penalties. 
A.  Violation. Anyone in violation of this section shall be given written notice of the violation and shall have thirty (30) days to correct the condition. If such condition is not corrected, then a complaint may be filed in municipal court. 
B.  Penalties. For the first offense, a penalty shall be imposed in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus court costs. In its discretion, the court may consider each day a separate and distinct violation. 
    For a second or subsequent offense, a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be imposed. Each day may be considered a separate and distinct violation by the court. 
    The court may further order the removal and obstruction and, in the event that it is not removed within fifteen (15) days of the court order, the court may permit the removal of the obstruction by the township and the cost of such removal shall be borne by the property owner and shall attach as a lien against the property until paid in full. 
(Prior code § 3-15.4) 
Chapter 10.24 - DRUNK DRIVING FREE SCHOOL ZONES 

10.24.010 - Designation of school crossings. 
    In accordance with and pursuant to the authority of P.L. 1999 Ch. 185, the list of school crossings which have been so designated by the township, is incorporated herein, made a part hereof, and marked as Exhibit A. 
(Ord. 6-2000 § 1) 
10.24.020 - Adoption of map. 
    The drunk driving free school zone map produced on or about April, 2000 by Churchill Consulting Engineers is approved and adopted as an official finding and record of the location and areas within the municipality of property which is used for school purposes and which is owned by or leased to any elementary school on school land and of the areas on or within one thousand (1,000) feet of school property. 
(Ord. 6-2000 § 2) 
10.24.030 - Map and list to constitute official findings. 
    The drunk driving free school zones map as approved and adopted shall continue to constitute an official finding and record as to the location and boundaries of areas on or within one thousand (1,000) feet of property owned by or leased to any elementary or secondary school or school board which is used for school purposes until such time, if any, that this shall be amended to reflect any additions or deletions with respect to the location and boundaries of school property and drunk driving free school zones. The list of school crossings designated above by the township committee shall continue to constitute an official finding and record of the location of school crossing zones within the township until such time, if any, that this shall be amended to reflect any additions or deletions with respect to school crossing zones in East Greenwich Township. 
(Ord. 6-2000 § 3) 
10.24.040 - Changes in location or boundaries. 
    The school board, or the chief administrative officer in the case of any private or parochial school, is directed and shall have the continuing obligation to promptly notify the office of the township engineer and the township attorney of any changes or contemplated changes in the location and boundaries of any property owned by or leased to any elementary or secondary school or school board and which is used for school purposes or of any additions or deletions to school crossings. 
(Ord. 6-2000 § 4) 
10.24.050 - Original map and list to be on file. 
    The township clerk is directed to receive and to keep on file the original of the map approved and adopted and the list of school crossings and to provide at a reasonable cost a true copy thereof to any person, agency or court which may from time to time request such a copy, along with a certification that such copy is a true copy of the map approved and adopted herein and kept on file. It is further directed that a true copy of such map and list and of this chapter shall be provided without cost to the Gloucester County clerk and to the office of the Gloucester County prosecutor. 
(Ord. 6-2000 § 5) 
10.24.060 - Map and list as evidence. 
    The following additional matters are determined declared, recited and stated: 
    It is understood that the map and list approved and adopted was prepared and is intended to be used as evidence in prosecutions arising under the criminal and traffic laws of this state and that, pursuant to state law, such map and list shall constitute prima facie evidence of the following: 
A.  The location of elementary and secondary schools within the municipality; 
B.  The boundaries of the real property which is owned by or leased to such schools or a school board; 
C.  That such school property is and continues to be used for school purposes; 
D.  The location and boundaries of areas which are on or within one thousand (1,000) feet of such school property; and 
E.  The location of all school crossings in the township. 
(Ord. 6-2000 § 6) 
Chapter 10.28 - MINIBIKES 

10.28.010 - Findings. 
    The township committee recognizes the safety hazard created by operation and use on public thoroughfares of minibikes and other motor-driven vehicles which do not meet the standard equipment requirements under the motor vehicle laws (Title 39) of the state of New Jersey. Pursuant to R.S. 40:48-2, the township committee deems it to be in the best interest of the township, and necessary and proper for the protection of persons and property therein, that all minibikes and similar motor-driven vehicles be registered with the township and that their use be controlled. 
(Prior code § 3-8.1) 
10.28.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Minibike" means an unlicensed motor-driven vehicle or conveyance, including but not necessarily limited to two wheel motor vehicles known as mini-bicycles, trail bicycles, or motor scooters. The term "minibike" shall not include "motorized bicycles" as defined in N.J.S.A. 39:1-1. 
    "Person" means any individual, association or corporation. 
(Ord. 23-2001; prior code § 3-8.2) 
10.28.030 - Registration requirements. 
A.  Registration Required. From and after October 11, 1976, no person shall own, ride or operate a minibike within the township unless such minibike is registered pursuant to the terms of this chapter. 
B.  Registration Procedure. 
1.  Application for registration shall be made by the owner of the minibike to the township clerk upon a form approved by the mayor and the township committee. Such form shall require the name and address of the owner, the make, model and serial number of the minibike, and such information as the mayor and the township committee shall deem necessary and proper. 
2.  The owner shall sign the registration form and shall certify that the information contained thereon is true. 
3.  A separate registration shall be required for each minibike. 
4.  A registration fee in the amount of two dollars shall accompany each registration form. 
C.  Minibike Tags. 
1.  Upon receipt of the registration fee and a completed registration form signed by the owner, the township clerk shall submit the registration form to the chief of police or his or her designee. 
2.  The chief of police, or his or her designee, upon receipt of the registration form from the township clerk, shall issue to the registrant a minibike tag which shall be attached to the seat of the minibike in a prominent place so as to be visible from the rear. The tag number shall be noted on the registration form. 
3.  The chief of police, or his or her designee, shall be responsible for the custody and maintenance of all registration forms. 
4.  No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any minibike tag or the number which appears thereon. 
D.  Transference of Ownership. Every person who sells or transfers ownership of a registered minibike shall report such sale or transfer to the township clerk and shall return the minibike tag issued for such minibike. 
(Prior code § 3-8.3) 
10.28.040 - Use and operation of minibikes. 
    The following regulations shall apply in the use and operation of minibikes: 
A.  No person shall operate a minibike on the private property of another without the express written permission to do so by the owner of such property. 
B.  No person shall operate a minibike on any public street located within the township. 
C.  No person shall operate a minibike on public grounds without express written permission to do so by the chief of police. 
D.  No person shall operate a minibike in a manner so as to create loud, unnecessary, or unusual noise so as to disturb or interfere with the peace and quiet of other persons. 
E.  No person shall operate a minibike in a careless, reckless, or negligent manner so as to endanger, or be likely to endanger, the safety of any person or the property of any person. 
(Prior code § 3-8.4) 
10.28.050 - Impounding of minibikes. 
A.  Display of Minibike Tag Required. Any minibike which is used or operated and which does not display a minibike tag issued pursuant to this chapter shall be impounded by police and shall be stored in such a place as is designated by the chief of police. 
B.  Reclamation of Impounded Minibikes. The owner of any minibike so impounded may reclaim such upon proof of compliance with the provisions of this chapter and upon payment of all costs and charges incurred by the township for towing and storage of the minibike. The chief of police is authorized to prepare a schedule of costs and charges for towing and storage. Such schedule shall become effective upon publication and filing with the office of the township clerk. Any modifications to the schedule shall be accomplished in a like manner. 
C.  Police Record. When a minibike is impounded, the police department shall keep and maintain a record which shall contain, where possible, the color, make, model, year and serial number. These records shall also include the date and hour of impoundment, the location from which impounded, the reason for impoundment, the name of the impounding officer, and the location at which the minibike is stored. 
(Prior code § 3-8.6) 
10.28.060 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  Violations by Minors. Any person, under the age of eighteen (18) years, who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be, for the first offense, reprimanded in writing by the police department. Such writing shall be addressed to the parents or guardian of the offender and shall state the nature of the violation. Upon a second or subsequent violation of this chapter, a summons shall be issued to appear in municipal court and, upon conviction, the offender shall be punished by the payment of a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
B.  Violations by Adults. Any person, eighteen (18) years of age or older, who shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by the payment of a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment for ten (10) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 3-8.5) 
Chapter 10.32 - OFF-ROAD VEHICLES 

10.32.010 - Findings. 
A.  The township committee deems it necessary and proper for the good government, order and protection of persons and property, and for the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare of the township and its inhabitants to enact an ordinance regulating the operation of snowmobiles, motorcycles, motorized bikes and other two, three and/or four wheel motor powered off-road type vehicles on private property with the township. 
B.  Such regulation is considered necessary and proper to regulate the operation of snowmobiles, motorcycles, motorized bikes and other two, three and/or four wheel motor powered off-road type vehicles on private property when such vehicles are being used for recreational purposes or other nonfarm purposes. 
(Prior code § 3-13.1) 
10.32.020 - Use over private property restricted. 
    The operation of any snowmobile motorcycle or motorized bike, as defined by the applicable provisions of Title 39 of the New Jersey Statutes, and the operation of any other two, three and/or four wheel motor powered off-road type vehicle, hereinafter referred to as subject vehicles, by any person, whether or not that person is the owner of such subject vehicle, over and/or across the private property of another is expressly prohibited, unless the operator thereof has, in his or her possession and on his or her person, written consent or permission of the owner or user of the private property to be affected for the operation of the subject vehicle over and/or across such private property. 
(Prior code § 3-13.2) 
10.32.030 - Display of written consent. 
    Failure to produce written consent or permission upon demand by any police officer of the township shall be presumptive evidence in any court of competent jurisdiction of operating the subject vehicle without the written consent or permission of the owner or user of the private property affected as required by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 3-13.3) 
10.32.040 - Enforcement. 
    Any police officer of the township shall enforce this chapter on the basis of personal observation or investigation or on the basis of a signed complaint, under oath, of any owner or user of private property affected by a violation of this chapter, and such police officer shall issue the appropriate summon(es) to effectuate such enforcement and may impound the subject vehicle as more fully provided by Section 10.32.050. 
(Prior code § 3-13.4) 
10.32.050 - Impounding of vehicle. 
    Any subject vehicle which is used or operated in violation of this chapter shall be subject to impoundment by any police officer of the township and shall be stored in such a place as is designated by the chief of police until such time as the owner of the subject vehicle so impounded makes payment to the township for all costs and charges incurred by the township in the towing and storage of the impounded subject vehicle, and until such further time as adequate restitution has been made to the aggrieved owner or user of the private property so affected for damages to property caused by the operation of the subject vehicle in violation of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 3-13.5) 
10.32.060 - Exception. 
    It is not intended that the prohibitions contained in this chapter be applicable to any subject vehicles being operated for legitimate farming purposes. 
(Prior code § 3-13.6) 
10.32.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate or fail to comply with this chapter, upon conviction in the municipal court, shall be punished by the payment of a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment in jail for a term not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 3-13.7) 
Chapter 10.36 - ROTARY TOWING OF VEHICLES 

10.36.010 - Rotary list. 
    The township committee shall establish rates for towing certain vehicles within the township as well as certain qualifying rules and regulations for the awarding of towing contracts in accordance with NJSA 40:48-2.49 as well as storage fees in accordance with NJSA 40:48-50. The contract shall be awarded after notice of advertisement for tow contract to be published by the township. The services provided by the tow contractor shall be evenly divided between the contractors with each contractor providing his or her services for a two-week interval beginning on Sunday at 12:00 and concluding fourteen (14) days later on Saturday at 11:59 p.m. The contractor shall rotate and there shall be only two contractors for the township. It shall be the responsibility of the chief of police to be certain that the dispatching personnel are familiar with the chapter and provide a schedule of contractors to contact. The tow contractors list will be valid from January 1 to December 31 of each calendar year and no tow companies are permitted to be added to the schedule during that time unless a vacancy exists. The rotary list is from January 1 to December 31. No tow companies are permitted to be added to the schedule during that time unless a vacancy is created. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. 19-2009) 
10.36.020 - Application and approval process. 
    The term of a towing contract shall be one year. Also, applicants must apply on or before December 15 for the following calendar year. The township must advertise for tow contracts along with all professional services which are granted at the reorganization meeting. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. 19-2009) 
10.36.030 - Denial, suspension, revocation, hearings. 
    When an application is denied by the Township of East Greenwich, the applicant may request a hearing on said application by the service of a notice requesting a hearing. Said notice shall be served on the township clerk and at the next regular scheduled meeting of the governing body a hearing date shall be set which shall be no less than seven days nor more than thirty (30) days from the date scheduled. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
10.36.040 - Regulations. 
A.  The police department in general and the chief of police in particular shall enforce the within provisions. 
B.  The chief of police is hereby authorized and empowered to establish from time to time written policies and procedures as may be reasonable and necessary to obtain compliance with the terms of this chapter and the laws of the state of New Jersey. 
C.  All regulations, policies and procedures shall be made available for inspection by the public at the township clerk's office during normal business hours. 
D.  Complaints by motor vehicle owners of any tow contractor shall be referred to the chief of police who shall promptly investigate and resolve any dispute. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
10.36.050 - General requirements. 
A.  The rates applicable to towing services performed hereunder code shall be posted in a conspicuous place, visible to the public at the contractor's place of business. 
B.  The contractor shall, at its expense, prepare a printed bill for distribution to the customer, reflecting the fee to be paid in accordance with the rates stated herein. The bill shall also include a statement to the effect that all complaints shall be referred to the police department. 
C.  Hours of Service. 
1.  Towing services must be provided on a twenty-four- (24-) hour seven-day per week basis. All wreckers must be equipment with two-way communications to facilitate prompt response. It is required that a tow vehicle be on the site of the event within fifteen (15) minutes of the time of the call from the police department. The contractor shall provide the police department with a telephone number which will be operational at all times to quickly dispatch tow vehicles. 
2.  The contractor's normal hours of operation for the public shall be from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and 12:00 noon to 4:00 p.m. on Sunday. 
D.  Employees. 
1.  Contractor shall employ a sufficient number of employees to comply with the minimum operational requirements. 
2.  Contractor shall have conducted the required background check of the employee and confirm that all statutory and regulatory requirement and other requisite criteria have been met. 
3.  All drivers of the contractors shall be over the age of eighteen (18) years and must have a valid current New Jersey State Driver's License, CDL Commercial Driver's License and shall be in good health and of good moral character. 
E.  In order to keep information current, the contractor shall supply an updated list of drivers to the police department. 
F.  All employees of the contractor shall wear uniform clothing with a name patch indicating the employee's first name and the name of the contractor's company. All employees shall be clean, neat and make a good appearance. All employees of contractor shall be required to wear photo identification badges. 
G.  The contractor agrees that the owners or officers of the contractors shall be responsible, except as otherwise provided by law, for the reckless, negligent and/or careless acts of their employees or agents while acting hereunder. 
H.  The contractor shall record all vehicles towed in a book kept for such purposes. The details of each disabled vehicle towed, serviced or transported together with full information of the towed vehicle and name and address of the owner and the charges paid for his services. Full information of the towed vehicle shall include, but not be limited to, the vehicle's license number, VIN registration number, make, model, color and year. The record book herein described shall be kept open for inspection and at all times by any duly authorized representative of the township. A monthly towing record containing the information herein stated above shall be filed with the Township of East Greenwich police department and office of the township clerk setting forth the details of all tows by vehicle type, date, time of day, sector and whether additional services were required. Each incident shall be reported using the invoice number used for billing. The form of these reports shall be approved by the chief of police. 
I.  The contractors shall maintain a record of all personal property in a towed vehicle that are observed in sight at the time the vehicle comes into possession. 
J.  Authorized representatives of the township shall have access to any of the records required to be kept by the contractor. 
K.  Towing contractors shall have a designated inside storage facility for purposes of police investigations. 
L.  It shall be the responsibility to the contractor to label all vehicles that are towed for the police department by labeling either the windshield or some visible part of the vehicle that will identify a police investigation. This information will be supplied by the investigating officer. No vehicles will be released unless there is written authorization from the police department to the contractor for release. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. 19-2009) 
10.36.060 - Equipment. 
A.  The contractor must provide with its application a detailed listing of the equipment to be utilized while on the towing list. The listing shall include the following information: type of vehicle, storage location(s) of vehicles and whether vehicle is owned or leased. Each piece of the equipment must meet the minimum standards set forth herein. Equipment that cannot meet these minimum standards shall not be used for the rotary list. The contractor is solely responsible for the safety, maintenance, and operation of each piece of equipment utilized while on the rotary list. The contractor shall provide a minimum of equipment to handle multi vehicle collisions involving passenger vehicles, heavy equipment and/or trucks. 
B.  The towing contractor shall supply manufacturer's certification of the lifting capacities of the devices of type of vehicle with application submission. A certified testing laboratory test result is also acceptable for rating lift capacity. 
C.  Tow vehicles shall be equipped with two-way radios for communications with contractor's office facilities. These communications shall be available twenty-four (24) hours a day. 
D.  Tow vehicles shall be equipped at all times with safety vests for operations, first-aid kits, hand tools, lockout kits, flashlight, broom, shovel, work gloves and receipts for services rendered. 
E.  Tow vehicles shall be kept in a clean and neat appearance so as to be reasonably accommodating to a person who may come in contact with such vehicle and if stored, storage shall be in a six foot high chain linked area with locking gates and monitored cameras. 
F.  Tow vehicles shall have the name, address, and telephone number of the contractor painted on or permanently attached to both sides of the tow vehicle in compliance with Motor Vehicle and Traffic Laws of New Jersey (Title 39 of the Revised Statutes). 
G.  All tow vehicles shall be properly permitted by the state of New Jersey for the use of flashing amber emergency lights. Permits shall be in compliance with Motor Vehicle and Traffic Laws as referenced above. 
H.  All tow vehicles shall be registered in the name of the contractor in compliance with Motor Vehicle and Traffic Laws as referenced above. Applicant must have the capabilities to tow commercial vehicles with the maximum gross vehicle weight of eighty thousand (80,000) pounds. Applicant must have the capabilities to tow a minimum of three vehicles at the same time. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. 19-2009) 
10.36.070 - Towing and storage fee schedule. 
    The following fees are established as being the usual, customary and reasonable rates which shall be charged for towing and storage of automobile defined as basic towing services. 
A.  Towing services provided within the Township to destinations within the Township shall be:

10.36.080 - Fees-General. 
A.  There shall be no additional charges, other than those provided in the fee schedule, including, but not limited to, for the use of the extra required equipment in tow vehicles, flat bedding, waiting time, winching, up-riding, clean-up costs and additional labor. 
B.  The above towing charges shall not apply when the operator of the vehicle elects either a specific tower or to be towed to a destination other than the designated storage facility. In such cases, the towing charges shall be mutually agreed upon between the operator of the vehicle and the towing contractor. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
10.36.090 - Insurance. 
    Towing contractors shall be required to purchase, maintain and provide during the time of service on the rotary list, proof of insurance, including the certificate(s) furnished by a reputable insurance company licensed to do business in the state of New Jersey, containing the following coverage with liability limits as set forth below: 
A.  Garage liability/comprehensive general liability insurance policy in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit covering bodily injury and property damage liability including, but not limited to, personal injury, products liability (where applicable), independent contractor and completed operation coverage. 
B.  Garage keepers legal liability insurance policy in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). Such policy must include both comprehensive and collision, and an endorsement to include "On Hook." 
C.  Automobile liability insurance policy in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit covering bodily injury and property damage liability including, but not limited to, owned, non-owned and hired vehicles. 
D.  Worker's compensation insurance as required by law, including, but not limited to statutory New Jersey Worker's Compensation Benefits and Employers Liability of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
E.  Excess Umbrella Liability. In the event that garage liability and/or automobile liability cannot be purchased up to the required one million dollar ($1,000,000.00) limit, an excess liability or umbrella liability policy must be purchased to effect a total liability limit of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). Excess or umbrella liability policies will not be required for garage keepers policies that meet or exceed the one hundred thousand dollar ($100,000.00) minimum limit. 
F.  The garage liability and automobile liability policies shall name the Township of East Greenwich as an additional insured and certificate holder. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002) 
10.36.100 - Indemnity. 
    The contractor shall execute an agreement to hold harmless, indemnify and defend, at contractors' expense, the township, its employees and officials from any and all claims, demands, suit or action for personal injury or property damage brought against the township, its employees and officials for any activities which arise out of any services performed hereunder. 
(Ord. 2-2002 (part), 2002)

Chapter 10.42 - TRAFFIC CONTROL WORK ZONES 

10.42.010 - Adoption. 
    The township committee hereby finds and declares that problems of traffic control occur when traffic must be moved through or around street construction, maintenance operations and utility work, both above and below ground, which requires the blocking of roadways and obstructing the safe flow of traffic, and that such obstructions are or can become dangerous when not properly controlled. In order to better promote the public health, safety, peace and welfare, it is necessary to establish controls and regulations directed to the safe and expeditious movement of traffic through construction and maintenance zones and to provide safety for the work force performing these operations. 
    The Township of East Greenwich in the County of Gloucester, and State of New Jersey, does hereby adopt the current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, hereby known as (M.U.T.C.D.), except as hereby supplemented and amended, as it controls and regulates whenever construction, maintenance operations or utility work obstructs the normal flow of traffic. A person, contractor or utility failing to comply with the provisions of M.U.T.C.D. while performing such work is in violation of this section. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.020 - Pre-construction meeting. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the person, contractor or in the case of a public utility as required under the public utility agreement, wishing to conduct work within, under or above the roadway to contact the office of the chief of police for East Greenwich Township in order to arrange a pre-construction meeting to submit plans for the safe movement of traffic during such period of construction work. Any person, contractor or utility failing to comply with this section prior to the start of such work or whose plan is not approved by the chief of police is in violation of this section. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.030 - Hazardous conditions. 
    The person, contractor or utility shall provide the police department with at least two emergency contact phone numbers to be called in case of any problems occurring at the construction site or maintenance site during off-hours or prior to the start of any work. If for any reason emergency contact cannot be made, or emergency contact personnel fail to respond to the call from the police department, to correct the hazardous condition, the township may respond to correct such hazardous condition. Reasonable fees for such service by the township shall be charged to the person, contractor or utility responsible for such conditions. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.040 - Hours of operation. 
    There shall be no construction, maintenance operations or utility work on any roadway in the Township of East Greenwich prior to the hour of 7:00 AM or after 5:00 PM. This time limit may be adjusted by the chief of police to permit work prior to or after the stated times, if reasonable conditions apply and only after thorough review of a request to modify working hours. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.050 - Road closings and detours. 
    Road closings and/or traffic detours shall not be permitted unless approved by the East Greenwich Township police department. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.060 - Traffic directors. 
    Traffic directors shall be posted at all construction or maintenance sites when determined by the East Greenwich Township police department that same is necessary to provide for the safe and expeditious movement of traffic. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.070 - Stop work. 
    The East Greenwich Township police department shall have the authority to stop work, including the removal of equipment and vehicles, stored material within the street right-of-way, back filling of open excavations and/or other related work, in order to abate any nuisance and/or safety hazard or for any violation of this section. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.080 - Site preparation. 
    No materials, vehicles or equipment are to be placed in the roadway or sidewalk area until all construction signs, lights, devices and pavement markings are installed. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
10.42.090 - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, contractor or utility who commits a violation of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof pay a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or may be imprisoned in the county jail for a term not exceeding ninety (90) days or both. 
    A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day or on which each violation occurs or continues to occur. 
(Ord. 23-2003 (part)) 
Chapter 10.44 - CROSSWALKS 

10.44.010 - Mid-block crosswalks. 
    The following locations are established as mid-block crosswalks: 
Name of Street Location Quaker Road Beginning at a point 135 feet east of the easterly curbline of Stone Ridge Drive and extending to a point ten feet easterly therefrom.  
    The signs and markings for this mid-block crosswalk shall be installed pursuant to the current edition of the "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways," Part 7, entitled "Traffic Controls for School Areas." 
(Ord. 4-2006) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapter 12.04 - STREETS AND ROADS GENERALLY 

12.04.010 - Township road defined. 
    The term "township road" shall mean the full width of the road, meaning and intending the traveled portion, the shoulder, the slopes, up to and including the right-of-way line. 
(Prior code § 9-2.1) 
12.04.020 - Regulations. 
    It is unlawful for any person without first obtaining a written permit from the township committee to: 
A.  Tear up, excavate, or otherwise injure or destroy any portion of a road under the control of the township committee; 
B.  Drive upon any township road with any vehicle or farm implement which injures or tears up the surface or shoulder, or which in any way damages any township road or any portion thereof; 
C.  Obstruct, injure, damage or destroy any gutter, sidewalk, shoulder or slope of any township road; 
D.  Throw or cause to be thrown or placed upon any township road, trash, stones, dirt or other materials, other than for the purpose of constructing, repairing and maintaining township roads; 
E.  Discharge or drain, or permit or cause to be discharged or drained, upon any township road any liquid or material such as sewage, wash water, drainage from any pig pen, barn yard, gas station, or other place where the fluid or liquid discharged constitutes waste material; 
F.  Cause any material, fluid or substance to be on any township road which impedes or obstructs or makes dangerous the traffic thereon; 
G.  Application shall be made to the township engineer who shall fix the amount of bond to be filed by the applicant with the township clerk; 
H.  The application fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00) to be paid to the township clerk; 
I.  Permits shall be issued by township clerk upon approval of township engineer; 
J.  The township engineer is authorized to approve issuance of emergency permit with permit to be obtained after correcting the emergency; 
K.  Discharge or drain or permit or cause to be discharged or drained, upon any township road or country road, any liquid that either causes deterioration to the road or creates a hazardous driving condition; however, such shall not be a violation under this chapter unless the property owner has first received written notice from the township committee to cease and desist such activity to which the order shall be effective within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice unless otherwise stated within the notice. 
(Prior code § 9-2.2) 
12.04.030 - Street opening regulations. 
A.  No person shall cause any part or portion of a street, road or right-of-way under control of the township committee to be opened, excavated or altered for the purpose of installing, repairing or maintaining any utility without first having obtained a permit from the township. 
B.  The application shall first be submitted to the township engineer for review and recommendation as to street rehabilitation and sufficiency of bond. No permit shall be granted until all of the pertinent facts have been presented to the township committee at an authorized meeting, at which time the township shall approve the issuance of a permit before it may be issued. Upon approval, applicant shall pay a fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
C.  In order to obtain a permit, the applicant shall submit a sketch of the area to be opened, excavated or altered, setting forth the exact dimensions to be disturbed. In addition thereto, a bond shall be posted in any amount recommended by the engineer, sufficient to guarantee the restoration of the street to a condition as close as is practicable to the condition of the street before it was disturbed. 
D.  The applicant shall submit to the township engineer a list of the materials to be used to restore the street to its condition. 
E.  The bond to be posted shall not be released until the engineer has certified to the township committee that the street has been restored to an acceptable condition. 
F.  In lieu of a bond, the applicant may submit cash or a certified check. 
G.  In the event of an emergency, the applicant may obtain the approval of the township engineer or the township committee-person responsible for roads; however, all other aspects of this section shall be satisfied as quickly as is practicable. 
(Ord. No. 3-2013, 3-12-2013; Ord. 27-2008; Prior code § 9-2.4) 
12.04.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person shall be deemed to violate the terms of this chapter if he or she does any of the acts prohibited herein or causes the acts by means of an agent and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisonment for a period not exceeding fifteen (15) days, or both. 
(Prior code § 9-2.3) 
Chapter 12.08 - PARK AND RECREATION AREA USE REGULATIONS 

12.08.010 - Intent. 
    The township has attempted to provide certain areas within the township that are set out for recreational use. It is the intention of the township to provide these facilities and maintain the order and dignity for the usage of same that is in keeping with the inhabitants of the township. By establishing certain rules and regulations, it is believed that the parks and recreational areas will afford the inhabitants a safe, sanitary and wholesome location for recreational purposes. 
(Prior code § 3-9.1) 
12.08.020 - Hours of usage. 
    All areas designated within the township as parks or recreational areas shall be open from the hours of nine a.m. until five p.m., except during daylight savings time, when the closing hours shall be eight-thirty p.m. However, when there are organized games or events illuminated by the park lights, the park closing time shall be one hour after the conclusion of the event or game. 
(Prior code § 3-9.2) 
12.08.030 - (Reserved). 
12.08.040 - Prohibitions. 
    Hunting, trapping, camping, swimming, littering, use of trail or minibikes, burning an open fire, unless authorized by the township committee, the use of alcoholic beverages, the possession of alcoholic beverages, vandalism or destruction to any township property or being in the park or recreational area other than during the designated hours shall be a violation and subject to the penalty provisions set forth hereinafter. 
    Smoking or the use of tobacco related products, and/or discard of those products, in an area designated as "Tobacco Free", or within fifty (50) feet of any park and/or recreation area owned, leased or utilized by the Township of East Greenwich and/or the youth sports organizations of the Township of East Greenwich. 
(Ord. 18-2002 (part); prior code § 3-9.4) 
12.08.050 - Open fires. 
    There shall be no open fires unless an application has been made to the township committee and permission granted by that body. The application shall set forth the purpose of the open fire as well as the exact date and time to which permission is sought for the open fire. Authorization shall not be for more than one day. 
(Prior code § 3-9.5) 
12.08.055 - Tennis courts-Prohibition of other activities. 
A.  Prohibition of other activities. The tennis courts located at the intersection of Democrat and Harmony Roads in the township of East Greenwich shall be used for the playing of tennis only. No other activities whatsoever, including, but not limited to, skateboarding, roller skating, hockey, basketball or any other activities, are permitted there. 
B.  Sentencing Provisions. Any person convicted of violating the ordinance codified in this section may be fined by the court in an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or be subject to imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days, or perform community service not to exceed thirty (30) days, or any combination thereof. In addition to the foregoing, any person convicted of violating the ordinance codified in this section may be ordered by the court to make full restitution to the township for any damage to the tennis courts caused by the defendant. 
(Ord. 18-04 § 1) 
12.08.060 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any person violating a provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
    Anyone under the age of eighteen (18) convicted of violating the "Tobacco Free" provision shall be required to perform community service and pay court costs. 
(Ord. 18-2002 (part); prior code § 3-9.6) 
Chapter 12.12 - MUNICIPAL OPEN SPACE, RECREATION AND FARMLAND AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION TRUST FUND 

12.12.010 - Annual levy. 
    The township imposes an annual levy in the sum of three cents per one hundred dollars ($100.00) assessed valuation per year to establish a municipal open space, recreation, and farmland and historic preservation trust fund and shall determine the appropriation of the raised revenue by conducting at least one public hearing thereon, for any or all of the following purposes, or any combination thereof: 
A.  Acquisition of lands for recreational and conservation purposes; 
B.  Development of lands acquired for recreation and conservation purposes; 
C.  Maintenance of lands acquired for recreation and conservation purposes; 
D.  Acquisition of farmland for farmland preservation purposes; 
E.  Historic preservation of historic properties, structures, facilities, sites, areas, or objects and the acquisition of such properties, structures, facilities, sites, areas, or objects for historic preservation purposes; 
F.  Payment of debt service on indebtedness issued or incurred by the municipality for any of the aforesaid purposes except for subsection C of this section. 
(Ord. 13-1998; Ord. No. 30-2003, § 1, 12-30-2003) 
Chapter 12.20 - SHADE TREE COMMISSION 
Section: 

12.20.010 - Creation; composition; appointment; compensation. 
    There is hereby created a Shade Tree Commission consisting of not less than three and not more than five members, who shall be residents of the township, which commission shall be known as the "Shade Tree Commission of the Township of East Greenwich", and shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve without compensation except as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 1) 
12.20.020 - Jurisdiction of the commission. 
    The Shade Tree Commission of the Township of East Greenwich shall have jurisdiction over the planting, care, control, and removal of shade and ornamental trees and shrubbery upon and in the streets, highways, public places, parks and parkways of the township; except state highways, unless the state highway department shall assent thereto; and except county highways, parks and parkways of Gloucester now or hereinafter has a county shade tree commission, unless the county shade tree commission shall assent thereto. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 2) 
12.20.030 - Terms. 
    The commission shall be appointed within sixty (60) days from the final passage of this chapter [March 10, 2009], and their terms shall commence upon the day of their appointments and be for the respective periods of three, four, and five years counted from January 1 next succeeding their appointment. All subsequent appointments, except to fill vacancies, shall be for the full term of three years, to take effect on January 1 nest succeeding such appointments. In event that the membership of any commission is increased, the new members shall be appointed in such manner that the terms shall expire in accordance with the foregoing. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 3) 
12.20.040 - Organization. 
    The commission shall organize within thirty (30) days after the appointment of its total membership for the remainder of the then-calendar year and thereafter annually by the election of one of its members as chairman and the appointment of a secretary. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 4) 
12.20.050 - Powers. 
    The shade tree commission of the township shall have power to: 
A.  Exercise full and exclusive control over the regulation, planting, care and/or removal of shade and ornamental trees and shrubbery now located or which may hereinafter be planted in any public highway, park or parkway. 
B.  Regulate and control the use of the ground surrounding same so far as may be necessary for their proper growth, care and protection. 
C.  Move or require the removal of any tree or part thereof dangerous to public safety. 
D.  Care for and control such parks and parkways; encourage arboriculture; and make, alter, amend and repeal, in the manner prescribed for the passage, alteration, amendment and repeal of ordinances by the governing body of the municipality, any and all ordinances necessary or proper for carrying out the provisions hereof. 
E.  Administer treatment to or remove any tree situate[d] upon private property which is believed to harbor a disease or insects readily communicable to neighboring healthy trees in the care of the municipality and enter upon private property for that purpose, with the consent of the owner thereof, provided that the suspected condition is first confirmed by certificate issued by or on behalf of the department of agriculture. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 5) 
12.20.060 - Cost of trees and improvements. 
A.  Except as hereinafter provided, the initial cost of all trees planted by the commission, the cost of planting the same, the cost of the posts and boxes or guards used for the protection thereof and the cost of the removal of any tree or part thereof dangerous to public safety shall, if the commission shall so determine, in accordance with uniform rules and regulations promulgated for this purpose, be a charge upon the real estate in front of which such tree or trees shall be planted or removed as an improvement thereof. Such cost, if it is so determined that it is to be paid by the owner, shall, unless paid directly to the commission, be certified by it to the collector of taxes of the municipality, shall thereupon become and be a lien upon said real estate, shall be included in the next tax bill rendered to the owner or owners thereof and be collected in the same manner as other taxes against that property. 
B.  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
1.  A planting to replace a tree or trees theretofore planted by the commission. 
2.  A planting in connection with Arbor Day exercises or other educational demonstration. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 6) 
12.20.070 - Public improvements affecting trees; consent of commission; county park commissions unaffected. 
    No statute giving any person or state, county or municipal board, body or official power or authority to lay any sidewalk along, or to open, construct, curb or pave any street, or to do any similar act, shall be construed to permit or authorize any interference with or injury to a highway shade tree without the consent of the shade tree commission within whose jurisdiction such tree shall be located. In all cases, such commission shall reasonably cooperate with such person, board, body or official for the general public good. Nothing contained in this chapter shall be held to take away or diminish any of the powers or authority of the county park commission over the trees or shrubbery in any county park or parkway within its jurisdiction, or to give any other commission or board any power or authority with respect to such trees or shrubbery. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 7) 
12.20.080 - Annual appropriation. 
A.  During the month of December in each year, the Shade Tree Commission of the Township of East Greenwich shall certify to the governing body of the municipality the estimated sum necessary for the proper conduct of its work during the ensuing fiscal year, which shall include the sums estimated to be expended for such of the following items as it is anticipated expenditure will be made: 
1.  Payment of wages and salaries of employees. 
2.  Expenses of commission members in discharging official duties, including expenses incident to attendance at professional meetings. 
3.  Purchase of trees and shrubbery. 
4.  Purchase of necessary equipment and material and the cost of services for the prudent promotion of the work. 
B.  The Township Committee of the Township of East Greenwich shall annually appropriate such sums as it may deem necessary for said purposes. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 8) 
12.20.090 - Regulations of commission. 
    No person shall do any of the following acts to shade any ornamental trees [to any ornamental shade trees] and shrubbery upon and in the streets, highways, public places, parks and parkways of the township except state highways, unless the state highway department shall assent thereto and except county highways, parks and parkways if Gloucester now or hereafter has a county shade tree commission, unless the county shade tree commission shall assent thereto, without the prior approval of the shade tree commission. 
A.  Cut, prune, climb with spikes, break, damage, remove or kill. 
B.  Cut, disturb or interfere in any way with any root. 
C.  Spray with any chemical.
