D.  Fasten any rope, wire, sign or other device. (Nothing herein shall prevent any governmental agency from affixing in a manner approved by the shade tree commission a public notice upon a tree in connection with administering governmental affairs.) 
E.  Remove or damage any guard or device placed to protect any tree or shrub. 
F.  Conduct razing, removal or renovation of any structure if deemed, by the commission, to be damaging to neighboring street trees. 
G.  Place or distribute chemicals, including but not limited to salt, deleterious to tree health. 
H.  Maintain a stationary fire or device which vaporizes noxious fumes deleterious to tree health. 
I.  Remove soil, either for trenching or otherwise. 
J.  Construct new sidewalks and/or driveways with any material whatsoever within five feet of a tree. 
K.  Plant any tree or shrub within the designated area under the control of the commission. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 9) 
12.20.100 - Penalty for violation of commission ordinances; jurisdiction of courts. 
A.  The commission may prescribe a fine for the violation of its ordinances in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation, and the Municipal Court of East Greenwich shall have jurisdiction over actions for the violation of such ordinances, and its ordinances shall be enforced by like proceedings and process as that provided by law for the enforcement of ordinances of this municipality. The officers authorized by law to serve and execute process for the municipal court of this municipality shall be the officers to serve and execute any process issued out of the municipal court for violations of the ordinances of the commission. 
B.  In addition to the penalties authorized by subsection A., the commission may require a person who removes or otherwise destroys a tree in violation of a municipal ordinance to pay a replacement assessment to the municipality. The replacement assessment shall be the value of the tree as determined by the appraisal of a trained forester or certified tree expert retained by the commission for that purpose. 
C.  Any public utility or cable television company that clears, moves, cuts, or destroys any trees, shrubs, or plants for the purpose of erecting, installing, moving, removing, altering or maintaining any structure or fixtures necessary for the supply of electric light, heat, power communications, or cable television services upon any lands in which it has acquired an easement or right-of-way shall not be subject to any penalty imposed by a commission pursuant to subsection A. or B. This subsection shall not exempt any public utility or cable television company from any penalty or replacement assessment imposed for negligent actions. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 10) 
12.20.110 - Disposition of penalties. 
    All money collected, either as fines or penalties, for any violation of a rule or regulation of the Shade Tree Commission of the Township of East Greenwich or as a charge against real estate as provided by law shall be forthwith paid over to the township treasurer. 
(Ord. 1-2009, § 11) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER SERVICE SYSTEM 

13.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Applicant" means a petitioner to the township committee requesting potable water service. 
    "Customer" means the applicant or use of water service at one household or business, whether tenant or owner. 
    "Lateral" means the service line piping and appurtenances extending from the distribution main to the user's premises. 
    "Main" means the township owned or leased piping and appurtenances, in or along public streets or highways, or in or along township rights-of-way or easements, used for the transmission or distribution of water. 
(Prior code § 10-1) 
13.04.020 - Laterals. 
A.  Installation and Maintenance. The installation of the lateral from the main to and including the curb shut-off shall be the responsibility of the customer. The township shall be responsible for maintenance of the lateral from the main to the street side of the curb shut-off. The installation and maintenance of the lateral, from connection at the curb shut-off to the premises served shall be the responsibility of the customer. 
    The lateral installation shall be completed by a licensed plumber and shall include all road opening permits, excavation and restoration for a complete installation. The construction materials and installation shall be inspected and approved by the township water superintendent who shall be notified at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of construction. All construction work shall be done during normal township business hours. 
    For the extension of new water mains, the installation of the lateral from the main to and including the curb shut-off shall be the responsibility of the party constructing such extension, whether it be the applicant or the township. 
B.  Construction Materials. Laterals shall be copper (K-type or ductile iron cement-mortar lined-class 52) installed to provide suitable connection to meters. 
    In the event that the house to be connected is situated more than two hundred (200) feet back from the property line where the water supply originates, then a State Building Code approved plastic pipe may be used in lieu of copper. All pipes shall be installed to provide suitable connection to meters. 
    Water service pipe at point of entrance to the building shall be made of copper tube or copper pipe. Copper tube when used underground shall not be less the "K". 
    In those cases where a qualified owner elects to use and install plastic pipes as per the preceding paragraphs, the township shall place the meter at the property line where the supply originates. 
C.  Renewal of Laterals. If the renewal of a lateral from the main to the curb stop or meter pit is found to be necessary by the township committee, the lateral shall be renewed in the same location as previously used. If the customer desires the lateral at some other location, and agrees to pay any additional expense of such relocation, in excess of installing the lateral in the same location as previously used, and cutting off and disconnecting the old lateral, the township committee shall install the new lateral at the location desired. 
D.  Service Lateral Tap Charge. Although there is no tap charge for the extension of existing water mains, there shall be a service lateral tap charge, the amount of which shall be in accordance with the rate schedule hereinafter set forth. 
(Prior code § 10-2) 
13.04.030 - Meters. 
A.  Property of the Township. All meters are and shall become and remain the property of the township and shall at all times be under the control of and subject to inspection of the township committee. 
B.  Installation and Maintenance. The township shall be responsible for supplying and installing all water meters up to one-inch. The material costs for the water meter and readout shall be set by the township and shall be the responsibility of the customer. Additionally, the meter installation fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) which shall be paid prior to installation. All meters one and one-half-inch and longer shall be the customer's responsibility to purchase and install the Neptune T-10 meter. The township shall provide maintenance of the water meter, however, replacements, repairs or adjustments of any nature rendered necessary by the act, neglect or carelessness of the owner or occupant of any premises, or any expense to the township caused thereby shall be charges against and collected from the owner of the premises. 
    The owner of any premise where a meter, curb box and rods are installed shall be responsible for its care and protection from freezing, and from hot water, and from injuries or interferences by any person. In case of any injury to the meter, or in case of its stoppage or imperfect working, the owner shall give immediate notice to the township committee. 
    The owner of a property, where a curb box is installed after March 1, 1997, shall be responsible for having the top of a curb box at ground level visible at all times for accessibility and service. 
C.  Location of Meters. Meters shall be located and fixed in such place or places as the township committee may determine: 
    No person other than the authorized agent or employee of the township committee shall change the location, or alter, or interfere in any way with any meter. 
    Any unauthorized person or persons, other than as described herein, changing the location, altering, interfering or tampering with the meter or the seal affixed thereto shall be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
D.  Testing-Determination of Accuracy. Periodic tests of meters shall be carried under regulations prescribed by the township committee, its authorized agent or employee. If the meter is found to register more than three percent less water than actually passes through it, a new meter may be substituted and the township committee shall adjust the water bill in such a manner as if fair and just. 
    The accuracy of the meter on any premises shall be tested by the township committee upon written request of the owner who shall pay, in advance, a fee of one-hundred dollars ($100.00) for up to one-inch meters and two-hundred dollars ($200.00) for up to two-inch meters to cover the cost of the test. If, on such test, the meter is found to register over three percent more water to the owner than actually passes through it, another meter shall be substituted therefore, and the fee shall be repaid to the owner in such a manner as is fair and just. 
(Prior code § 10-3) 
(Ord. 7-2009, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 7-2013, 6-11-2013; Ord. No. 4-2015, 3-24-2015) 
13.04.040 - Water use regulations. 
A.  Restrictions. No restrictions upon the quantity of water used on any premises from the mains shall be enforced, except as follows: 
1.  No person shall take or use water from the mains from premises other than his or her own, and no person shall sell or give away any water from the mains from his or her own premises for any purpose. 
2.  In time of serious emergency, the committee may limit the use of water. 
3.  Preventable waste shall not be allowed; water will be shut off in case of leaks remaining unrepaired. 
B.  The township committee has the authority to declare a serious emergency and if so declared the township committee may limit the use of water. A declaration of serious emergency must be done by resolution of the township committee and the specific limitations of use of water must be set forth with that resolution. If township committee adopts a resolution declaring a serious emergency as set forth in this section the provisions of that resolution shall supersede the provisions of Section 16.49.020.B until the emergency is over as declared by the township committee. 
C.  Hydrants. Only persons authorized by the committee shall take water from any public fire hydrant or water main appurtenance, except for fire purposes, or for the use of the fire department in case of fire. No water main appurtenances shall be used for any purpose other than fire purposes without first securing the written approval and consent of the committee. 
D.  Automatic fire protective devices and hydrants. For automatic sprinklers or other automatic fire service protective devices located inside a building or buildings, a separate service line will be required, to be used exclusively for fire service. At the option of the customer, fire hydrants located outside of the buildings may be connected to the fire service line. Each such separate service line shall be subject to the charges shown in the rate schedule. The township reserves the right to refuse approval for an application for automatic fire service where, in the judgment of the township, such service is not practical. All meters for private fire service shall be approved by the township, but shall be furnished and installed by the customer. Meters will be set in an approved type of brick or concrete masonry meter vaults, adequately drained, located on the premises of the customer. The meter vaults are to be constructed and maintained at the expense of the customer. Meters and vaults shall at all times be accessible to the township, its officers and employees. 
E.  Private Unmetered Fire Service. When in the judgment of the Township, it is practical, private unmetered fire service lines may be permitted to be installed at the expense of the owner, and shall be subject to the charges shown in the rate schedule. 
(Prior code § 10-4) 
(Ord. No. 17-2010, 8-24-2010; Ord. No. 22-2010, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 8-2013, 6-11-2013) 
13.04.050 - Connections. 
A.  Connections Required. The owners of all buildings now erected, and the owner of every building hereafter erected or acquired, which is located within two hundred (200) feet of any public water supply main and is located upon a street, right-of-way or easement in which a public water supply main is constructed shall be required to connect with that public water supply main within one hundred eighty (180) days of the installation of the public water supply main. 
B.  Failure to Make Connections-Township Installations. Upon installations of a water main, the township committee shall give written notice of installation to every building owner affected by such installation. If the owners of those buildings affected fail to install the required water tie-in connection within one hundred eighty (180) days after such written notice is given, the township committee may cause such water tie-in connection to be made under the direction and supervision of the township engineer. Before proceeding to make any such connection or installation, the township committee shall cause notice of such contemplated connection or installation to be given to the owner of any properties affected thereby. Such notice shall contain a description of the property affected, sufficiently definite in terms of identifying it, as well as a description of the required connections, and notice that unless the connection or installation is completed within thirty (30) days after the service thereof, the township shall proceed to make such connection, or cause same to be done. All written notices shall be served upon the owners or owners' residents in the township, or shall be mailed to any nonresident's last known post office address; notice may also be served upon the occupant of the property, or upon the agent of the owner in charge thereof. If the owner of such property is unknown, or service cannot be made as above directed, notice shall be published at least once, not less than thirty (30) days before the making of such connection by the township, in a newspaper circulated within the township. 
C.  Assessment of Costs. If the property owner fails to make such connections, and the township committee is required to install the water tie-in connection, the cost of such installation shall become a lien upon the property, if the cost remains unpaid by the property owner for thirty (30) days after assessment. Every such connection or installation charge shall bear interest and penalties from the same time and at the same rate as assessments for local improvements in the township where the same are made. 
(Ord. 27-2001; Ord. 24-1996; prior code § 10-5) 
13.04.060 - Service regulations. 
A.  Service Through Existing Connections-Existing Mains. No new service shall be permitted by the township committee unless all current charges for water service have been paid. 
    Where service is extended through an existing lateral and meter providing service to additional improved premises containing one or more kitchens, the constructions code official, prior to issuing a certificate of occupancy shall be provided with an acknowledgment by the water clerk of the necessity for increased billing. Each additional kitchen shall require an additional billing based on the rate schedule for the appropriate size meter. No additional tap fee shall be required. 
B.  New Construction-Existing Mains. 
1.  Certificate of Occupancy. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the construction code official until certification by the appropriate township official has been made indicating that all fees have been paid and that the lateral and meter have been installed in accordance with township rules and regulations. 
2.  Initial Billing Date. The initial billing date of a newly constructed building shall be the date of the certificate of occupancy. 
3.  Connection and Other Fees. All connection and other fees shall be paid prior to any review of the plans by the construction office. 
C.  Service Through Extension of New Mains. Applicants proposing construction which require extension of mains shall submit plans, specifications and supporting data, prepared by professional engineers, licensed by the State of New Jersey to the township committee for approval by the township engineer. The committee shall permit extensions of new mains only when paid for and installed by the applicant. The committee, after construction has been approved by the township engineer, shall require title to new mains be vested in the township by instruments approved by the township solicitor. 
D.  General Requirements-Main Extensions Utilizing Public Roads or Rights-of-Way. Residential subdivisions containing three or fewer building sites, or commercial or industrial buildings deemed by the township committee to be too removed from existing water mains or, in the event the volume of potable water required is greater than capabilities of the township's existing facilities, shall be permitted to provide their own potable water systems provided plans for the on-site potable water system meet the minimum standards promulgated by all appropriate government agencies. 
    Residential subdivisions containing four or more building sites or commercial or industrial buildings, when deemed practical by the committee, shall be required to extend mains and provide connections to the township's water system. 
    During the construction, but before final acceptance, the committee shall have the right of use of any completed portion of the system without waiving its right to further inspection and testing or to order correction of any defects. 
E.  General Requirements-Main Extensions-Private Property. Prior to the installation on private property of any water distribution system to be connected to the township water main, per plans and specifications approved by the township engineer, the applicant shall be required to enter into an easement agreement with the township covering that portion of the land in which the water distribution system will be placed, and, further, the owner shall be required to construction and dedicate the entire water distribution system, upon approval by the township engineer, to the township. Any and all agreements necessary to accomplish the provisions of this subsection shall first meet the approval of the township solicitor. 
F.  Industrial Service. Industrial and commercial establishments making application for water service, in addition to making written application for such services, shall furnish a detailed description of the type and size of buildings, nature of the business to be conducted in each structure and the number and type of fixtures to be served. Such applicants shall also furnish the township committee four copies of plans showing: 
1.  The boundaries of the property; 
2.  The location within the property of the structures to be served; 
3.  The location and profile, with respect to finished grade of the services; 
4.  Details of the proposed connections to the water system, and arrangement and details of meter installation. 
G.  Cost of Administration. The applicant shall post with the township clerk funds to be held in escrow by the clerk for the purposes of paying for review of plans, inspection and testing by the township engineer, legal services as may be required by the township solicitor or other reasonable administrative costs. The township engineer shall provide an estimate of escrow fees required which shall be posted by the applicant prior to the incurring of any administrative costs. The township engineer shall provide an estimate of escrow fees required which shall be posted by the applicant prior to the incurring of any administrative costs. Upon completion of the main extension an accounting shall be made to the applicant of funds expended, and balances due the applicant shall be returned. Should a determination by the township engineer during the construction of the main extension find that the escrow fund is insufficient, the applicant shall supplement the escrow fund as recommended by the township engineer. All payments from the escrow fund shall be on standard voucher forms approved by the township committee in accordance with applicable procedures. 
(Prior code § 10-6) 
13.04.070 - Service charges-Rate schedule. 
A.  Service Charges to be a Lien. All service charges for the use of water shall be a lien against the premises where such service shall be made or water shall be used. In the event that a tenant or person other than the owner occupies the premises, the property shall remain and be liable for such a charge, for service or water consumed on the premises. 
B.  Water for Building or Special Purposes. A supply of water for building or other special purposes, except on a lot or premises already supplied with a metered connection, shall be specially applied for and fees paid as set forth in the rate schedule. All applications for water for building or special purposes shall be formally requested by the owner, or his or her duly appointed agent, and shall be interpreted to mean that the water is to be used from a builder's hydrant, temporarily adapted with a meter. 
C.  Water Rates. The following charges shall be made for all water services rendered in the township as follows: 
1.  a.  Usage. For uses other than commercial uses, there shall be a minimum charge of thirty six dollars and twenty five cents ($36.25) for first ten thousand (10,000) of water used, or portion thereof, and thereafter as follows, rounded up to the nearest thousand gallons: 
Gallons Per 
Thousand 
Gallons 10,001-15,000 $3.20 15,001-20,000 3.70 20,001-25,000 4.90 25,001-37,500 6.40 37,501-50,000 7.35 Over 50,001 8.85  
2.  Water Tap Charges. Water tap charges shall be as follows: 
a.  Three-quarter inch water tap: One thousand four hundred ninety-one dollars ($1,491.00). 
b.  One inch water tap: One thousand nine hundred eighty-nine dollars ($1,989.00). 
c.  In excess of one-inch water tap: One thousand nine hundred eighty-nine dollars ($1,989.00) per each additional inch, or portion thereof, rounded up to the nearest inch. 
d.  Water for temporary tap purposes: two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a 3/4-inch tap, three hundred dollars ($300.00) for a one-inch tap, and three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for a two-inch tap. Water usage rates shall be charged at the rates set forth in subsection (1). Meters for monitoring this usage shall be rented from the township on a monthly basis. Such renters shall be charged the replacement cost for damaged or lost meters. 
e.  Any person who makes an individual water tap on a county road shall also pay the prevailing county road opening fee. 
D.  Meter Readings. Meter readings shall be made quarterly or at such intervals as the township committee may prescribe. 
E.  Billing. Bills shall be rendered quarterly or at such intervals as the township committee may prescribe. 
F.  Termination of Service for Nonpayment. Water may be shut off at the option of the township committee in the event that any bill for services remains unpaid for one month. Service shall not be renewed until arrears and penalties are paid together with a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for shutoff and a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for service restoration. 
    If the property owner requests a shut-off or a turn-on, the fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). 
G.  Reserved. 
H.  Administrative Charges Upon Changes in Ownership. When the title of any property in the water district shall be transferred an administrative fee in the total amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00) shall be payable upon such transfer. 
I.  Revision of Plans-Payment of Fees. All connection and other fees shall be paid prior to any review of plans by the construction office. 
(Ord. 32-2003: prior code § 10-7) 
(Ord. 7-2009, §§ 4-11; Ord. No. 3-2012, §§ 1, 2, 4-28-2012; Ord. No. 4-2015, 3-24-2015; Ord. No. 6-2016, 4-12-2016; Ord. No. 2-2017, 4-11-2017; Ord. No. 7-2017, §§ 1, 2, 12-12-2017) 
13.04.075 - Billing, payment and delinquencies. 
A.  Rendering of Bills for Water Service. A single bill for water services will be rendered quarterly to each customer. 
B.  Payment Schedule. 
1.  Late Payment. If a bill is not paid within thirty (30) days of the date of billing, an interest rate of one and one-half percent per month will be charged. 
2.  Disputed Bill. In the case of a disputed bill terminating substantially in favor of the customer, the payment is due within ten days of the termination of the dispute. 
C.  Delinquent Accounts. 
1.  Unpaid Bills-Discontinuation of Service. Any bill unpaid after thirty (30) days of presentation shall be classified as delinquent. Any bill unpaid after forty-five (45) days of presentation shall be subject to discontinuance of service after not less than five days of written notice. 
2.  Restoration of Service. If service is discontinued for nonpayment of the account, it will not be restored until the fees payable in cash, plus all unpaid charges are paid or satisfactory arrangements have been made for payment, as set forth in section 13.08.140, schedule III. 
3.  Return of Check-Processing Fee. Any individual or entity that submits a check to any department of the Township of East Greenwich which is returned by the bank as unpayable due to insufficient funds being available in the operative account shall be responsible for a fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
4.  Unpaid Balance as Lien. Any unpaid balance of service charges and interest thereon shall be a lien against the property and action shall be initiated pursuant to the procedures specified under NJSA 54:5-1, et seq. 
5.  Notice of Delinquent Charges for Publication. Notice of delinquent charges shall be given annually to the township tax collector thirty (30) days prior to the township posting notice of publishing all delinquent taxes. 
D.  Discontinuance of Service. Service may be discontinued at the sole discretion of the township for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Misrepresentation in application; 
2.  Willful waste of water through improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures or otherwise; 
3.  Destruction or damage to any service pipe or any other appliance of the township; 
4.  Nonpayment of any charge accruing under the application; 
5.  Refusal of reasonable access to the property for purposes of inspecting, reading, repairing or removing meters and/or plumbing; 
6.  Making or refusing to sever any cross connection between a pipe or fixture furnished by the township and a pipe or fixture from any other source; 
7.  Nonpayment of bills within the time prescribed; 
8.  Violation of any rules of the township. 
E.  Renewal Service. Service will be renewed when the conditions under which such service was disconnected are corrected and upon payment of all accrued charges provided in the schedule of rates or rules of the township. 
F.  Deposits. 
1.  Deposits may be required from any customer who becomes habitually delinquent. The amount of the deposit shall be equal to his or her average quarterly bill. 
2.  Any customer having paid a deposit shall pay bills for water service as rendered, in accordance with the rates, rules and regulations of the township. The deposit shall not be considered as payment on account of a bill during the time the customer is receiving service. 
3.  Deposits shall be returned to the depositor when he or she shall have paid undisputed bills for service for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months. 
4.  No interest will be paid on deposits. 
G.  Continuing Obligation to Pay Service Charge. Upon connection of an improved and usable property to water, the obligation to pay the minimal annual service charge continues despite the failure to occupy the property or to use the water facilities, so long as the building or structure on the property is still available for use and the water facilities remain available. 
(Ord. No. 7-2009, § 12; Ord. No. 14-2014, 11-12-2014) 
13.04.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of Sections 13.04.010 through 13.04.070 of this chapter shall be subject to penalties as set forth in Chapter 1.08. If a person is determined to be in such violation, each and every day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior code § 10-8) 
13.04.090 - Water emergency. 
A.  Declaration of Water Emergency. Whenever the township committee shall be satisfied and finds that a water emergency exists in the township, it may adopt a resolution declaring that a water emergency exists in the township. Such resolution shall be adopted by the township committee at a regular, special, adjourned or emergency public meeting of the committee. Such resolution shall identify that portion of the township affected by the water emergency, which may include the entire township, and shall specify which of the water use regulations contained in subsection B of this section is being imposed as well as any exemptions as may be authorized. Such resolution shall be effective immediately upon publication according to law and shall continue in effect for ninety (90) days, unless extended or repealed as set forth in subsection C of this section. 
    For the purposes of this subsection, a water emergency shall exist if, for any of the following reasons: 
1.  The public utility providing water service to all or a portion of the township has adopted water use restrictions, has notified the township, the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection as well as any other state, county or local agency entitled to notice of such restrictions, and such restrictions are not overruled or declared invalid by any state, county or local agency having the jurisdiction and the power to do so; or 
2.  The township committee is otherwise satisfied that a water emergency exists in the township. 
B.  Water Use Restrictions. Upon adoption by the township committee of a resolution declaring that a water emergency exists in the township in accordance with subsection A of this section, all citizens shall be urged to observe voluntary indoor conservation measures and any of the following water use restrictions shall be imposed and shall be applicable to all residents and tenants, except where a bona fide health emergency exists and to exempt businesses as specified herein during the water emergency: 
1.  The complete ban and prohibition of outside water usage, including the watering of lawns and plants, the filling of pools and the washing of cars; 
2.  Outside water usage on alternate days allowing outside water usage by persons or businesses having even house or box numbers on even days and those having odd house or box numbers on odd days with outside water usage being completely banned and prohibited on the thirty-first (31st) day of any month during the water emergency; or 
3.  Any other water use restriction specified by the township committee in the resolution required by subsection A of this section which is reasonable under the circumstances considering the nature and extent of the water emergency. Any water restriction imposed pursuant to this subsection shall be limited in application to that portion of the township, which may include the entire township, identified as being affected by the water emergency in the resolution adopted. 
C.  Duration of Water Use Restrictions. The resolution adopted, in addition to complying with subsection A of this section, shall provide a period of time during which the water use restrictions imposed shall be applicable and which shall be no longer than reasonably necessary to abate the water emergency under the circumstances considering the nature and extent of the water emergency. At the expiration of the time period specified in the resolution, the water use restriction shall lapse and be inapplicable and unenforceable. If the township committee shall be satisfied that the water emergency has been abated prior to the expiration of the time period specified in the resolution, it shall adopt a resolution declaring the water emergency ended and the water use restrictions inapplicable. If, at the expiration of the time period specified in the resolution, the township committee shall be satisfied that the water emergency continues to exist, it may adopt a resolution in accordance with the requirements of this section continuing the water use restrictions. 
D.  Enforcement of Water Use Restrictions-Penalty for First Offense. The water use restrictions imposed pursuant to this section shall be enforced during a water emergency by the local authorized official. 
    The local authorized official is hereby empowered to write summonses for the violation of the water use restrictions imposed pursuant to this section. 
E.  Penalties for Second, Third and Subsequent Offenses. After a first offense, in accordance with subsection D of this section, any person or business who thereafter violates the water use restrictions imposed pursuant to this section shall be fined or imprisoned in accordance with this subsection. 
    For a second offense, the fine imposed shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for ten (10) days, or both. 
    For a third and subsequent offense, the fine imposed shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. 5-2003; prior code § 10-9) 
(Ord. No. 17-2010, 8-24-2010; Ord. No. 22-2010, 10-12-2010) 
Chapter 13.08 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM 

13.08.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the East Greenwich Sewer Department is to foster and promote relief of waters from pollution and abate the menace to public health. These rates, rules and regulations are established for the conduct of the township's business, to cover the use of the sanitary sewer system, to provide a schedule of fees and rates, to outline allowable procedures and whatever else is deemed proper and relevant to operating the township sanitary sewer system. 
(Prior code § 10A-2.1) 
13.08.020 - Office of township and hours of business. 
    The principal office of the township place of business and mailing address is the Township of East Greenwich, 21 East Cohawkin Road, Clarksboro, New Jersey 08020. 
    The office of the township will be open for the purpose of the transaction of regular business during regular business hours each weekday, Monday through Friday, except holidays. 
(Prior code § 10A-2.2) 
13.08.030 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of the terms used in these rules and regulations shall be as follows: 
    "Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days and twenty (20) degrees Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from waste and other wastewater drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer. 
    "Building sewer" means the extension from the building to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection or lateral. 
    "Domestic consumer unit" means a dwelling or structure normally occupied by a single-family and equivalent to a specific flow rate as defined by the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection. 
    "Domestic sewage" means the normal waterborne fluid wastes from residences, commercial establishments, institutions and industrial establishments, limited to the wastes from kitchens, bathrooms, water closets, lavatories and laundries. 
    "Easement" means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    "Floatable oil" means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. The wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    "Garbage" means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
    Garbage, Properly Shredded. "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    "Industrial wastes" means the wastewater from industrial processes, trade or business as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes or sewage. 
    "pH" means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams per liter of solution. Neutral water for example, has a pH value of 7. 
    "Public sewer" means a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
    Sanitary Disposal System, Individual. "Individual sanitary disposal system" means an on-site sewage system by which a residential structure manages the treatment and disposal of its waste. Commercial and industrial structures are specifically exempted. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer that carries liquid and water carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface water that are not admitted intentionally. 
    "Sewage" means the spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater." 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
    "Sewer department" means the East Greenwich Township Sewer Department. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water or wastewater which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five times the average twenty-four (24) hour concentration of flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
    "Storm drain" or "storm sewer" means a drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water or unpolluted water from any source. 
    "Superintendent" means the superintendent or person in charge of wastewater facilities and/or of water pollution control of the township. 
    "Surface grading" means the process by which virgin ground is altered to adjust ground elevation. 
    "Suspended solids" means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods of the Examination of Water and Wastewater", 13th edition of the American Public Health Association, Washington, D.C., 1971, and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
    "Virgin ground" means ground in its natural state. 
    "Wastewater" means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment and processes required to collect, pump and pretreat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
    "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "water pollution control plant". 
    "Water, unpolluted," "Unpolluted water" means water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect for the receiving water or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards. 
(Prior code § 10A-3) 
13.08.040 - Sewer connections required. 
A.  Toilets. The owner of every house, building and structure now erected, and the owner of every house, building and structure hereafter erected or acquired, which may be occupied or used by human beings and is located on a street, road, avenue or other public thoroughfare and is located within three hundred (300) feet of any sanitary sewer now constructed or hereafter constructed in the township or to which sanitary sewer service is available, shall, within one hundred twenty (120) days after written notification install a toilet or toilets in such house, building or structure, unless a toilet or toilets are already installed therein, and connect the sanitary sewage facilities emanating from such house, building or structure to the sanitary sewerage system of the East Greenwich Township Sewer Department. 
    The township committee, in its discretion, may extend the time period for tying into the sewer system. 
B.  Industrial Wastes. If any such house, building or structure referred to in subsection A of this section shall be used for industrial or commercial purposes, the owner thereof, within ninety (90) days of notice of sewer availability of such sanitary sewer to such house, building or structure, or prior to occupancy or use of such house, building or structure, whichever date shall be later, shall install such facilities as are necessary to pretreat and convert the industrial wastes emanating therefrom into a form that may be treated by and is acceptable to the Gloucester County Utilities Authority and the East Greenwich Township Sewer Department. All industrial and commercial wastewaters must comply with all federal, state, county and local requirements. 
C.  New Connections. Where any house, building or structure shall be completed on or after December 8, 1990 and sanitary sewer services shall be available to it, the same shall be connected to the township sanitary sewer system before its use or occupancy for any purpose. 
D.  Cesspools, Septic Tanks and Other Private Wastewater Disposal Facilities. Where any house, building or structure is required to connect and when such connection is made to the sanitary sewerage system of the township in compliance with this chapter, any existing cesspool, seepage pit, septic tanks and similar private wastewater disposal facility shall be cleaned of its contents and filled with suitable material and inspected by the Gloucester County health officer and comply with all New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection abandonment and closure requirements to insure that no public health or safety hazards are in evidence. 
E.  Manual of Rates, Rules and Regulations. The sewer department shall prepare, adopt and publish a manual of rates, rules and regulations for furnishing sanitary sewerage service in the township. 
F.  Failure to Connect. If the owner of any property in the township affected by the terms of this chapter shall fail and neglect to make any sanitary sewer connection or installation of pretreatment as herein provided, the mayor and township committee, by resolution, may authorize proceedings in respect thereof, and after giving notice as therein provided upon expiration of the period prescribed in and by such notice, proceed to have the sanitary sewer connection made and installation of pretreatment made at the expense and cost of the property owner. Upon completion of the work, the cost thereof, including any charges by the township, shall be certified to the township tax collector. 
(Ord. 28-2001; prior code §§ 10A-1.1-10A-1.6) 
13.08.050 - Domestic service. 
A.  New Domestic Customer Service. 
1.  Charges as Municipal Lien. As sewer charges are municipal liens, all charges will be submitted by the sewer department prior to the date of settlement and verified, in writing, to the title company or whichever authorized agent is processing the transfer of property. The title company shall be obligated to clear all sewer charges outstanding on the property. In the event that charges are not paid at settlement, those charges shall remain on the account as a lien against the property. 
2.  Search Fee. The township shall charge a search fee as set forth in Section 13.08.140, Schedule III for sewer on each account. Search fees are due upon presentation. Failure on the part of the title company or the proper authorized agent to pay the search fees within twenty (20) days of presentation will result in the discontinuance of township lien information. 
    Search fees will be charged for information in areas in which there is no existing sewer service. 
3.  Connection and Other Fees. All connection and other fees shall be paid prior to any review of the plans by the construction official. 
4.  Township Approval for Certificate of Occupancy. No township approval will be given to the building inspector for issuance of a certificate of occupancy until the sewer department has certified that the sewer lateral systems have been installed in accordance with the township sewer department's rates, rules and regulations. 
5.  New Fixtures. Under no circumstances shall any new fixture be installed in a building or dwelling at an elevation lower than the front curb elevation or the street centerline elevation, whichever is higher. The installation of an accessible check valve system with a gate valve between the check valve and the curb is mandatory for all customers requesting such new fixture installation to prevent surcharging of the new fixture installation from the sanitary sewer main because of high flow or blockage. Such installation is at the expense of the customer who is subsequently deemed owner of the installed facilities. All customers are deemed to be responsible for its maintenance. The township is indemnified and held harmless by the customer from any liability resulting from the malfunctioning of any fixture or required installation under this subdivision. 
6.  Initial Billing Date of Newly Constructed Home. The initial billing date of a newly constructed home will be the date of the certificate of occupancy or the date of settlement, whichever is first. 
B.  Garbage Disposals. Garbage disposals will be billed at an annual rate in addition to the normal sewer charge set forth in Section 13.08.140, Schedule II. Charge for the disposal will continue until the customer has notified the township of the removal of the disposal and a house verification by the township has been made. Routine house inspections will be made by the township to determine the existence of garbage disposal systems and the customer will be billed for the disposal as of his or her last billing date preceding the inspection. 
C.  Landlord-Tenant Responsibility. All charges for sewer are a lien against the property and therefore the responsibility of the owner. If the landlord requests in a letter that the bills be sent to the tenant, the township, at its discretion, may oblige after informing the landlord that the final responsibility for any unpaid charges is the responsibility of the owner of the property and subsequent charges will be billed to the owner. 
D.  Discontinuation of Customer Service. In the event that a sewer lateral service will be permanently discontinued, the township shall be notified, in writing, that the service billing shall be terminated. The sewer lateral shall be permanently sealed watertight in a manner subject to the approval of the township engineer or superintendent. 
E.  Inspection of Riser Cap. When the township inspection indicates that a riser cap is missing or damaged, the customer will be notified that the cap must be repaired or replaced within seven days. After that time period the township will replace or repair the riser cap and the customer will be charged for parts and service. 
(Prior code § 10A-4) 
13.08.060 - Industrial service. 
A.  Application Required. Industrial and commercial establishments making application for sanitary sewer service, in addition to making written application for such service, shall furnish a detailed description of the type and size of buildings, the nature of the business to be conducted in each structure, the number and type of fixtures to be serviced and the type, volume and chemical characteristics of the waste to be discharged. Such applicants shall also furnish the township with four copies of twenty-four (24) inch by thirty-six (36) inch or thirty-six (36) inch by forty-two (42) inch plans showing at scale no less than one inch equals one hundred (100) feet, the following: 
1.  The boundaries of the property; 
2.  The location within the property of the structure to be served; 
3.  The location and profile, with respect to finished grade of the services; 
4.  Details of the proposed connections to the sewerage system, and arrangement and details of meter and sampler installation should they be required. 
B.  Written Agreement Required. The township will accept industrial wastes into the sanitary sewage system upon execution of a formal, written agreement, and under and subject to the provisions appearing in such agreement and the rules stated hereinafter. The agreement will set out in detail the acceptable characteristics of the wastes, the flow conditions which shall govern, the conditions and costs with respect to the physical connection or connections and the annual service charges. It will be the policy of the sewer department to consider each application on its merits, and to establish specific conditions applicable to the particular situation for each agreement. No connection shall be made prior to execution of the agreement. All proposed industrial discharge must have the endorsement of the Gloucester County Utilities Authority and comply with all of the Authority's industrial pretreatment requirements. 
C.  Application for Construction Approval for Commercial or Industrial Applicants. 
1.  Purpose of Application. Prior to approving an application for a connection involving the acceptance of industrial wastes, the applicant shall submit complete data along with a completed industrial sewer connection application Form F. This application and supporting data specifying the engineering details of the proposed project will be analyzed for compliance with township engineering standards, including provision for orderly growth. The final condition of approval will be a mutual agreement between the applicant and the township regarding the terms and conditions for providing water and sewer service. 
2.  Forms and Supporting Data. 
a.  Application Form. The applicant shall submit Form F, Site Plan: Commercial or Industrial Application for Review of Plans for Public Sewer to the township. 
b.  Supporting Data. Supporting data shall consist of four sets of drawings, reports and other pertinent data describing details of the sanitary sewer system. If additional data is required after the initial review, the applicant will be contacted to submit same to the township. 
3.  Fees. 
a.  Filing Fee. The filing fee shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
b.  Review Fee. The review fee shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first five thousand (5,000) square feet, or any portion thereof, and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each additional five hundred (500) square feet, or any portion thereof. 
c.  Inspection Fee. There shall be an inspection fee of five percent of the total sewer construction cost, as verified by the township engineer, to be deposited in an escrow account. 
    The applicant shall increase portions of the escrow account as required by the township. The actual amounts of review and inspection fees shall be based on vouchers and all surpluses shall be returned to the applicant when the respective phases are completed. 
4.  Action by the Township. The application and supporting data will be reviewed by the township. If it is determined that it is feasible to extend service and that the plans are in compliance with the sewer department rates, rules and regulations, the applicant will be notified of the township's approval and the connection fee. Upon receipt of the fee, the sewer permits will be issued to the applicant and to the building inspector. 
5.  Industrial Wastes. Prior to approving an application for a connection involving the acceptance of industrial wastes, the applicant shall submit complete data with respect to the following: 
a.  Completed industrial sewer connection application Form F; 
b.  Average, maximum and minimum rates of flow to be expected daily and seasonally; 
c.  Flow diagram, showing points of application of chemicals, type and quantity of each chemical used per day and per shift, a schedule of operations, expected chemical characteristics of the untreated wastes and the point or points of connection to the sewerage system. The normal situation will require the separation of, and separate points of connection for, domestic sewage and industrial wastes for each industrial establishment. 
D.  Prohibited Wastes. Wastes containing the following substances or possessing the characteristics listed below will not be accepted: 
1.  Any septic tank or cesspool wastewater; 
2.  Any fluids with temperature in excess of one hundred ten (110) degrees Fahrenheit; 
3.  Any fluid wastes which contain in excess of forty (40) mg/l of fat, oil grease, either vegetable or mineral; 
4.  Any volatile, explosive or flammable substance such as: benzene, gasoline, naphtha, fuel oil or similar substances; 
5.  Any solid or viscous matter which may cause any interference with the flow of wastes such as: ashes, cinders, concrete, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, hair or similar substances. Equipment or trucks carrying such materials shall not be washed and this water discharged into the system; 
6.  Any fluid wastes having a pH value less than 6.5 or in excess of 10.0, or possessing other properties capable of causing damage or hazard to sewers, structures, treatment process, equipment or operating personnel; 
7.  All wastewater constituents or characteristics prohibited by the Gloucester County Utilities Authority; 
8.  Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance which is capable of causing a public nuisance; 
9.  Any radioactive substances; 
10.  Any wastes containing components which exceed limits set forth by the county, state or federal regulatory agencies. 
E.  Grease, Oil and Sand Separators. When, in the reasonable opinion of the township engineer, grease, oil and sand interceptors or oil reclaimers are required, they shall be provided and maintained at the expense of the owner in continuously efficient operating condition. The owner will be required, upon request, to provide written verification or documentation that the units are being cleaned at a frequency acceptable to the township and to the Gloucester County Utilities Authority. Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperatures. They shall be watertight, substantially constructed and equipped with readily removable access covers. Where deemed necessary cold water sprays shall be installed. The design and pertinent data shall be submitted to the township for review and approval prior to construction or installation. Separators must be constructed entirely on the property of the owner. 
F.  Pretreatment. The township reserves the right to require pretreatment and/or flow equalization where the chemical or flow characteristics of the proposed industrial wastes, in the opinion of the township engineer or the Gloucester County Utilities Authority or of state or federal agencies, make such pretreatment or flow equalization desirable or mandatory. Some of the characteristics which may indicate pretreatment is needed are listed below: 
1.  Five day BOD in excess of three hundred (300) mg/l; 
2.  Suspended solids in excess of three hundred (300) mg/l. 
    In such instances where it is agreed that the industrial waste will be received following pretreatment in accordance with the Sewer Use and Pretreatment Rules and Regulations of the Gloucester County Utilities Authority, drawings and specifications shall be submitted for approval of the township engineer and the Authority. 
    Where pretreatment and/or flow equalization facilities are required, they shall be provided and continuously maintained in an effectively operating condition at all times, at the expense of the industry. 
    Each industry connected to the township sewer system shall be responsible for maintaining a quality of effluent from their premises which conform to the provisions established in their agreement with the township and in compliance with the Sewer Use and Pretreatment Rules and Regulations of the Gloucester County Utilities Authority. 
    The cost of preparing and submitting this data for consideration by the township shall be borne by the industry. Likewise, the cost of sampling and analysis to determine compliance with the terms of the agreement shall be borne by the industry, although conducted by the township or its duly authorized representative. 
G.  Control Manhole. Industries permitted to connect to township sewers, even though not initially being required to provide preliminary treatment, may be required to provide a control manhole and/or meter and sampler as described in subsection I of this section. 
H.  Violations and Penalties. In the event that any industry fails to conform to these regulations or fails to comply with the terms and conditions of their agreement with the township, which failure causes damage of any sort to the township's sewer system or the township's employees, the township reserves the right to cancel any agreement with the industry and terminate service to the industry. The township shall determine the extent of the damage and bill the industry accordingly. If such bill is not paid within thirty (30) calendar days from the date of the bill, legal action may be instituted to enforce collection. 
    The township reserves the right to cancel the agreement, upon ninety (90) days written notice, in the event of repeated failure to comply with the terms of the agreement or the rates, rules and regulations of the township. 
I.  Industrial Waste Flowmeter and Sampler. Where deemed necessary by the township, industrial and/or commercial customers may be required to provide an approved flow measurement and sampling system. The requirement to furnish, install and maintain a flowmeter of the indicator-register-recorder type to measure the discharge of industrial wastes and a wastewater sampler to periodically take and preserve a portion of the wastewater stream is described in subsection F of this section. The flowmeter and wastewater sampler will be approved by the township but supplied by the customer with the cost of such equipment and installation to be borne by the industry. All cost of furnishing, installing and maintaining the industrial waste flow and sampling equipment will be borne by the industry and shall be readily accessible to township personnel. Township personnel shall have the right to enter the establishment of an industrial user for inspection. 
J.  Treatment of High Strength Industrial Wastewaters. High strength wastewaters, including pretreated wastewaters will be subject to a rate surcharge if they unduly add to the expense of operating and maintaining the collection system or surcharges to the township from the Gloucester County Utilities Authority. The surcharge for industrial wastewater shall be based on the strength of the industrial wastewater. 
K.  Industrial Sewer Rates. The industrial sewer rate and surcharges will be addressed in the agreement between the industry and the township. 
    Sewer service charges for domestic sewage discharge from general warehousing/light manufacturing facilities shall be billed on a quarterly basis for sewer service, using actual water metered per quarter divided by ninety-one (91) days in order to establish the average daily flow of sewage. The sewer service charge shall be calculated by dividing the average daily flow by three hundred (300) GPD to establish the number of domestic consumer units, one unit minimum, multiplied by the annual rate per domestic consumer unit currently in use by the township. 
    Users not serviced by public water, but utilizing the convenience of public sewer, must install, at the owner's expense, a direct externally read water meter at the well location in order that a township representative can make the necessary water readings to substantiate the sewer rates. 
L.  Industrial Connection Charge. The following data shall be used to establish the industrial connection charge for industrial wastewater: 
1.  For industrial wastewater not subject to metering and/or sampling, one industrial connection unit shall equal three hundred (300) gallons per day of wastewater flow. 
2.  For industrial wastewaters subject to meter and/or sampling, the number of industrial connection units shall be derived based on the formula: 
Highest Annual Peak Flow or Permit Flow __________300 GPD 300 GPD  
    The industrial connection charge is based on one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per industrial connection unit. 
M.  Industrial Service Revisions. The industrial wastewater parameters and the criteria for industrial waste limits are subject to future revision or modification as may be required by the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, the Gloucester County Utilities Authority, the Delaware River Basin Commission and the township of East Greenwich. 
N.  Mobilehome Park and Campgrounds. Each mobile home site shall be charged as one connection unit and, in the case of a campground, every six sites approved by the township shall constitute one connection unit. However, calculations made the by the township engineer may result in fewer sites constituting one connection unit and the applicant will be so notified. 
(Prior code § 10A-5) 
13.08.070 - Sewer main extensions. 
A.  General Provisions. Persons proposing subdivisions or developments requiring a main extension for sewer service shall prepare applications described in this section with the necessary supporting documents. The policy of the township is to permit extensions only when paid for and installed by the applicant. No facilities for collection, treatment or disposal of sewage within the district of the township, which corresponds with the boundaries of the township, shall be constructed unless the township shall give its consent and the township engineer shall approve contract plans and specifications therefore. 
B.  Auxiliary Electrical Power. Auxiliary electrical power is required for all motors used for pump stations and other motor driven equipment as determined by the township. This shall apply to all major projects, which major project is defined as including, but not limited to, major subdivisions, general commercial projects and multiple occupancies in the excess of three domestic consumer units. The township reserves the right to make exceptions to this requirement when it appears that the imposition thereof will be patently inequitable. 
C.  Connections. Residential subdivision containing four or more contiguous building sites or lots or any residential structure to be used by three or more families, regardless of volume of flow, and all nonresidential developments such as schools, commercial buildings, industrial buildings and all other structures will be required to install a sanitary sewer system to be connected to the nearest existing sanitary sewer in the township. 
    Residential subdivisions containing three or less building sites or lots or if the lands are deemed by the township to be too remote from any existing facilities, then consideration will be given to an individual sewage system, with a dry sanitary sewer system for future use, in lieu of connection to existing facilities. Individual sewage disposal systems will be permitted only upon specific written permission of the township and approval by the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection. 
    Such individual system, plant or expansion of the location thereof shall be subject to approval by the township in accordance with the standards and requirements as hereinafter set forth. 
    Any main extension and related facilities installed under the provisions of this section shall be transferred to the township as hereinafter described. 
    During construction, but before final acceptance, the township shall have the right to use any completed portion of the system without waiving its right to further inspection or testing or to order correction of any defects. 
    Use of the sanitary sewer system for the discharge of sump pumps or drainage from cellar drains, floor drains, leaders, downspouts, drainage tile, swimming pools, cooling system drains and other similar discharges shall not be permitted. 
    Unpolluted industrial cooling waters and unpolluted drainage shall be discharged into a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
    These general provisions are and shall be subject to the existing contractual obligations outstanding. 
D.  Connection Fees-Delinquent Charges. It is the policy of the township to charge connection fees for connection of its sewer system following the rates as set forth in Section 13.08.140, Schedule IV. The connection fee is two thousand two hundred and forty-five dollars ($2,245.00) per domestic consumer unit. 
    Connection fees shall be payable within thirty (30) days of approval of the application by the township, unless specific arrangements are agreed upon. If payment is not received within this period, the applicant will be charged a delinquent charge of one and one-half percent per month and a certificate of occupancy will not be issued until the fee and delinquent charges are paid in full. 
E.  Applications-Fees. 
1.  Applications. A sequence of applications for sewer extensions are required for the township's determination of needs, availability of service, effect of proposed extension and inspection of installed extension. Application forms are available from the township. Chart I at the end of this chapter outlines the contents of this subsection and describes the sequence of applications, forms, supporting data, fees and township action that results in acceptable main extensions for sewer. No application will be considered unless a professional engineer, registered in the state of New Jersey, is in charge of the planning and design of the proposed sewerage facilities and has affixed his or her seal and signature thereto. Each application shall be submitted in duplicate with the designated fee to the township no less than thirty (30) days prior to the township committee meeting at which action on the application is desired. 
    Applications shall be signed by the owner or owners, or by a proper official of the company or, if signed by an authorized agent, a certified copy of the authorization of the company shall be attached to the application. 
2.  Fees. All fees accompanying applications shall be cash, certified check or acceptable other draft at the option of the township. Escrow fees are for professional reviews and inspections. These fees will be paid at each level of application submission. Outstanding balances will be refunded after all obligations have been met by the township at the time of total project completion, and legal acceptance by resolution or at the time of rejection. Before proceeding to the next level of application, it may be necessary to satisfy any outstanding deficit at the preceding application level. 
F.  Application for Feasibility. 
1.  Purpose of Application. An application describing the proposed project of residential, commercial, industrial or other development shall be submitted to the township with supporting data to determine the economic and technical feasibility of extending sewer service. The township may defer or waive certain parts of this supporting data at its discretion where the cost of data preparation is not commensurate with the development or project planning and approvals. 
2.  Forms and Supporting Data. 
a.  Application Form. The applicant shall submit Form A, Application for Report on Feasibility of Public Sewer Recommendations and Conditions to the township. 
b.  Supporting Data. In addition to preparation and submission of the application, the applicant shall furnish a general location plan showing streams, streets, blocks, lots and tax map numbers, copy of application submitted to the planning board, if required, location of any existing sanitary sewer systems in the area, proposed system outline and route of construction and estimated volume of flow. 
3.  Fees. The application shall be accompanied by a filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for sewer. A separate two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) minimum fee shall be deposited in the escrow fund for professional review. 
4.  Action by Township. The township shall analyze the submitted application and supporting data and report to the applicant the township's recommendations and/or findings. 
a.  Subdivisions and Site Plans. If the project is shown to be feasible, the applicant shall receive a letter of recommendations and conditions from the township along with Form B, Major Subdivision: Application for Review of Plans for Public Sewer, for the applicant's submittal. 
    If the township determines that the proposed subdivision or development is too remote for extending sewer service or contains circumstances which justify the use of an approved on-site septic system, the township may do the following: 
i.  Waive the application fee; 
ii.  Approve the application and waive all subsequent applications. 
G.  Application for Preliminary Approval. 
1.  Purpose of Application. An application and supporting data specifying the engineering details of the proposed project will be analyzed for compliance with township engineering standards, including provisions for orderly growth. 
    Form B shall be filed as an initial request after approval of Form A on all subdivisions. 
2.  Forms and Supporting Data. 
a.  Application Form. The applicant shall submit Form B, Major Subdivision: Application for Review of Plans for Public Sewer, to the township. 
b.  Supporting Data. 
i.  General. Upon formal approval by the township, the applicant shall submit all data required by the current rules and regulations of the Gloucester County Utilities Authority and the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection. The applicant shall submit the sewer permit application and the applicant shall pay all fees of the Gloucester County Utilities Authority and the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection. Permits to construct sewers and/or other structures within floodplains, wetlands and the right-of-way limits of state, county, municipal roads and all railroads. All other permits must be secured by and paid for by the applicant. 
ii.  Public Utility Approval. The applicant must inform and secure any necessary clearance and/or approval from any public utility involved. Proof of such notice and/or approvals shall be filed with the township. 
iii.  For Initial Sewer Permit Submittal. The applicant shall file the following fully executed papers with the township of submission to the Gloucester County Utilities Authority for its endorsement and the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection for state sewer permits: 
(A)  Two copies of completed CP-1 Form and copies of certified mail receipts indicating proper notification and distribution; 
(B)  Two copies of the engineer's report for sanitary sewer systems; 
(C)  Two sets of sanitary sewer specifications; 
(D)  Two sets of township approved sanitary sewer plans and profiles; 
(E)  Check for state review fees. 
    After the township engineer's comments have been addressed and the engineer has recommended approval, an additional six copies of the documents enumerated in subdivisions (iii)(A) through (D) of this subsection shall be submitted to the township. 
    No sewer permits will be issued until the preceding referenced data has been received by the township. 
iv.  Authorizing Resolution. The township will then adopt a resolution authorizing the township engineer to submit the plans and supporting data to the Gloucester County Utilities Authority for their endorsement and to the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection for their approval and issuance of the necessary permit. 
3.  Fees. The application fee shall be determined as follows: 
a.  Filing Fee. The filing fee shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
b.  Review Fee. The review fee shall be seven dollars fifty cents per domestic consumer unit for the first one hundred (100) units. Additionally, five dollars per domestic consumer unit for the next one hundred (100) units (one hundred ten (110) through two hundred (200)), and three dollars fifty cents per domestic consumer unit for all in excess of two hundred (200) units. 
c.  Minimum. The minimum amount to be placed in escrow fund necessary to initiate professional review of sewer systems will be as follows: A review fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be deposited for the first five thousand (5,000) square feet, or any portion thereof, and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each additional five thousand (5,000) square feet , or any portion thereof, for commercial or industrial areas. 
    In the event that costs of review shall be more than the amounts deposited, the applicant shall pay the additional cost prior to final approval by the township. 
4.  Action by Township. The application and supporting data will be reviewed by the township to determine compliance with the township's comprehensive sewer distribution plan, these rates, rules and regulations and supplements thereto, applicable statutes and projected growth patterns. A final condition of approval of this application shall be a mutual agreement between the applicant and the township regarding the terms and conditions for providing sewer service. 
    Any agreement at this stage would be conditioned upon the receipt of the approved permit from the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection, if required. A major element of this agreement shall include the legal description for all easements to be dedicated to the township as well as proof of executed easement agreements for sewer facilities that traverse land not owned by the applicant. Both easement legal descriptions and easement agreements shall include any restrictions prohibiting installation of fencing, shrubbery and other landscaping on any easements to be turned over to the township. 
    When the township has approved the plans, it will adopt a resolution authorizing submittal of plans to the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection for a state sewer permit. 
    Upon notification by the township that approval from the NJ. Department of Environmental Protection has been given to the proposed project and necessary sewer permits have been received from them, the applicant may file an application or series of applications for construction approval as set forth in subsection H of this section, with a period not to exceed two years from the date of approval by the township or from the date of receipt of the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection permits that may be required, whichever is the later date, unless otherwise waived by the township if such waiver is within the jurisdictions of the township. 
H.  Application for Construction Approval. 
1.  Purpose of Application. Following approval of the application for preliminary approval for a period not to exceed two years, the applicant may apply for construction approval. This application may be submitted as a sequence of applications as each segment of the total approved project is scheduled for construction. This application provides a control on the extent and schedule of planned sewer facilities installation and establishes a schedule for township inspection of completed installations. 
2.  Forms and Supporting Data. 
a.  Form. The applicant shall submit Form C, Application for Construction of Public Sewer System, to the township. 
b.  Supporting Data. Where the plans of final sections which are being submitted for authorization to construction are identical to those approved by the township and the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection, no additional sewer utility plans need accompany the submittal. However, the project professional engineer shall sign, seal and certify a letter attesting to the accuracy of the plans. 
    The application shall be accompanied by two sets of final data as approved on the preliminary approval, as per subsection (G)(2) of this section. This data will be the basis of construction approval, inspection and testing. Requested major revisions will be treated as resubmissions of preliminary approval requiring review and approval. Such revisions are subject to the requirements of subsection G of this section in its entirety. 
3.  Performance Bond or Surety Documents. A performance bond or surety documents, in a form satisfactory to the township, shall be submitted to the township prior to township approval of the application. The bond or letter of credit shall be in the amount of one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the total estimated construction costs, as verified by the township, for the final section or sections covered by the application. This bond or letter of credit shall guarantee complete construction within the time period specified by the township and shall further guarantee that such construction shall be in accordance with the final plans and specifications approved by the township and the N.J. Department of Environmental Protection. 
    The bond or surety documents shall remain in effect until the sanitary sewer collection system and related appurtenances are installed, tested and protected by an adequate layer of flexible bituminous paving or approved equal. Subject to the recommendation and approval of the township engineer, the bond or surety documents will be released upon receipt of a two-year maintenance bond equal to fifty (50) percent of the performance bond. It shall be required that the bonding agent will notify the township ninety (90) days in advance of any expiration of bonds by certified mail. 
    The developer shall continue to be completely responsible for this section of the system until it is legally accepted by a township resolution.
